text:
Appearance: Nice cola-colored body with massive light brown head and a nice cascading effect.

Smell: As i was pouring, aroma was already all around. Dried fruits but the major coffee and cocoa kicks in. Smell a little like fresh-brewed coffee but more roasted than bitter. Some hops in there for good measure.

Taste: Sweet chocolate, very strong taste. Not as roasted as the smell, more on the malt side. A good hop presence near the middle to the end. Coffee in there also. Very good balance between sweet & bitter. Quite harmonious.

Mouthfeel: Creamy, smooth & milky. Rather low carbonation but very good body (medium). Literally wants to stay in my mouth.
Draft. Black with an average tan head. Aroma is coffee grounds, cocoa, and dark roasted malts. Taste is espresso, cocoa, and a little vanilla. Average thickness and dry on the finish.

Dark black in color...Aroma of light roasted malt notes, oats, light coffee... Flavor is lots of dark fruits, raisins, overripe fruits, dark roasted malts, oats... dry finish... Great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft to taster at The Pint Room. Looks good; a translucent cherry cola with foamy mocha head. Smells of dark malt, chocolate, caramel, roast, and piney hops. Tastes like it smells, but less piney, and a touch floral. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied. Solid, but smells better than it tastes.

Super tasty stout. Very dry and coffee flavored. Easy to drink. Pours dark brown with a tan head bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black pour from bottle at home. No head. Has a mild whiskey aroma with cocoa and fruity notes. good shit
Bomber shared with brian sara pledge lamont Dallas. ..pitch black pour with kaki head. .good shit
Bottle shared at Darkness day. Pours dark brown with big head. Smell of roasted wood and malts. Taste of strong roasted malts. Smooth finish. Good beer.
October 25, 2014 - bottle at Darkness. Dark brown pour with big head. Aroma and taste of roasted malt and hops. Relatively smooth and mild bitter finish.
"a decent take on a dry stout, but not quite standout. solid in every aspect, though. lots of roasted malt, maybe a tad hoppier than the norm for the style. dry, bitter finish."
Very enjoyable. Aromas of dark malt, chocolate, and vanilla. Flavors all came through in the taste. Very well balanced, silky smooth.

Sans grande surprise cette bière est brune avec une mousse beige. Au nez des notes de chocolat et de café froid, le tout agrémenté de houblon. Une bouche mince avec des notes de chocolat et de houblon. Pas mon style. (merci milan..pas la ville mais le gars)

Un stout pourpre qui construit une tête brune qui simpose rapidement. Une dentelle qui sinstalle après chaque gorgée. Un nez bien fruité et bien enlacé autour de notes sèches de cacao et de mélasse. Donc, des notes doranges, de raisins et de mûres qui vagabondent entre mes narines ravies. Sur mes papilles, des notes asséchantes de houblons américains et de malts bien travaillés. Je soupçonne le Cascade dans la salle à manger de ma langue avec un chandelier rempli de notes bien noires. Au palais, le liquide montre un corps moyen-faible avec un pétillement modéré et une texture huileuse. En finale, mon cerveau retient des notes amères de houblons bien aromatiques et des notes sèches de grains maltés. Très facile à boire. Un stout savoureux. Merci à Adam pour la bouteille.

Bottle, thnx to Bytemesis, cheers bro. Pours a very dark brown, almost black beer with a thick, creamy, beige head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla. Very subtle aromas, making it very inviting. Flavour is very nice, soft coffee fudge with caramel and vanilla touches in the background. Long lasting, bitter finish. Soft carbonation, decent mouthfeel. Awesome lacing on the glass, great beer. Incredible.

04-14-2011. 22 oz bottle.

A: Pours absolutely black with a thin layer of tan head, great lacing.

S: Smell is dominated by hops and lots of pine. Some burnt malts.

T: Really outstanding. Huge roasted malts, I mean really roasted, lots of nice bitter black coffee and chocolate. Some hop bitterness balances out the malt nicely. The finish is very dry with more roasted malts.

M: Medium bodied and creamy, good carbonation. 

O: A really great stout, very tasty and drinkable.

2011 bottle. Pours dark with a mahogany color if looked at closely. The head slowly dissipates and left a soft ring of foam that hugged my glass. In aroma I noticed sweet carmel malts, sugar, weak hop notes, and a mild roasted malt character. As for taste I picked up on carmel malts, medium level dry inducing malts, bittering hops, a pleasant roasty flavor, and a dark chocolate flavor. The finish had a nice dry intensity, there was a nice bitterness, and lastly the malts were lasting on my palate. It was a good finish but not great. Overall I enjoyed this but FFF stuff with a definitive hop character does seem to fall off when aging that I have experienced.

bomber black with dark brown full head aroma is extremely mild only smelling some roasted malt and maybe a hint of chocolate thin bodied but full on the palate roasty malt some nice flavors and well balanced

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Belmont bottle about a year ago. Pours an opaque dark brown with a medium brown head and decent lacing. Big sweet, malty aroma. Flavor of dark roasted malt that leaves a little long-lasting bitterness on the tongue. Pretty nice and true to form.
Coffee and leather aroma. Taste chocolate, some plastic, leather, dark roasted malts. Long chocolate aftertaste.
Black in the glass. Good sized head. Decent mixture of chocolate, coffee, malts and hops. Nice smell.
Bottle shared by Marcus pours black brown head. Taste is nice chocolate taste. Some bitter in the end.

Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours black with a modest tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a hearty dark molasses flavor with a hint of coffee, although its probably just the roasted malt. Very tasty.

Bomber from timfoolery. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is treacle and dark malt. Full bodied. Flavor is coffee, treacle, and smooth dark malt. No chocolate. Subtle. Smooth. Finishes quite tasty and almost dry. Excellent stout.

Black Sun is really quite a good beer, I would have expected more body and alcohol, but the flavor is quie nice. But with hints of vanilla and caramel, this stout is really surprisingly light and tasty.

A year old bottle. I try to let the hops fade in stouts at least a little bit.

light looking body with a head that is about a finger or more, loose and dissipates.
Nose is roast forward with strong hops batting second, hint of coffee in the roast.
Flavors are roasty and dry chocolate for most. hops brighten this up somewhat in a citrus sort of manor.
Mouthfeel is thinner and more carbonated then i prefer.

Decent beer, but out of my price range for what it is, but maybe there just isnt enough going on besides the hops. When i age other hoppy beers like Expo or Yeti they turn out great, this one, not so much.

Bottle courtesy of Jstax. Thanks. Pours a deep umber black color with a godd three finger eggshell foam that sticks around for a bit. On the nose its got some nice sweet malty chocolate with touches of pine and coffee. On the palate its creamy yet light and refreshing with great chocolate coffee notes that turn slightly bitter as the beer drys out on the finish. Tasty.

Bottle - thanks to Randy for taking time away from his golf game to find and mail me this. Pours deep reddish black with a medium tan creamy head that dissipates with some lacing. Aroma is coffee and dark roasted malts plus a touch of chocolate. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet and moderately astringent, with some citrus bitterness on the dry finish.

22oz bottle from Daknole, thanks 
Appearance: Black with a big tan head and lots of lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, milk chocolate, vanilla and coffee 
Taste: Roasted malts, chocolate and roasted coffee 
Very nice and roasty. Drank on stout day.
Pours coffee black with a thick mocha head. Smells very much like chocolate.  Stout is a bit watery on the tongue for my taste.  A good brew.

Has some very nice chocolate roast scents. Taste is similar but a little lighter, nice bitter finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2012 
Location: Bottle shared w/ jcos, 10/20/12


Aroma: The nose is somewhat hoppy, with some malts, fruit, coffee, and chocolate

Appearance: This one pours a dark brown color, with a light brown head and mid-heavy lace

Flavor: The taste of this one is light-medium sweet and decently hoppy

Palate: The body of this beer is medium, it is decently drinkable, slightly smooth, and has a medium dry finish

Overall Impression: 
Very solid, hoppy stout.  I liked it.  Three Floyds doesnt seem to miss all that often in my opinion, and this one is no exception.
Bottle.  Pours black with beige head and lacing.  Nose is roasted coffee, caramel.  Dark chocolate, caramel, slightly hoppy.  Light body, very drinkable.
Pours the standard black with tan head.  Smells of both chocolate and caramel - not overly sweet, but there is a sweetness in it.  Dry, as expected...easy to drink though.

22 oz. bottle, pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma of grassy hops, dark roasted malt, and some mild dry cocoa powder. Flavour is quite full for being only 6.5%, with dry cocoa powder, some milky qualities, some dry roast, but keeps bringing me back to milk chocolate / caramel qualities, Quite full-bodied for the strength, finishes slighty sweet and milky, with a slight hop kick. Solid stout.
great easy drinking stout, perfect mouth feel, packed full of malty deliciousness

22 ounce bottle.  Pours almost black with a nice thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.  Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, caramel, and hops.  Lots going on here.  Nice.

Taster @ deans. Aroma is chocolate, almost creamy, some roast, nice. 
Flavour is big roast, huge chocolate, some liquorice, very full for the abv. Great.
Very dark brown, frothy head. Mild aroma, milk chocolate, roasted and clove and nutmeg. Quite rich for the abv. Nice mild sweetness at first, dried bitterness down. (At Deans Tasting)

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours black with a small beige head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, light roasted malt and coffee.  Flavour is medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Very full for the medium body.  Soft to moderate prickly carbonation.

66cl bottle shared.
Decent creamy tan head.  Clear dark pour.  Smooth dry taste.  Another great 3 Floyds beer.  Very drinkable.

Bottle: poured a black with light brown head. Aroma is very roasted coffee, nice hops. Nice rich coffee, roasted malts and nice hops on the back. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep black colour, with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma is of roasted barley with a larger hop presence tan expected for a stout. Taste is a little sweet and in line with the aroma, fairly bitter for a stout and quite dry. Creamy on the palate, medium body, good carbonation. Overall a unique and enjoyable brew.

Shared at my tasting on May 29, 2010. Thanks Jonathan!

This beer appears a near black, with an average sized head and adequate lacing. The aroma definitely smells like a foreign stout. The beer is decent tasting, with a slight alcoholic warming note in the finish. The carbonation level feels a bit low, which is in line with the style. The mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy. A pretty decent beer, but nothing leaps out. A fairly normal beer from a brewery that makes beers that are "not normal".

Black in color, with a pleasant industrial new car aroma to it.  Nice dry chocolaty bitter flavor. Some coffee notes as well come through on the tongue.  Overall, veddy tasty!  Thanks again to the always generous BarZigKin for sharing.

22oz bottle, unknown date.  Served at around 45F.

Pours dark brown to black with a three finger light brown head that retains exceptionally well and leaves some sheets and spots of lacing behind.

Aroma is roasted malts, some chocolate and coffee, dark fruit, caramel, also a good deal of hops, particularly pine, also this candy-like note I cant quite put my finger on.

Flavor is caramel, toffee, roasted malt, some chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, some citrus and pine hops, mild sweetness, decent bitterness for the style, minimal alcohol.

Mouthfeel is light/medium bodied, creamy, a bit sticky, good carbonation.

Pretty rich and robust for a Dry Stout.  Nice one.  Dunno if it is worth $10/bomber for something in this style, but good none-the-less.
Black body; thick tan head. Dry hoppy aroma. Soft dry texture; lightly roasty, hoppy flavor.

Pours black with nice, lingering beige head left substantial lacing. Typical stout aroma, sweet, light malt. Flavors of roasted malt and a hint of chocolate.  Some piney hops give it a little more bitterness than an average stout giving it a good balance. Its very creamy, pleasant mouth feel.

Not quite what I was expecting from an Irish stout but was pleasantly surprised. Quite hoppy, which was nice, but kept the rich & creamy tast of a stronger stout. Again, lots going on here for a 6.5% Irish Stout. would gladly drink again.

Pours deep brown/black with a huge mocha head.  Aroma is roasty with nice spicy/tea like hop notes...a bit of citrus.  Flavor has some burnt notes and cocoa...lots of nice hoppiness...spicy, citrusy...roasty.  mouthfeel is medium and the finish is roasty and bitter with great hop flavors.  An awesome hoppy/roasty stout!

Bomber from Marheb. Black with a generous light mocha head that fades quietly but can return quickly with a gentle swirling...somehow relaxing to watch and repeat...odd I know. Some cocoa, light roasted malts, bit of vanilla and coffee, along with toffee. High carbonation, moderate body, slightly bitter with a slight sweet tinge as the beer finishes (slight fig) however as it dries out on the palate it becomes more bitter again, lots of chocolate and a bit more coffee. This is a really nice drinkable stout - like the lower alcohol and the great taste - if I could ge this on a regular basis, maybe in a 12oz bottle, I would probably put this into the regular rotation.

I received a 22oz bottle in a trade with a friend (thanks, Joe!). I split it with a friend. We each poured it into imperial pint glasses.

Appearance: Opaque, seemingly black body (actually very dark ruby red). Forms a very large, fluffy, tightly compacted, dark tan head which retains and laces extremely well.

Smell: Piney, resiny hops are definitely the most prominent aroma. A subtle, typical stout scent is underlying, though.

Taste: Three Floyds is a brewery known for experimenting with styles and Black Sun Stout is definitely not your average beer. Supposedly its a dry stout, but a swig or two into it makes that a little difficult to believe. Its by far the hoppiest and most bitter "dry stout" Ive ever encountered. Sweet black licorice up front with a fairly generic, and rather mild stout palate. It changes on a dime as all the piney hops come rushing in with a strong burst of sappy, resiny, earthiness. Whats interesting is that they fade away quickly as the beer reverts back to the opening salvo of standard stout. Theres not much in the way of roasted malts, although there is a discernible coffee-like taste, but it doesnt last long. The beer finishes fairly clean, although the hops do add up by the end. Overall, a very interesting tasting experience. Not one that blew my mind, but it did give my taste buds something to talk about.

Drinkability: While this beer may be too complex and robust to truly be considered a dry stout, it definitely has the drinkability of one. The mouthfeel is on the thinner side with a low amount of carbonation. It goes down very smooth - so smooth in fact that its easy to drink in big gulps. Not that its refreshing or as delicious as a dessert beer, just a fun, original take on an otherwise pub style brew. Three Floyds website indicates its 6.5% ABV, but that seems a little high as it has the weight of something slightly smaller. I could see the average drinker enjoying multiple servings of this without being overwhelmed or bored.

Bottle from preismj, thanks! Great looking pour, black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt with coffee and dark chocolate in the background. Taste is light smoke, roastiness, meat, chocolate, coffee grind. Pretty light bodied, but with a long lasting finish, actually ends a bit sweet. A great beer, full flavored, surprised that the ABV isn´t higher. Would drink a lot of this if I had the chance.
Pours dark brown with light cereal notes.   Dry flavors drive the grain and roast nuts into a nice flavorful finish.
It smelled and tasted like fresh wort and it wasnt that fresh of a bottle. Not to style but I dont care it was delicious.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of drfabulous. Thanks Jeff! Pours a hazy, dark brown appearance with a fluffy, deep brown head. Roasty dark malty, slight pinesol/cleanser, organic aroma. Burnt, roasty, dark chocolate malty flavor again with a piney, cleanser-like flavor and a bit of fruitiness. Some nice elements like some roasty espresso, but I am totally getting a cleanser flavor that Im not fond of. I think its just that the hops are piney and sappy that I get the pinesol flavor. That being said, it isnt that hard to drink.

Very dark brown color with a medium tannish head.  First aroma had a distinct west coast aroma but upon resting the traditional 3F aroma comes out along with coffee notes, a burning alcohol feeling as it warms.  Taste is mild coffee along with a lingering pine note.  A medium to thin body helped by the frothy head that lingers.  Gains some momentum as you drink it but not as impressive as its price tag would lead you.

Refrigerated bomber poured into a shaker.  Pours black with small dark brown hightlights and fluffy creamy big light brown head.  Little lacing, medium creamy body, little carbonation, and light bitter hop aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, some coffee, and finish is bitter dry hops.  Best dry stout I have had.
Bottle pours a black beer with a thin tan head. Scent is coffee and roasted malts. Taste is coffee, sweet malts with an earthy bitter finish.

Bottle from kabutomushi. Thank you, sir. Piney hop aroma, with some dark chocolate (like a black IPA). Pitch black with a creamy dark head. Chocolate, wood, some citrus, very nice bitter aftertaste. Medium body. A very good hoppy mild stout.

Bomber shared by Kabutomushi. Nose of orange, lemon, big hops. A little bit of chocolate too, maybe. Black with lovely lace. Flavor is Belgian orange chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and wood. Light burn from the hops. Rich, thick body. A bit sweet. Is this really a black IPA?
Pours thick and dark brown, not at all transparent. Rather full-headed, with a brown head. Carbonation disappears quickly. It really is shockingly light for being a stout.
Hop and dark chocolate aromas.  Flavors of chocolate covered hops.  Overall a pretty impressive stout.
Bottle from Rozis, pour is a black with brown head light hop nose with plenty of roasty taste, bottle was frozen and thawed but still is carbonated not bad but not 8.99 a bottle tood

Black with a tannish brown small head that fades quickly. Aroma is a combination of a big roastiness balanced by a sweeter sugary chocolate. There is also a little smokiness and a decent amount of tart cherry in the smell. Flavor starts with a big deep roasted malt that goes quickly past a sweetness in the middle to a powerful sour-tart sweetness. A bit overpowering.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/3/2011.  2011 22 oz. bottle poured into a tulip.

Black Sun Stout is a deep ebony color with a small tan head that fades to a few wispy islands after a minute, leaving no real lace.

The aroma is full of rich dark chocolate and chocolate malt, roast coffee, roasted malt, a bit of anise, and some soft spicy pine in the background.

The flavor starts with a blast of dark roasted malt, dark burnt chocolate, and roast espresso. The flavor maintains and a creamy milkiness comes in midway, before a now faded level of citrus and pine hops. The finish is somewhat sweet, with chocolate flavors dominating, but with some citrusy hops also present.

It is tough to believe that this is 5.25% ABV, as this drinks much bigger. A rich, smooth, milky, creamy mouthfeel is very impressive. Slightly sticky on the lips. The remaining hops create some salivation and a light spicy prickle on the tongue. 

Especially compared to some of the more popular beers in the style (Guinness), this drinks bigger, has a bolder flavor, and is just better overall.

I picked up on a lot of tangerines and milk. This is the most unusual and interesting stout Ive had in a while.  Its really light bodied, easy to drink, and surprisingly black, despite the light flavor and texture.  If you drank it without seeing it, youd never guess that (1) it is so dark and (2) its a stout.  Really good stuff.

Poured deep black color with a brown head that left excellant lacing. Smell is piney hops come right through, paired with some roastiness and cocoa. Taste of coffee and cocoa paired with a wonderful piney hoppyness. Mouthfeel had medium carbonation.

22 ounce bottle into pint glass; no bottle dating but it is from this year.  Pours a clear very dark brown color with a nice 2-3 finger fairly dense tan head with great retention that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Some nice spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big roasted malt, toast, chocolate, biscuit, coffee, pine, and herbal hops.  Nice aromas with good strength and balance.  Taste of chocolate, toast, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, herbal hops, pine, biscuit, and a touch of molasses.  Good amount of herbal/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of chocolate, coffee, caramel, herbal hops, and pine on the finish for a while.  Good hop to roasted malt flavor balance.  Medium carbonation and body; with a fairly creamy mouthfeel.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish.  Overall this is a very nice and interesting dry stout style.  Definitely a bit off the wall with the hoppy flavors; but it is nicely balanced and still has a good roasted character.  Enjoyed this one.

Poured from 22oz bottle.  Pours nearly black with loads of creamy tan head.  Aroma is some light coffee and cocoa.  Taste is just a touch of coffee and some smoke and roasted malts.  Very mellow and easy to drink.

2010 bottle thats been aging in the cellar. Black liquorice, dark chocolate, prune aroma.  Black with a small brown head. Dark roasted coffee, wood, charcoal, bitter orange peel hops flavor. Body was a tad on the light side, dry finish.

Another great beer from FFF. this was just a random pick up just because of the brewerys name. It turned out to be quite nice. It was a really nice blend of lots of hops and nice roasty malt backbone of a typical stout. It was citrusy hop character and it was really nice offering, could be a black IPA in my book
Black, tan head. Oh, thanks travlr! Um. Pine scents at first, followed by smoked meat. Interesting? Venison jerky, gosh darn it. Tastes smoky, piney, and good.

A - pours deep dark opaque black that has 1 finger chocolate brown head that dissipates. S - pine and grassy hops, burned malts, smells dry and peppery. Leather, fresh coconut and dried wood as well. M - surprisingly light and airy dry stout. Lingering burned malts and smoky end. T - smoke and burned malts on the end. Coconut, leather, dark chocolate on the palate. Lingering tobacco burned malt ending. O - interesting complex very dry stout. 7-/7

Bottle. Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma is of pine, roasted malt, coffee, dark caramel and chocolate. The flavor is of piney and citrus hops, roasted malt, coffee, dark caramel, chocolate and some dark fruit notes. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty tasty Dry Stout even though its kind of out of style since its hoppy. But certainly much more tasty than Guinness etc.
Great color with good tan head. Slightly more hoppy than most stouts. Nice carmel with coffee undertones. Smooth finish. Three Floyds has yet to let me down. Another great beer.
Pours a black body with a thin tan head. Begins with some caramel, coffee, and citrus - quite hoppy. Ends slightly dry. Good.

Black Sun pours pitch black.  Medium sized tan head.  Minimal lacing.  The most apparent smell in this beer is a rich, sweet dark chocolate.  It smells great.  Backing that up is a good amount of roasted malt, caramel, brown sugar, and a small amount of coffee. A really nice big smell for a lower abv stout.

Taste is just as good.  Its slightly dry and chewy.  The dark chocolate gives off a bit of a bitter taste.  The coffee shows up a little bit more then it did in the smell.  Rounding the taste out is the caramel.  Mouthfeel is slightly dry, chewy, silky, and a little bit towards the thick side.
Three Floyds is always on the ball and they dont disappoint here.  A lighter Stout with an interesting hoppiness.
Three floyds hardly ever disapoints. This was a nice tasting stout. Kind of spendy, wouldnt be buying it everyday, but a good one to pull out and pour with someone who appreciates beer

Poured from bomber into a pint glass. Pours a straight black color with a foamy head

the hop aromas are a bit odd along with more expected aromas of roasted coffee beans, malts and hot caramel

The flavors were a complete mess. The hops really dominated and left a bitter aftertaste. The feel was pretty good, but it didnt make up for how bad the hop flavor was on this

Very disappointing. The hops completely overpowered the other flavors when tasting it while they were pulled back a bit with the aromas. Not one of the better beers on the day
noticably lighter than most big stouts but it tasted much heavier than a 5% beer.

22oz bottle. Black body with small tan head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some chocolate, light peach. Taste is medium sweet, bittersweet chocolate, roasty, with a grapefruit finish. Light-medium body. Much more hops than what I think of in a dry stout.

Bomber. Pours a deep black with slight reddish hues. Big Frothy chocolate colored head that dissipated and laced nicely. Aroma is roasted malt, toffee, some vanilla. Taste is a mouthy roasted toffee, slight chocolate and vanilla, balanced nicely by a slight bitter hop. Very good dry stout indeed. A great offering!

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. The beer is dense black with a thick, khaki colored head that slowly dissipates. Aroma is dark chocolates, toasty notes, caramel, vanilla, and coffee. Taste is sweet and reminiscent of the nose. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. Hands down the best dry stout Ive ever come across.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on January 25th, 2011.
Appearance: Pours black with faint red head. 
Aroma: Aroma is malty, with faint chocolate and coffee.
Taste:Taste is similar to the nose.
Palate:Lighter for stouts in general, but nice level.
Summary: Its nice to have a tasty stout that isnt imperial for once. And as usual Three Floyds delivers.

Very roasty and full flavored, yet light bodied and light in alcohol.  Very complex palate with a lot of roasted malt, coffee, a little choclate and maybe a bit of hops.  Was interesting to see a s stout thats so low in alcohol have such a good flavor.

Black pour, thick tan head.  Aromas of caramel, and pine hops.  Nice balanced flavor.  Not an overly bitter coffee flavor.  Medium bodied, like a porter and a bit creamy.  Nice dry finish.  Overall, another solid one by FFF.  I like this one as it is very sessionable.

Bottle shared with evanlarkin.  Black, large variegated brown and tan head, solid lacing.  Aroma of pine and dark milk chocolate.  Taste resembles an espresso pot left on the burner way too long.  Nice stuff.

Overall: Three Floyds has a nice dry stout here, but nothing spectacular. It isnt particularly difficult to quaff, with a mild mouthfeel and relatively low ABV, but it also isnt something Id go crazy to try and get. Good for a lazy Sunday evening.

Pours very dark brown with huge tan head.  The nose is noticeably hoppy with notes of pine and citrus but I definitely get some of the roasted, coffee notes in there as well.  Taste is bitter roasted malts with a lot of high-alpha hop goodness and a dry finish.  This is really good.  By far my favorite dry stout.

Bomber purchased at the source. Pour is a damn dark black brown colour, with a decent head that dies down to a thin sheet of tan head, and thick lacing. Aroma is super piney hops, a little citrus too, there is some roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Tastes a tiny bit bitter, dry, chocolate and coffee malt, a little citrus in there too. The finish is without a doubt malt. Nice stuff.
Bottle. Black, opaque, with a thick tan head. Smoke malt aroma, pepper and some citrus. Roasted malt, bitter, coffee, dry finish.
bottle. pours black with a gorgeous strawberry/brown head. aroma of chocolate coverd hops sprinkled with coffee. taste is very silky with hops mixing well with the chocolate and roasted malts.
Bomber from the beer closet.  Pours dark / almost black.  Taste and nose is mild...not as bold as one would expect from 3F...a good but not great stout
Sweet coffee aroma. Really dark color. Medium head with a little lacing.  Taste is mostly hops, but the after taste turns into coffee then sweet caramel. This is pretty tasty and definitely complex.

Its not a normal stout..  This one is less about burnt coffee notes,  and more about a nice hoppy undertone..

Easily one of the best and most balanced beers I ever had the privilege of having. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: Deep brown black body with a large frothy khaki head.  Eventually subsides to a nice full skim.  Substantial lacing left behind after each sip

S: Bright piney and citric hops are the first notes to hit the nose.  Roasted malts, dark chocolate and traces of espresso are also present.

T: Like the nose, this is a rather hoppy stout but there is also a fair amount of roasted malts, chocolate and caramel malt.  

M: Medium full mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, lively bitterness, long dry finish. 

O: A tasty hoppy stout.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with a couple inch tan head that stayed around a long time.  Theres also a lot of lacing.  The brew smells like roasted malt, piney hops, coffee, and bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also the addition of some light citrusy hops.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and a bit slick with a good amount of carbonation.  Its also smooth and goes down pretty easy.  This is definitely one of the better hoppy stouts that Ive had, too bad Three Floyds doesnt make this one year round.

~Has a high piney hop aroma with  coffee and chocolate malts.
~Pours black with dense creamy brown lasting head.
~Piney hop flavors with roasty almost burnt tasting malts. 
~Medium light bodied with medium CO2, piney roasty lasting finish.
~This is more of a black IPA than a dry stout. Hops are way too strong in this for my taste. I didnt get any caramel sweetness like description says. Caramel malts would make a great balance for this beer.   I think my expectations were too high for this and I feel let down. Still a good brew just not great. Too hoppy and not balanced. It does get much better as it warms and I raised my rating a bit.

Ive waited most of a year to try this one, and it meets my high expectations.  Another winner from Three Floyds, which I wish was available year round.  Bomber pours an opaque very dark brown, almost black, with a frothy and lingering tan head.  The first whiff was full of piney hops, like so many other good FFF brews.  Aroma is more what I would expect from a stout: rasted coffee, roasted malts and perhaps a bit of chocolate. Taste is almost bitter on the tongue but the long satisfying finish is malty and chocolate.  This one got even better as it warmed up.   I look forward to the next time I see a Black Sun available: hopefully before the next solar eclipse.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle via trade.  It pours pitch black with a small but dense head of tan foam.  The nose has a good dose of roasted malt with a nice coffee background.  Perhaps a bit of dark chocolate as well.  The flavor is very well balanced with lots of roast (but not burnt), coffee, and a touch of sweetness.  Leaning towards more medium bodied with a drier finish.  I could drink a lot of this brew.  It goes to show that a stout doesnt have to be imperial to be great.  Highly recommended.

Smells of dark coffee and

Jet black with a small tan head. 

Taste of coffee, dark chocolate, pine and citrus hops.  Lots of hops for this style.  Dry finish. 

Overall this is a very good beer.  The flavors are much more complex than a typical Stout, more of an Imperial with low ABV.

Pours dark coffee chestnut black with a big creamy caramel head. The aroma is light sweet and smoky. The flavor is starts out with a bit bitter hops and then ends with the hops slowly fading and a noticeably dry ending. The body is medium and smooth.
Pine and caramel in the nose.  Citrus flavor from the hops.  Malty brown sugar goodness.  Not a typical stout.  Relatively unique.  Lighter body. Dry finish.  Very good.

Tasted on 12/29/11 from a 22oz bomber bottle purchased at Lush West Town.  Pours an extremely dark, oily black, with an average tan head that slowly recedes to thin, spotty lace.  The nose is very dry, with some fruity aromas, dark chocolate, caramel, coffee, and some spicy hops bitterness.  The flavor is the same, with caramel, dark chocolate, milk chocolate, coffee, and fruity, spicy hops.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long, dark chocolate, coffee, spicy, and fruity hops.
The best Irish dry stout Ive ever had.  Depth of flavor, great roasted caramel malt flavor with a good medium body.

Aroma: Caramel, coffee with hints of roasted malts, but also a sense of smokiness--almost a burnt aroma. 
Appearance: Black with a rocky tan head.
Taste: Medium bitterness and medium sourness all the way through. They play off of each other nicely.
Palate: Light-medium body, slick texture, average carbonation, dry finish; no bizarre aftertaste or long hoppiness, but not too short, either.
Overall: Im not so bowled over that Im completely undone, but this is still a really solid and well developed beer with lots to say for it. Id certainly hunt this down next winter. Its a really good beer.

A delightfully opaque and dry stout. Pine and citrus in the nose, light mouthfeel for such a dark beer and a clean finish (something a lot of stouts dont have). Id rate this in the same ballpark as a Guinness, but with more body and less bitterness. One of my favorites from FFF. Too bad it isnt available year-round.

Black in the glass with a medium sized, frothy, tan head that leaves stringy rings of lace. Light roast, coffee, brown sugar, and piney hops on the nose. Smooth chocolate and coffee flavor, with light roast and a dry, balanced finish. A bit of hops linger afterward. Light, well carbonated body. Pretty good, really dry.
Awesome aroma of piney hops and coffee notes. Creamy mouth feel. Very tasty sessionable stout with dry finish. Another great brew from FFF!

Got this from my brother. Now thats love. Pours black with a nice tan head. Creamy with pronounced piney hop aroma. Some coffee. Creamy mouthfeel and medium body. Taste of hopiness in first sip. Lingering flavors of coffee, roast, and some caramel. Finishes with a little dryness.

22 oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma has coffee, roastiness, brown sugar, cocoa, and dark fruit, with a light citrus hoppiness.  Flavor includes molasses, roastiness, somewhat tart, finishing with coffee, a little ashiness, citrus and slight herbal hoppiness.  Pretty darn good.

Draft at Sugar Maple.  Pitch black.  Rusty beige head.  Smooth and rich.  FFF packs in the chocolate and still keeps it balanced.  Rich and roasty, lot of specialty malt.  Excellent, nails it like FFF often does.  Medium to full bodied, but quite sessionable.  Mossy finish.  Right on.

22 ounce bottle that poured a jet black color.  Aromas of roasted malt, smoke, dark fruits, and a touch of milk.  Flavors are big, bold and balanced of the aroma, real nice beer that i could continue to drink all day.

22oz bottle, actually 2 years aged (i"m pretty sure).  Pours out a nice black hue, off white head.  Aromas arent that robust, slightly malty, some roasty notes.  Palate is decently balanced, cocoa is light, coffee hints, very easy drinking.  ABV is right on the money, no off flavors or burn.  Pretty light on the flavor however.

Bomber thanks to the always Epic- footbalm. Thanks Eric. Pours a viscous oily black color with a small beige head. The aroma is massive and very much suggestive of a much stronger beer; huge dark fruits, prunes and plum, milk and char. The flavor is similarly super rich; dark fruit, some tartness, ash, light smoke, caramel, a heavy roast. Wait, this cant be 5 percent? Show me the proof this is bigger than 90% of 10% percent beers. The palate shows both some thinness and also a robust carbonation when given some effort. Excellent. All day long, this beer could be imbibed.

Very dark brown with little head.  Nose of dark dried fruits, wood, a touch of smoke, and....white glue....?  Medium body with good carbonation.  Taste of molasses, bakers chocolate, and coffee.  Dry.  Not bad, but boring.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2013 65cl, no mention of ABV, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex dry Stout, malty/roasted and slightly bitter/fruity, balanced, hazy, small head, good Winter brew, yet expensive!

Poured a very dark brown color with a small tan head and brown oily film on the glass. Roasted malt aroma had a good amount of coffee and a large amount of piney hops. The flavor consisted of chocolate and coffee with more piney hop. Finishes a little thin. Medium bodied.
Holy crap I cant believe I love a dry stout, very rich dry stout, perfect finish,

Bottle via a trade. Pours with a black body and a lasting tan head. Aromas are roast, floral, chocolate, tobacco, rich, lightly vinous, hickory, dark currants, fudge, milk chocolate. A lot going on for a smaller beer. Flavors of tobacco, earthy, ashy, chocolate covered raisins, tar, iodine, and biscottis. Medium bubbles, medium bodied, creamy. Tasty.
A really awesome dry stout.

05 vintage shared by and sampled with my fellow beer geek and friend.  Poured absolutely flat and midnight black, as expected.  The aroma is full and rich with notes of molasses, over ripe fruit, and just a touch of roasted coffee.  Really enjoyed.

picked up a bottle of this at the casanova in WI.   Pours almost black with a dark head that is there for longer than I can wait to taste the beer.  smell is ok, nothing special, some coffee and chocolate with roasted malt.  Taste is the same as the smell with a good roasty coffe taste with a chocolate finish. Very easy to drink.
Bottle. Tanx to Micke. Black body and a brown head. Aroma hopy and some burnt malt. Flavor got coffee and in the same way fresh from flowers and little sweetnes.
Almost black with à Brown head. Hoppy nose mixer with some dark malts. Sweet caramel. Same in the mouth with à bitter ending. Almost a black ipa due to its hoppyness.

light black body with a finger of tan head, good retention, ok lace... nice nose that doesnt mess around, dry and roasted coffee, simple but nice, does have  an off vegetal note that bothers me a bit... taste is also a bit vegetal, peppery, spicy coffee, dry coffee finish, a little weird but good... a touch to carbonated... decent overall but not one of their best beers

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 Dark brown almost black pour with tan head.  Being a homebrewer, I am familiar with the aroma of brewing beer and this brew exemplifies the fresh piney hops and malts of a fresh brew even after sitting in the bottle in my cellar for 5 months.  Medium bodied with mild coffee notes, pine, and chocolate as well. Another fabulous offering from 3F.  Exemplifies the signature Floyds terroir of heavy hops and plenty of malt body to balance.
RE-RATING:
2010 Vintage bottle consumed Christmas Day.... all of the above but with a delicious hint of vanilla.  This one really holds up, unexpected with the low abv.

Picked this bottle up over Christmas back in the Midwest. Served in a wine glass.

Pours near black with a big tan-mocha head. Quite creamy and sticks around for a good period of time before falling into a nice cap and leaving some spotty lacing. The nose is pretty underwhelming with some roasted notes and a bit of coffee. The taste amps things up a bit with some stronger roast and espresso notes plus a bit of dark chocolate. Body is medium without any noticeable alcohol and has a fairly-dry finish. Pretty drinkable and one of the better versions of this style that Ive had, but nothing earth-shattering.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-24-2011
Bottle split with Pat and PJ. Pours a dark body with nice lacing. Aroma is sweet malty notes and some roast and caramel. Great mouthfeel and similar notes in the flavor

Bomber. Pours black with brown translucent edges when put up to a light. The tan head quickly diminishes but creates some decent lacing. The aroma is very, very interesting. Lots of hops, chocolate, and some burnt notes. The initial flavors are rather interesting as well, because some werent noticeable in the aroma. All kinds of citrus and fruit is apparent. Some roasted notes start to creep through when it warms, along with a slight bitterness and burnt notes. Towards the finish, chocolate becomes more apparent. The roasted notes bursts, complementing the chocolate quite well. Citrus becomes overwhelmed by the other flavors, but is still noticeable towards the end. I wasnt prepared for this, but was pleasantly surprised.

pitch black with large tan head.  nose of medium and low crystal malt.  some bitterness before the above crystal malts with touches of near molasses prior to some citrus hop notes.  the roasted malt is present but understated and little yeast component is placed.  there is almost flavors of vanilla and near oak character.  a lingering and flavorful finish.  overall it is an excellent and flavorful stout, though i would say it is more of an american stout than a dry stout, since the finish and components dont resemble the traditional version.  overall a great beer though

The pour on this dry stout is jet black with a big, creamy tan head.  The aromas are fresh piney hops and dark roasted coffee with flavors of dark roasted malts, fruity sweetness, coffee with some dryness in the finish.  A light bodied and refreshing stout yet it is still quite flavorful and delicious.

22oz bottle in a tumbler.  Pours black with a thick, tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, a little smokiness, and the strong floral citrus hops standard of Three floyds.  Flavor a nice complex blend of these.  Average texture.  A great beer, as expected.

22oz Bottle.  Pours a color somewhere in between dark brown a black, with a thin tan head.  Aroma is hoppy, and roasted malt.  A little thin on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, caramel, hoppy up front, with a nice coffee, roasted malt finish.    Somewhat reminiscent of an American Black Ale.  Good, but for me, not the best from FFF.

I opened the bottle and got a good whiff of the aroma and wondered, "Did I buy an IPA by mistake?" No, the bottle says its a stout. Pours a nice, dark, black like a stout, with small, white head. Strong piney, hop aroma and hop flavor that makes this one of the most IPA-like stouts Ive ever had. Its interesting, but I wonder just a bit if they have any other tricks up their sleeve (see the wheat beer, Gumballhead, that also tastes more like an IPA). Guess Ill have to get my hands on a Dark Lord some time.
Hoppy aroma with the roasted stout characteristic as base. Taste has very much acid, pine and wood. A certain bitterness lingers in the back of the mouth. Ovrall too acidulous

Bottle (thanks to madvike)...  Poured black with a light tan/brownish head.  Decent amounts of roast, coffee and a light, drier body.  Lots of hop going on in Three Floyd style of course. A slight citrus hop presence to balance the roast and malt sweetness and also gave an added pineyness.

Coffee, graham cracker, and chocolate notes. Dry and medium bodied with a crisp hoppy finish. At only 5%, this wont fill you up too much, but will cleanse your palate quite nicely. Flavors of bitter malts and hops along with coffee, caramel, and citrus in the background. Nice dry stout.

Pours dark black with off white almost tan head.  Aroma has notes of chocolate, roast, some dark fruit and coffee, even a tiny bit of pine hops.  Taste is some pine up front, chocolate, coffee notes in the middle with a dry roasted finish.

Bottle from Phaleslu. Huge thanks for this one Peter. Pours solid black with a creamy, dense brown head. Aroma of roast malt, milky sweetness, more hop aroma than expected, cocoa, ashy. Taste is leans toward more sweetness than bitterness. There is a lot of chocolate, burnt malt, toffee sweetness. Great stuff. Medium body, thick texture, soft carbonation.

A: The beer pours a dark brown color with some reddish highlights and a creamy tan head.

S: A really surprising amount of hops on the nose. Lots of pine and probably even more grapefruit. A little bit of rubber, but otherwise a nice roasted malt aroma and perhaps some dark fruits.

T: The grapefruit flavor is bountiful and the pine provides a light bitterness. Toffee and roasted malts give this beer some feeling of a stout. However, the flavor seems a bit watered down.

M: Sort of watery on the tongue with a moderate carbonation.

D: Not like any Irish stout Ive had before. Quite hoppy, which was nice, but the watery nature of the flavor and mouthfeel was a let down.

Thanks Dave!  This was more than I expected from a style, dry stout.  This had a green piney nose.  The pine (to me) stayed thru out the nose and the taste and the finish.  Noticed some licorice along with the roasty bitterness.  The bitter was slightly stronger.  Finish had a dry woody pine.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2011 Bottle. Pour is black brown with a tight kahki head that dissipates to a little film. Aroma is smoky peat and beets. Taste is licorice and chocolatly malt that tastes burnt and toasted with a brazilian nut finish. Palate has a thick medium mouth feel and fizzy chaulky finish. This is very tasty and has a very complex mouth feel that makes this an awesome dry stout!
It was good. I had higher hopes for it, but it was a lot lighter than I thought it would be for being so dark. I like surprises though.

(22oz bottle courtesy of Lilo boy).  Pours black with creamy tan head.  Some lacing and small carbonation bubbles.  Aroma of nuts, cocoa, pine/wood, and something earthy.  Taste is sweet with a bitter, roasty finish.  Thin/medium bodied with a creamy texture.  Bitter finish.  Theres an off-taste (band-aid) in this that is distracting.  Not my favorite.

Typical for Three Floyds: nice packaging, good PR and a decent product--but it does not seem worth the premium price. No disrespect intended here. The aroma is a delight, the texture is creamy despite the body being light, and the finish is especially nice: sweet and long. But $8.50 for a bomber?

Bottle via Lushawn.  Sits pretty damn black.  Nice full sheet of dark tan on top.  Nose seems to suggest some sweetness for whatever reason...some roastiness, licorice,  and some caramel.  Flavors are relaxingly mellow and smooth...certainly a lot more sweetness than one would expect in a "dry" stout..medium body is able to carry the flavors well...but its got a lot of caramel, licorice, and just overall malt sweetness to be labeled a dry stout.  Its certainly enjoyable for a low gravity stout though...I cant usually dig on low gravity stout.

Brownish, borderline black, no head. Huge coffee, spicy hops, not much else. Flavor much the same, tons of coffee, long residuel aftertaste of wet coffee grinds. Me and coffee well....you know the drill.

Poured this from a 22oz bomber into a goblet glass. Pours an extremely dark brown, almost pitch black, with a 2-fingers worth of head. Eventually dissolves and leaves about a fingers worth.

On the nose, Im getting dark chocolate right away. Im also picking up some roasted malts. The hops come through on this stout. I like that. A little grapefruit in there.

The taste is a bittersweet chocolate. This is followed by a mellow coffee roastiness. A touch of grapefruit, just like the aroma. Finishes with a nice kick of hops. Just enough kick to let you know they are there. Not as "hidden" like in a sweeter stout but not "in-your-face" like an Imperial.

Medium-bodied. A little creamy but still drinkable. Had the whole bomber and it still left me wanting more!

Overall, a great brew from Three Floyds. I would highly recommend this to a Three Floyds fan. Actually, I would recommend this to a stout fan!

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Vin and Sean on the night of the launch of PhillyCraft. Pours a deep, black-coffee brown with zero head. Aroma of espresso beans, chocolate, licorice, graham crackers, and roasted malts. Medium bodied with a cool, dry palate. Smooth, extra airy and dry finish, This is a remakable stout. The espresso and chcolate flavors mingle perfectly with the underlying dryness. Drinks almost like room temperature coffee. Very good.

Bottle courtesy Josh - thank you!  Thin brown head.  Aroma is dry roasted malt, peat, pronounced molasses, and some caramel notes.  Interesting twist on the aroma.  Taste is roasted malt up front followed by sweet malt and near-raisin notes.  Drinks much larger than its stated ABV.  Feels a bit thin in the mouth but there is a lot going on with the flavor - I like this beer.

Pours black with long-lasting brown head that dresses the glass with lacing. Piney hops in addition to a hint of espesso and roasted and chocolate malt. Light-medium in body and smooth. Lightly sweet with caramel malt, but finishes dry and roasted. A superb stout. Enjoyed every ounce.

Pours an oily black  opaque with a dark amber/cherry hue, and a thick cola head. Nose is piny with notes of cream and coffee. Taste starts slightly bitter, with very light roasted coffee malts and unsweetened cocoa. Finishes bitter and dry. Had a light and watery mouth feel.
On tap at brewpub. Black with tan head that retains well. Aroma is roastiness. Flavor is very dry--roasted coffee. Solid, but plain, stout.

Bomber. Pours dark with frothy tan head. Its three floyds so naturally the hops dominate the nose with hints of coffe and chocolate malt. Nice medium bodied mouthfeel easy going. Lots of grassy hops, nice roasted chocolate malt, a touch of fruitiness and a dry finish. The sweet maltiness pairs well with the hoppiness. In my amatuer opinion I think this works better than Alpha Klaus. Not huge in to hops this winter but this works for me.

Enjoyed at a good friends house prior to going to dinner before the busy holiday weekend.  It was either this or the Mikkeller imperial IPA, and Im glad we went with this.  Appearance pure black, rather bubbly with a coffee-like tan rich head.  Aroma grassy, pine cone hoppy with a bit of malt in there.  Taste of rich chocolate malt, plenty of hops, bit of lactose.  Really, this is a crazy hoppy stout.

On tap; pour is brown with a nice tan head. Nice retention, excellent lacing on this one. So initially you cant help but notice the alpha klaus similarities on the malt side on the nose. The hop profile is typical three Floyds but I dont really understand some peoples issues; it seems subdued to me. Cocoa, coffee, and caramel malts fuse with a subdued piney hop/ grapefruit character. Nice creamy feel from the head, nice roastiness from the malt side, subdued bitterness from the hops, and naturally a dry finish. Nice really
Average stout. There is nothing wrong with the aroma and taste, but they are both just too bland. This beer needs to go to the gym and work out.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown to black color with a medium sized tan head.  The aroma is dark chocolate malt with additional notes of roasted coffee and light smoke.  The floral and piney hoppiness were surprising.  The flavor is more dark chocolate with touches of black coffee, roasted malt and light vanilla.  There is good bitterness to the finish.  It is herbal and piney and lasts through the dry finish.  Medium plus bodied and smooth.  This is one of my favorite dry stouts, if it were more affordable to drink more often.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a 1" brown head.  Sweet malt aroma with a surprising amount of citrus hop. Medium bodied with low carbonation, perfect for the style. Clean, dry finish. Flavor is roasted malt, light coffee and cocoa nips. Bittering hops keep it from getting to sweet.

Bomber. Black with a small ring of bubbles and minimal lace. Sweet nose of oatmeal cookie dough and cocoa. Flavor is sour cream, tart berries, cocoa, orange, brown sugar, and a finish of resiny herbs, citrus and coffee that barely rescues this pne from a near-cloying sweetness. Medium body is smoothly carbonated, sticky-sweet, and lightly tingly with acidity. Tasty beer, and pretty good as a sweet stout, but really out of place as a "dry stout"

0.33 l bottle at Monks Porterhouse, Stockholm. Black color. Thick lemony hop aroma with coffee, chocolate and cola. Bitter and roasty flavor with charcoal, citrusy hops, coffee, chocolate and black currant. Sharp carbonation. A very hoppy stout, citrusy hops and heavy roastiness, not a great combination.

Deep black/brown with orange-tan head.  Aroma not particularly overwhelming.  Chocolate, toffee, a little more hoppiness than average, but not as strong as others have described.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, some sweetness, and finishes nutty and slightly dry.  Medium body is an accurate descriptor.  Fairly lackluster.
Bottle. Aroma has got notes of grapefruit hops, caramel and chocolate. The taste has got some vanilla and hop notes. Ends very dry.

Bottle at Monks Porterhouse.
Rather hoppy aroma.
Dry taste of berries and chcolate.
Thanks to StFun for the bottle. Nice black pour with a thin tan head. Chocolate, citrus hops and toffee aroma. Taste is smooth dry malt, with touches of chocolate and hop bitterness.Good stuff.
22 oz. bomber.  a little hoppier than i prefer my stoutr.  almost like a black ipa.  nonetheless it was very creamy and smooth.  very nice.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours black with light brown head. Roasted malt and chocolate aromas with a big dose of citrus hops. Roasted malts and citrus hops flavors with a hint of smokiness. Medium body with soft carbonation and a silky mouthfeel. A very intersting brew. Thanks Peter.

Pours is black with thick khaki head.  Aroma of toasted malt, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, liquorice, some spicey hop notes. Taste is similar, hop bite at the end.  Very smooth and creamy.  Solid stout from 3F.
Pours a black body with a lasting ring of tan head.  Aromas of brie rind and roasted grain.  Flavor is grainy with some coffee.  Rich for the abv.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2010 Bomber deployed a penguin tuxedo black elixir with a small tan head into my snifter.  The resident bloodhound sniffed out toasted, roasted, nutty malt aromas.  The taste is not normal.  Its a hoppy chewy beer with a wave of roasted malt flavors  and under currents of bitter chocolate, nuts, and biscotti.

22 oz. bottle from Party Town.  Pours a dark brown color with a minimal tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of roasted malts, orange peel, piney hops (or, a common FFF hop profile), dark chocolate, coffee, smoked hickory, and peat.  The same hop profile complements the roasty, coffee, and chocolate notes in the flavor well, along with more orange peel, peat, hickory smoked meat, and dark fruits- plums and dates.  Medium-bodied, with a chewy mouthfeel and dry finish.  Very mild carbonation, and very smooth.  Great dry stout.

Dark brown pour with just a little bit of tan head that leaves a respectable amount of lacing around the glass.   Very malty aroma - also picking up some slightly nutty scents along with roasted coffee.  Flavor is even more complex with some good carbonation bringing out the hoppy characteristics along with a bit of chocolate and molasses. Could a juuuuust a bit thicker IMO, but nevertheless it is a smooth sipper.

Will certainly be drinking this again - YUM!

Black pour, thick beige head.  Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, anise, charred roast.  Loads of char and ash on this one, pretty burnt overall, with more coffee, toffee, anise, a bit minty and herbal with the hops on the finish.  Overly charred for my taste, but not too bad.
Milky chocolate body, hazy muddy brown. gritty chocolate body, kind of ashy. dregged up.

Bottle thanks to Overml01. Pours dark black with small tan head. Nose is licorice and chocolate. Taste is one of the best licorice-centric stouts Ive ever had. Subtleties include chocolate, caramel, toffee and roasted malts.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy wonderfull aroma. Moderate bitter nice flavor. Average moderate bitter wonderfull finish. Creamy palate. Excellent.
66 cl bottle. Black with light brown head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and liquorice.
vanilla, chocolate, coffee, alcohol and cookie,black, light brown foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, nice beer.
Black. Has a brown head, moderate lasting. Dark aroma, roasted, coffee, laqurice, chocolate. Flavor is sweet, light bitter finish, but still real good. Creamy, light watery texture.
Bottle. Black colour with a small beige head. Rich aroma and taste of roasted malts, vanilla, coffee and chocolate. Truly an impressive brew.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are anis and licorice with decent amount of caramel, roast malt and coffee.

Pours a nice dark brown/black with slight tan head. Smells of sweet dark chocolate malt with a hint of hops (?) Smooth taste to boot.
Very tasty. Nice medium mouthfeel.

Nose is predominantly piny hops with some fresh navel orange and a slight roasted or chocolate malt quality.  The taste doesnt follow as closely at first, being more reminiscent of a more standard dry stout with the roast characteristic dominating, but as this beer warmed up the hops definitely came to the forefront.  Kinda reminds me of a black IPA without the overbearing bitterness some of those have had lately.  Probably a tastier beer than my score indicates, but not sure where Id give it a bump.
sample from crown-a black pour -lite brown head-aroma and taste of coffee, chocolate, roasty, - sweet creamy  expresso finish

Very strong aroma......jumps out after the pour.   Pours black with creamy 1 finger head.  Great lacing.   Got better and better as it warmed up.  served from bottle to Imperial pint glass.    Smooth finish and tastes of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Light carbonation.    Great offering from Three Floyds.
Bottle: pours dark black with a thin tan head, aroma of roasted malts and coffee, taste of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, a touch of bitterness, full bodied, excellent stout

opaque black, high co2.

aroma: roasted malt, chocolate, silage.

taste:
T1= chocolate, co2.
T2= roasted malt, slight char, co2 sour.
T3= dark must, slight astringency.

very carbonated. has a high/bright astringent note.

Pours nearly black with a 1-2 finger, creamy tan head that has good retention and leaves some specks of lacing. Aroma is big roast up front, burnt sugar, bittersweet chocolate, mild coffee, light woody notes, and some husky grain. Flavor is sweet roast, burnt sugar, carmelized tree fruit, coffee and slightly burnt, sweet granola. Palate is light to medium bodied, chewy on entry leading to a creamy middle and fairly dry finish with a pleasantly light carbonation. Really nice brew, everything just pulls together so nicely..
Pours black with tan head.  Aroma of mild chocolate and hops.  Has a distinct dry hop with chocolate, butter and caramel.  Not too thick on the palate and finishes dry.

Bottle, shared with tarheels86. Pours black with a decent brown head. Taste is light, very drinkable with a nice malty flavor. The finish is the worst part, with the chalky dryness. This is really great though goes way farther than Guinness extra stout.

22oz bomber courtesy of pittsburghkid. Pours pitch black with a thick brown head that has crazy retention and lace. Whoa- does not look like a dry stout. Aroma is weak but there is some citrus, mango, faint chocolate malt. Taste is light-bodied with some very nice kumquat, light mango, slight tartness. Very refreshing, easy to drink. Almost like a smoother, richer schwarzbier and thus awesome. Chalky, dry aftertaste is my only qualm- but it is a dry stout after all. Could put a few of these away rather quickly.
Thanks Masterski- Black pour. Black flavour. Once you go black, you never go back.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 In short: A very roasted and grassy hoppy stout.  Very harsh.  Good tasty beer.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed when about 6 months of age.  Sent to me by Shawn213, thanks a lot Shawn
The look: Near black body topped by a quickly diminishing medium beige head
In long: Nose is highly roasted.  Taste of char, coal, burnt molasses, a little smoky touch, a lot of hops, mint, milk-chocolate, a cup of black coffee.  Cacao in the comeback.  The beer is very dry and quite hoppy.  Finish is a bit abrasive with the high roastiness joining a harsh resinous grassy bitterness.  The beer is very tasty for a 5% stout (which is not a bad thing) but it came through as a bit rough.  All in all it is quite good and certainly not boring, just not very classy.  The Black Sun was not exactly what I was expecting but I wasnt disappointed.  Unlike a black son which I am really not expecting and disappointing would be an understatement.

Bomber poured a clear dark brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, citrus, pine and light earthiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of bitter chocolate, citrus, pine and earthiness with a smooth dry lingering roasty bitter finish.
Bottle (rating from notes in 2006).  A back color with a dark brown head.  A hoppy stout with a nice medium bodied malt backbone.
Pours dark brown/black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is malt, hops, and coffee.  Taste is malty upfront with a mildly bitter hop finish.  Very tasty.
Pours darkbrown with a beige head. Aroma is black malt, plum, raisin, chocolate and light apple. Flavour is roasted barley, plum, raisin, chocolate, coffee and liquorish.

( 22oz bomber) Pours espresso brown with little head that fades. Nose of candied ginger, pineapple, cocoa and pine. These smells dont see to go together. Taste of dry cocoa, piney/pineapple hops, and lacks sweetness. Nicely carbonated with a dry bitter finish.

22 oz. bomber poured black light to meduim in body and a thick tan head  the aromas were of roasted malts, coffee,hops and choclates tasteed of roasted chocolates malts and coffee with a perfectly presented hop balance just a great stout smooth  light and creamy with alow ABV

Almost black, some brown hues around the edges though. A nice 2 cm light-brown head dissipates a little too quickly.

Absolutely amazing smell. Very distinct hop character. Almost hard to believe that a dry stout can smell like this. Fresh hops, pine-needles and resins. The hops are mixed with a smooth roasted malt character, chocolate and a faint smoky note.

The taste is almost better than the smell. I havent had many stouts with such a fantastic and distinct hop character. Its fresh with plenty of resins and grass, and even some notes of grapefruit. Underneath the hops lies a smooth stout character. Sweet malts, dark bread and some chocolate. The stout flavors go really well with the hops, a true work of art, Id guess. A gentle tart note in the middle. The finish is rather bitter with some wood, hop resins and sweet malts.

Semi-full body, plenty or carbonation. Finishes somewhat dry.

This is one amazing beer, I really enjoyed it. Could have finished the bomber in no-time. Would feel privileged if I got to try it again.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

bottle thanks to thirdeye11.   deep brown almost black pour with an espresso head.  ginger, piney hops and roasted malts on the nose.  nice thickness with flavors of chocolate, roasted coffee and a light hop finish.
Pine hop bite. Caramel and coffee in a thin malt body. I dont know, but I found it kind of bland. Not a standout beer that I was expecting. Still a decent beer, and still a Three Floyds fan.
See what I mean about the stout?  its really really good.  Plenty of sweetness of caramel and bitter on coffee grounds.  well made beer.  would definitely try this again.

This poured a dark brown color with a light tan head. Aroma was silky chocolate, some roasted notes, dark fruits, and that distinctive 3F hop profile. Flavor was dark fruits, overrippened cherries and plums, followed by a good amount of cascades and centennials, followed by an extremely smooth lightly roasted finish. This is probably the most complex lower abv stout ive ever had. Once again 3F did not disappoint.
Wild, wild brew.  Poured very dark with a nice tan almost orange head.  Tasted real roasty with a hint of cherries.  Dope stout indeed.

Pint at FFF. Pours black with a foamy tan head that leaves ghostly lace.  Coffee and chocolate in the aroma accented by resinous hops. Taste is rich and chocolatey with a long coffee finish.  Very soft mouthfeel.
Tap at FFF. Opaque very dark pour. Brown head. Aroma of dry roast and chocolate, maybe a little molasses. Taste is semi creamy, bitter chocolate. Medium body.

Excellent stout.  This is a great, clean, dry stout with big flavors.  It pours a very dark brown, completely opaque with a small beige head.  Black Sun looks a bit like hot cocoa made with dark chocolate.  The aroma is rich and chocolatey with a hint of brown sugar.  The flavor is rather dry with some lingering sweetness and a bit of ash.  The mouthfeel is nice and creamy.  Its an excellent stout and easily the best dry stout that Ive tried.  Bottle was from lambtaco on Reddit.

Bottle courtesy Guy411. Pours an absurd milky brown with a thin cocoa-colored head. Aroma is reminiscent of chocolate milk with some roastiness and a lightly fruity note. Rich flavors of chocolate and iced coffee with lesser notes of cherries and fruity hops. Doesnt make any sense that it would be classified as a dry stout, but regardless of style this tastes really good. Medium-bodied with a tiny bit of chalkiness and a dry finish.

Poured from 22 oz., dark, murky brown with a slight reddish hue and minimal tan head. Nose was mostly chocolate a bit hoppy, mostly citrus, cherry.  Reminded me of a chocolate cherry cola.  Medium body with a slightly oily texture.  Nice finish but not exceptionally dry.  Better than the Moloko.

22oz bottle shared by Guy411.   Murky dark brown color with a small brown head.   Chocolate milk with grapefruit and orange hops in the aroma, with the malt showing lots of creamy chocolate.   The flavor is hoppy with some spice and grapefruit, a good dose of chocolate malt flavors and roasty bitterness.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   Interesting combo of hops and chocolate.   Far from a dry stout, but an interesting American stout.

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan coffee head.  Big roast y coffee aroma with some pine hoppiness.  Cream y and roast y despite the low abv.  A strong roasted finish that also has dark chocolate and caramel notes.  Great brew.

Black with a dense brown head that leaves amazing lazing behind. Aroma is green hops typical of Three Floyds here accompanied by fudgey caramell and light roasted malts. Flavour is extremely green hoppy and flavourfull for the ABV with a sturdy fudge/caramell foundation. Lightly roasted stout flavours coming through but its still all about the hops so its definitely a brew you want to drink fresh. Mouthfeel is smooth which adds to the drinkability, yum.

Pours dark brown with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is hoppy and chocolaty. Milk chocolate, caramel, pineapple, and  grapefruit stand out. As for the flavor, the bottle says it all; vanilla, cherry, coffee, chocolate, with some black licorice on the palate. Bitter citrus notes in the background, grapefruit and orange peel. This does not fit the description of a dry stout in my opinion. It tastes like dark lord light to me. Very good.

Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a rosted malty choclate aroma with some hoppy hints. Sweetish roasted malty chocolate flavor with some bitterness. Has a sweet roasted malty chocolate finish.

22 oz bottle. Pours super dark brown with a bubbly tan head that fizzes out to nothing rather quickly. Aroma is dark roasted grains, boozy vanilla and a light smoky wood scent. The flavor is very bitter coffee roast with some light sweet chocolate flavors. Medium to full body with a lively carbonation and a chalky dry finish. This is good but Im thinking this is an old bottle or possible slightly infected due to the short lived head, strange mouth feel and the somewhat acidic bite. Will definitely have to re-rate a fresh one sometime.
Poured very black, roasted malts dark chocolate, little coffee, slight nuttyness, dry finish.

A simple stout. Sugar, malt roastiness and water. I am guessing this sat a while, since the carbonation very shortly hissed out. Not much hop spice, but a nice sweet, chocolatey flavor. Pours black with just a little head, going away really quickly.  Has that trademark Three Floyds flavor - which is comforting. Finishes sweet though - so Im wondering if this is more of a sweet stout.

Dark black pour with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, fresh brewed coffee, rich flavorful smells. Roasted malt flavor, coffee, chocolate, oily, deliscious. Leaves a great aftrtaste in your mouth. Although this a step below Dark Lord, it is a step above many others. Brew on 3Fs.

Its been too long for this to make it my way and as my source for this, Eithcubes, says, this is a pretty outstanding beer. Incredibly drinkable stout. If there was a sessionable stout, this would be it. Roasty malt flavors dominate but the interesting part is a purple fruit sort of flavor working in the background. That was a nice surprise. A bit of sweetness and a full body give this one a significant mouth presence.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Bomber into a pint glass.  Pours deep black with a small brown head.  The aroma is fried smoked malts, dark fruits, dark chocolate, and coffee.  The flavor is stronger on the bitter coffee and finishes with sweet chocolate and a touch of sour.  Extremely high carbonation on this one.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted, coffee, fruit, hop. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, fruit, hop, citrus, orange. Easy drinkable nice beer, but i wish for more body.

Bomber poured into a tulip.  This better be a good one.  I have high expectations.  FFF BSS pours black with a minimal head.  It has a great clear aroma, being crisp, slightly fruity and wholly unexpected.  The body is more along the lines of a porter but it works none-the-less.  There is a slight cider feel to this beer due to the dryness.  The taste is slightly roasty with pine nuts, baked apples, and grapefruit acidity.  The finish is quick and clean.

22oz bottle shared with the kid. thanks again man. Very dark brown pour with a tan head that holds on well and it has lots of tiny carbo bubbles. Not especially thick and oily. Smokey and chocolate on the nose with a hint of caramel and roasted malts and some hops as well. Dry, medium-light body. Nice chocolate flavor with a slightly bitter finish. A decent stout.

[Bottle] Pours deep clear black with a large tan head. Aroma is dry cocoa powder and coffee. There is also a hint of noble hop in there as well. The flavor is very roast forward, nice and dry, and a bittersweet finish. Im not getting a ton of caramel in the beer, but no matter. Really a tasty, easy drinking brew.

22oz bottle pours a thick black/brown with a booming tan head which dissipates rather quickly . Complex taste is sweet full of malt with a chocolate caramel. The aroma does not give that Im a beer sent but is not bad.  A good tasting stout, nice finish on the palate. I would recommend for a desert beer
Dark black pour from bomber.  Chocolate, citrus and coffee taste.  Medium mouthfeel, with a nice bite to the finish.  Decent stout.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2010 Had this a couple weeks ago, it was very dry, poured black, Ill have to go back and get another so I can give it a proper rating.
Pours almost black with a big creamy light brown head with excellent lacing. The aroma fills the area, toasty, some hops, kinda grass in smell, some licorice. The taste is smooth, creamy some hop bitterness, some raisin a little vanilla. Very good.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours deep brown, bordering on black, fine medium, frothy, off-white head. Aroma has lovely roasted malts, dark chocolate, light blackberries. Grassy, light fruity hoppiness as well. Lowish carbonation, fine dry mouthfeel. Lovely, elegant, subdued flavour. Hard roasted, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, vanilla, a touch of smoke. Lovely grainy dryness with just a hint of good fruity hops. Nice.

22oz bomber, mail-ordered from Sams Wine and Spirits in Chicago.

Way the label is right: "Its not normal" - I completely agree!  Bordering on black as you pour, definitely black at the bottom of the bottle.  Faint ruby edges held up to the light, with a big bumpy tan head.  So far, its normal...then I took a whiff!  Who put hops in my stout?  There are a ton of hops in this beer, and they share the aroma spotlight with smoky malt and a bit of cocoa.  Flavor is also boldly hoppy up front, fading through light coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, vanilla, and more of that smoky malt.

Way the label is wrong: "very thick and full-bodied for the style" ... what?  Its a stout, and a somewhat thin one at that!  Dry finish with lingering smoke and hops.

22oz bottle.  Pours near black with a fizzy, light brown head.  A strong roasty aroma can be detected immediately along with cocoa, coffee and black licorice.  A smokey, roast flavor is dominant throughout with some hoppy and cocoa bitterness showing up in the finish. Dry texture with lively carbonation. Quite smooth and much lighter in body than I anticipated.
Dark pour thin beige head.  Floral and roast aroma.  Chocolate, citrus, and roast.  Medium bodied
Bottle thanx to my Buddy Tristan. dark dark black, with decent beige head. nose is inky and sweet.some hops but balanced. flavor is understated from what i was expecting. yummy beer

Bomber courtesy of shawnm213.  Pours dark brown with a lasting tan head.  Smells of sage, roasted malt, resin, peppery, boozy.  Tastes of resin, citrus, chocolate, pepper, cherries, earthy.  Very enjoyable!

Bottle, 22oz. A surprising aroma on this one, sure, its roasted, but orangey, citrusy hops more or less dominates it, probably too much. But nice. The flavor is also very orangey, adding a fine bitterness towards the end. Both aroma and flavor also have a tiny touch of wet cardboard, but nothing I would have noticed if I was just drinking and not rating. Its next to black in the glass, and topped by a small, good-looking tan head. I might think its too much on the orangey side, leaving the roasted, chocolate, coffee flavors and aromas in the background, but I really enjoyed it anyway. 090724

650 ml bottle.Pours black with a small beige head.Hoppy pine aroma with roasted grains, almost bread.Roasted grains and caramel with an almost minty hop flavor.Dry and bitter finish.Nice and hoppy stout.

22oz Bomber  Trade  StFun
Aroma: Big dark malt and roasty aroma.  Lingering hops this was awesome.    
Appearance: Dark Brown in color, clear with a light head.  
Flavor: Big dark malt with a roasty flavor.  The Chocolate and coffee came out awesome. This was a thick beer.  
Palate: Dry Stout Finish, with a Great Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Big beer flavors and the aroma was awesome.  Big flavors this was not for the non beer drinker.
pretty good stuff.. dark black, what a surprise .. . great level of roast .. mild mouth .. . light sweetness .. . some sediment .. . who goes antiquing? .. must be a demon on tap!

22 oz bottle acquired via trade. Poured a deep black that lightened up a bit towards the end of the pour. Aroma was hefty roasted chocolate with some oatmeal, coffee, a bit of dark fruit and a surprisingly high earthy hop note. Flavor of roasted chocolate, oats, earthy hops, dark fruit and toffee. Very tasty beer, another highly enjoyable one from Three Floyds. Smooth as shit mouthfeel as well.

Sample from September 11, 2009 Beer Club Meeting.  Muddy black/brown color.  Definitely bottle conditioned.  Smells like hops and smoke and... trees?  Flavor hoppy, but wild.  Best not to overdo the hops on this stout.  Definitely smoked or roasted malt here.  Thin, almost like it has a high alcohol content.  Basically an IPA with roasted or crystal malts.  Interesting.  Good!
Dark black beer with a tan head that leaves some very nice lacing.  Grassy hop and yeast aroma.  Creme Flavored coffee with ops throughout.  Carbonated with a yeasty finish to it.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque except for the slightest mahogany edge on the bottom of the glass when held to a light source. Frothy 2 finger beige head with excellent retention that very slowly fades into a lasting .5 finger cap that leaves chunky rings of lacing on my pint glass.

Very roasty chocolate malt aroma with hints of chocolate, oatmeal, coffee bean, burnt toast, toffee, vanilla, subtle dark fruit notes and a nice hop profile.

Chewy creamy full body with a very roasty bitter mouthfeel. Pretty hoppy up front adding a nice bitterness to the deep roasted coffee bean and burnt toast notes. Sweet chocolate maltiness with subtle dark fruit notes, vanilla, oatmeal, lactic creaminess, toffee and hazelnut. The bitterness from the hops and rosted notes is very prominent throughout, lasting through to a very dry finish. This beer is very complex but is still pretty quaffable with not a lot of alcohol heat.
Bottle. Mild coffee aroma. Dark brown colour. Very small light brown head. The flavour is slightly dry, but has some coffee, sweet liquorice. Hint of spice of some sort, probably from the hops.

22 oz. bottle from Delocks Liquors in Munster, IN.  Black pour with a tan head.  Aroma of some dark roasted malt, smoke, and just a hint of raisin or some dark fruit.  Very smoky roasted malt flavor as well as bitter chocolate.  Well carbonated for a stout but not unpleasantly so.  Very big flavor for such a low ABV beer.  I am quite impressed with this offering.

22 ounce bottle from my Secret Santa. Thanks! Pours a pitch black color with a large head. Average head retention and good lacing. Aroma is dark roasted malts and coffee with a fairly strong leafy hoppiness. Taste is roasted malts, coffee, light smoke and a hoppy finish. Fairly strong carbonation, very smooth and creamy with a medium body.
