Bottle. Pitch black with a steady beige head. Aroma is very complex. Lots of fruit, hops, yeast, chocolate and coffee. Flavour is fruity hops, prune, coffee and tobacco. Lovely complex stout. Lots of things going on but it is still very mild and easy to drink.

Bottle @ Odense Smagning, August 2009. Pours pitch black with a creamy brown head and lacings. Nose is roasted coffee, chocolate and piney hops. Very smooth and in a way mild - but it has explositions of flavor. Ashy, oily, slick and vinous. Very nice.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a thick chocolate brown head. Roasted and solid hoppy pinewood and citric aroma. Roasted, dark chocolate and hoppy flavoured. Interesting combo. Bitter and citric flavoured finish alongside and nice roasted acidic lingering finish.

Bottle shared by Hophead22 by way of shawn213. Thanks guys.. Pours black with a light brown head..Aroma wa roasty with a slight metallic sent.. Flavor was roasty with some smokiness and some dark fruits, slightly vinous... Medium carbonation.. Tasty.

#506 for this beer, 22oz bottle from shawnm213, thanks man. Virtually pitch black, but it did have a light glow when held up to the light, head was short lived, but it was a nice creamy tan head when it was present. Light, roasty aroma, very clean, somewhat tin like as well. More light roast, smooth, a little dry, very enjoyable. Lot of smokiness. (975)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bomber.  Very good dry stout.  Best dry stout that I have had.  Pours dark with little head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malts.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Pours a dark, inkyblack with a thin tan head.  Aroma is very hoppy for a stout.  Coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts are heavy in the aroma as well.  Notes of toasted malts, caramel, toffee, and cherry come out.  On the palet it isrich and creamy.  Bold chocolate flavors jump out.  I also detect a subtle cherry taste.  The finish brought out the hops character.  I  really enjoyed this one.

22 oz bottle

Having received this in a trade earlier in the year I was eager to finally give it a try.  Id passed it on the shelves so many times that Three Floyds pulled out of both Wisconsin and Ohio.  If Id known what I was missing I would have grabbed at least a single bottle to try along with Gumbalhead.  This is a decent stout in the style of Guinness but given the choice I would buy local (Midwestern).  Theres a reason it is near the top of its category.

Aroma / Appearance - The fading head actually consumes some of the liquid as it cascades downwards.  Transparent at the edges the body becomes dark and mysterious by the bottom.  A little hoppy it nonetheless has the stout aspects I expected to find including coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts.  The hoppy aspect reminds me of ivy which has just been trimmed off a tree where it was not wanted.

Flavor / Palate - The fluid mixture that clears the palate includes fresh chocolate, ash, coffee, and woody mulch.  Finishing with a dry smoky aspect it sits deftly between the tongue and throat.  Very mellow and sessionable I would recommend this to anyone looking to get their feet wet with what a stout should be.

2009 Bottle - Thanks shawnm213! - Pours almost black with a medium tan head...aroma is cocoa and coffee, dry malt and toasted grain...flavour is similar, no where near as dry as I expected, creamy malt, roast, very light charred wood bitters...this is what I look for in a stout...

Poured in the sediment from the bottom and this shit got undrinkable...dont do what eric dont does...

Bottle. Poured black with a brown head. Aroma was sweet with malt notes and undertones of chocolate and caramel. Flavor was soft and cream on the tongue notes of caramel, sweet malts, coffee and chocolate.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2009 This one took me completely by surprise.  I really wasnt expecting too much for some reason.  The hops really stand out in the aroma.  The strong dry, roasted malt, hoppy aroma is excellent. I now knew immediately that I was going to love this beer.  Hell yeah, the flavor is great.  Packed with dry roasted malts, hops, chocolate and coffee.  You really cant ask for much more when it comes to the balance of flavors here. Best dry stout hands down.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - brown head. Burned, dry roasted, milkey, lactic coffee, nice hoppy, piney, grass, light sweetness. Pleasant.

22 oz. bomber. Poured into a pint glass. Appearance: Black pour with a beige head. Aroma: Roasted malts and coffee. Flavor: Dark coffee and some hops. Medium body with plenty of carbonation. Really good stout.
A pretty tasty stout, I had this on-tap at the brewpub.  Even better was the ice-cream float with this as the liquid!

Poured into snifter.  Dark brown/black pour with a hint of ruby on the sides once you get through halfway.  Thick dark coffee colored head, aroma was off dark roasted coffee and piney hops, same with the flavor.  Seriously yummy and worth nice long sips.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2009 bomber (thanks to Pipper) into snifter. Near black with khaki head that fades to a ring and leaves no lace. Aroma and flavor dominated by molasses, both with a nice hop character to balance. Medium bodied with a bit of a watery character.  Over carbonated IMO. Overall: very solid.
Pours black with a two fingered beige head and a big roasted malt hoppy aroma. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee,light smoke and hops.
Black with a medium beige head. Aroma had plenty of roasted malt and coffee with accents of chocolate. Flavour had chocolate, roasted malt, and hoppy notes. Finished sweet.

Bottle via trade.  Black color with a nice brown head.  Aroma of roast, coffee, and slight dark fruits.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, mild hops, chocolate, and cherry.  Medium body with a smooth palate.  Watch out for the sediment at the bottom!  Gets a bit chalky at end-bottle, but its great up until that point.

Pours pitch black, thin body, decent head that sticks around for a while. Aroma of roasted malts. Flavor is coffee, heavy on dark malts, bitterness seems to come from the malt and not so much the hops, but thats just me. Palate is sort of dry, but not as much as you would think for a dry stout. Pretty good stuff, with a nice flavor and fairly clean palate thats easy to drink.

bottle from ølbutikken.
black, large thick brown head.
aroma is sweet, faint fruity, roasted grains, faint alc. syrup, coffee. very slight sour/hoppy note a bit disturbing.
flavor is strong roasted grans, slightly flowery sour, wood.
overall very nice, quite roasted and mild, more like a porter than a stout.

Botella, thanks a bunch for sharing Pinball. Pitch black colour, nice brownish head, ok lacing. Roasty malty chocolate bitter hoppy aroma. Very good mouthfeel. The flavour is dry with roasted malt, some smoke, powder chocolate, bitter hops and a chocolate roasty malty dry bitter finish.

Much,much better just barely chilled. Black,brown hues.  Thick,tight beaded head,with big,creamy,froth. Loose carbonation. Aroma a little hoppy,very roasty,with some caramel,chocolate.  Substantial mouth feel. Little thicker than expected,though still light. Initial flavors of hops and roasted bitterness. Late hop,heavily roasted,and chocolate. Finish is lightly hoppy,light chocolate,and big on the roast.Very roasty,dry all around,with some good hop burps. Easy drinking stout
Pours black with thin white head. Nose is surprisingly hoppy. Lots of citrus and floral hops, roast malt and sweet malt. Flavor is much the same as the nose with some cocoa. Dry finish.

22oz bottle.  Pours deep brown/ black with a thick and creamy tan head that left some spotty lacing.  Nose starts with fresh spruce and pine, followed by toasted malts, coffee, chocolate and toffee.  Flavor was mostly toffee, roasted malts, some dark fruits and chocolate. Fairly dry on the finish, medium in body, great stuff!

Pours jet black with a small tan/yellow head.
Nose is full of chocolate with some hoppy citrus
Taste is roasty with lots of sweeter malts, bigger than a normal dry stout, lighter than an RIS, Body is very light with nice light coffee notes and a little bit of tart citrus to balance out the sweeter and roastier flavors.

22oz bottle @Tampa Wkly Gathering-pours a dissipating to ring off white head with some lacing and dark brown color.  Aroma is sweet citrus/northwest hops, some dark malt.  Taste is sweet citrus/northwest hops with some bite, some drk malt.  Good carbonation.  Medium body.  Thanks HOPSHUNTER.

Bottle.  Thanks to cexshun for the trade.  Pitch black beer stains the glass, looks very promising.  Lots of hops in the nose reminds me of a black IPA.  Lots of roasted/burnt malts up front, some chocolate and anise, and more hops.  Finishes roasty.  Excellent brew.

22 oz Bomber. Pours a black color with a medium creamy tan head. Nose of roasted malt, caramel, earthiness and coffee. Initial taste of mild chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and hint of pine. Mid palate displays some creaminess blending in the flavors quite nicely. Finishing with a good resin hop balance. Light bodied and good head retention. Very enjoyable.

Had to move rating from Bourbon version to regular version.  This is the one I had.  Black pour, nice frothy tan head.  Aroma is quite unique.  Roast, coffee, and resinous hops...flavor is very nice.  Coffee, hops, some chocolate and roast.

Bottled. Pours black with a medium sized creamy, beige head. Good lacings. Nose of roasted malt and black coffee and pine. Flavour with coffee, dark chocolate and hops. Medium bodied. It has a lightly bitter finish with pine and grape in it. Well balanced. An excellent brew.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting off-white head with long lacings. Very dark red, without a lamp I would have said black. body. Powerful hard roasted barley malt aroma with notes of coffee and earth. High carbonated dry and hoppy roasted barley malt flavor with distinct coffee notes and a long dry and bitter aftertaste. Impressive body for a beer with such a low alcohol percentage.
22 oz bomber poured in a clear pint glass.  Aroma is light coffee and a bit of hops.  It is more of a dry stout that isnt overly sweet.  A pretty good dark beer that could be drank anytime.

Pours very nice black with tan head.  I get dry tannic tea, and roasted malt in the aroma.  The flavor is like the smell  - roasted barley mixed with black tea thats been steeped too long.  The mouthfeel is somewhat thin and very drying - cottonball in the mouth feel.  Overall, this is probably my least favorite FFF beer to date and I sadly didnt even finish the bottle.

Poured from bomber...black in color with a thin tan head.  Aroma has a dry feel to it with burnt malts and has a strong coffee feel to it.  Flavor is lots of sweet, heavily (burnt) malt, a hint of dark fruit, and old coffee, and some chocolate notes.  Palate is very dry, and somewhat harsh...a bitter ending to it as well.  Something about this one makes me say blah...maybe Ive just grown to expect a bit more from FFF.

one of my favorite stouts. pours black and thin with little tan head that disappears fast. aroma is burned malts and rich coffee. taste is bitter coffee up front and finishes a little sweeter thanks to the malts. great stout any time

Pour is almost black with red visible during the pour only.  A tan head is minimal ending is a blotchy cover on the glass.   Aroma is roasted malt with dark fruit.  Flavor is first chocolate, then dark fruit, then sour hops, then anise.  A very nice stout that is almost a session beer.

22 oz bottle likely picked up from Binnys (Orland Park, IL). A couples months back, but refridgerated for the duration. Pours a pretty much opaque black pour with decent tannish head that bubbles a bit and begins to subside a bit, laces well. Aromas are a nice dry stout feel, preaching some roasted malts, piney hop bouquet, a touch of soda bread, and chocolate that sweetens to balance. Very nice. Initial is a decent yet sessionable body, pushing chocolate, light coffee, caramel, and some roast, a creaminess comes in with the chocolate and caramel that keeps the roast in check. Pine makes an appearance towards the back of the body and finish, providing a nice change of pace from typical coffee bittering. The pine leaves its mark on the aftertaste with a touch of floral and citrus, mixing liberally with chocolate and cream, roasted malts, light coffee to make a wonderful balance and amazingly sessionable brew.
on tap at three floyds.  went great with my burger.  The best dry stout ive had.

Black in colour with a quickly dissipating tan head, light lacing.  The aroma is quite sweet, is very roasty, lots of oatmeal and quite malty.  The flavour has incredible amounts of oatmeal, rather sweet, creamy with lots of roast, light alcohol and chocolate malts.  Roasty mouthfeel, medium/large body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, creamy and roasty.
This is very filling considering the amount of oatmeal that I got out of this, roasty and chocolaty.  At times this got a bit harsh.
650ml bottle from Sahara Mart in Bloomington, Indiana.
Opened on October 27, 2008.
No date.

22 oz. bottle.  Dark black pour with a thick, light brown head.  Aroma of piney hops, dark chocolate, and licorice.  Flavor is of roasted malts, some smoky oak, and licorice.  Finish is bitter and dry.

Pours black with a nice creamy and frothy tan head. Aroma is pretty biting and forward, lots of coffee and a rich nuttiness. Chocolate and some hints of dark fruit are apparent. Reminds me a lot of a baltic porter. Flavor starts with the standard coffee and licorice sweetness. Caramel and more bitter coffee comes forth with a nice sort of subdued dark fruits that stay in the background. Very dry in the aftertaste and coffee like bitterness. Medium, nearly medium to full body. Nice stout, pretty bitter and biting, but still pleasant.

Pours a very black body with a small tan head. Aroma is medium sweet with grapefruit, some chocolate, light peach. The flavor is bittersweet chocolate, roast, woody and light citrus. The finish is dry grapefruit and a bit minerally. Light to medium body. Interesting hop choice for the aroma although I must say it worked for me.

Black pour with little head and a small tan ring.  Nice deep roast aroma with strong chocolate notes and lots of toasted, piny, hops.  Theres also some hints of molasses, brown sugar, brandy, damp wood, smoke, and a faint vinous quality.  Very toasty and chocolaty flavor with some molasses and brown sugar and lots of fresh, piny hops.  Creamy, full body with a moderate amount of carbonation.
Thanks to theisti for this beer. Super dark pour. Roasty malts, chocolate, coffee and licorice. Flavor is the same with some dark fruits, spice and smoke. Great beer.

3/10/2009:  My general impression of Three Floyds beers are that they are good, but over-priced (at least the bottle is FULL).  However, that having been said, I now see why I still buy a bottle of their beer every now and then.  They are rich and full of flavor.  They also dont hold back on those glorious, flavorful hops!  Black Sun Stout is no exception.  Its aroma is super hoppy; lots of FRESH pine and floral hops.  Underneath that green, fresh, lively hoppiness is a rich, chocoate maltiness.  The flavor is very similar.  The super fresh and substaintial hop flavor gives way to a moderately bitter-sweet roasted maltiness with significat hints of chocolate and coffee.  Delicate threads of citrusy orange hops and candy-like flavors can also be found in the mid-palate.  The finish is just a touch dry and the roasted coffee with some char flavor draws me back in for drink after drink.  All of this beer flavor and aroma goodness is presented in a nearly black, smooth, medium-full bodied liquid that has a frothy beige to tan-colored head.  This is a really nicely done stout.  Maybe my real problem with 3F is that the beer just disappears too quickly since its quite good leaving me $10+ lighter in the wallet much faster than I would have liked to be!
1 pint 6 fl oz bottle from West Side Liquor and Wine Shop in West Harrison, Ohio ($8.99+tax).  Rating #465 for this beer.

Courtesy of Sammy. It is pitch black with a huge, brown and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and licorice. The flavour has a light sweetness and a light roasted bitterness. It has notes of coffee, licorice, chocolate, light smoke, citrus and berries. The long finish has a light roasted bitterness and hints of berries. The flavour is rather intense even if the ABV is relatively low, nice indeed.

Thanks retorp for the share.  Pours dark browm with an off-white head.  Nose is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice, dark malt, and roastiness.  Flavor is slightly oaky with chocolate, smooth dark malt, and noticeable hops.  Medium to thick mouthfeel with roasted malt throughout and a complex blend of sweet and dry.

22oz bottle. Pours a jet black body with a fizzy, dark brown, quickly dissipating head that leaves an oily and runny lace. Aroma is very hoppy for the style, which is surprising except for the fact that this is a FFF beer, which doesnt surprise me one bit. Lots of the typical floral hops from FFF as well as a juicy citrus. Moderate amount of roasted dry coffee grounds, some ripe cherries, and a woody backing. Lots of sweet caramels and bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is very similar and right on track with the aroma. Roasted coffee and floral hops dominate from beginning to end. Quite sweet up front with the mellow dark chocolate and vast amount of caramel malts. Finishes very dry and woody with a touch of citrus. Lingers for quite a long time. Palate is light and smooth with a small amount of finishing carbonation. Very clean for such a complex dry stout. Overall, really solid dry stout. I remember having this on tap at DLD 08 and loving it. Glad to have finally found a bottle to rate.

Bottle courtesy of quake1028. Pours a murky pitch black color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet and roasted with notes of vanilla, oak, brown sugar, ripe dark fruit, chocolate, some hints of spice. Flavor is roasted and sweet with notes of chocolate, ripe dark fruit, molasses, caramel, some hints of honey and faint spice. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing roasted malt finish.

bomber. this coal black colored brew fills my tulip and forms a lovely crema cap roughly a half inch high. aromas of citrus hops roasted barley and dark chocolate are prominent. much more hop aroma than expected for this style, and its those juicy citric hops too. if youve had the chance to try these guys beers than you would agree this is common amongst many 3 floyds beers. bod y is light and and very smooth. hops are upfront and not tremendously bitter but add a nice touch. those flavors transition to roasted barley and chocolate bars.pretty straight forward. a solid brew though not particularly complex which is unusual for these guys.

Bomber shared with soccer290. As always, I was extremely excited to have a different brew from FFF. This beer poured a dark black color with mahogany tints around the edges and was accompanied by a one finger width tan head. The aroma really got me excited... there was a lot of dark dried fruit accents with a lot of roasted malts and some bitter chocolate. The taste was good but was very typical for a stout. There was bitter chocolate hints with some coffee, dried fruits, and nutty malts. This stout had a fairly light mouthfeel which was disappointing in my opinion. Finished bitter with some metallic hints. Overall a good stout but nothing to get too excited about.

22 oz bottle shared with General66. Pours a light black color that was not completely opaque. Smells of malt and dried fruit (I think it was mango). Tastes of coffee, bitter chocolate, and roasted nut. Very smooth going down, and left a taste of coffee in an aftertaste. Made me woner where the dried fruit smell went. Overall, a decent stout, first dry stout I have had, expected more from three floyds though

22 oz. bottle - Poured dark brown with tan head.
Aroma - toasted chocolate malt, hops and coffee.
Flavor - Mostly roasted chocolate malt along with earthy taste. Leafy hop taste on tongue.
Palate - medium bodied with average carbonation. Finish is dry and aftertaste lingers. SOAPY aftertaste
Overall - Fairly decent Stout but not that great. $8.49 for 22oz. is high for low ABV. and average taste.

Bottle, courtesy someone. Black pour, big dark tan head and thick lacing. Nose has some sweet fruity coffee, some chocolate and roasted malts. Big on roast in the flavor, coffee, chocolate, and a very nice spicy dry finish. Crisp. Quite drinkable. Full-bodied for a small beer. Enjoyed it considerably.

22 oz.  Jet black pour with a dark tan head, disappated pretty quickly.  Roast malt and coffee with that signature piney hops.  Tastes real nice with coffee, peat, hint of dark chocolate.  The 3F piney hops work really well with the dry stout style.  Semi-lively for a stout.  Solid medium/full body.  Finish real clean and hop dry.  I find the 3F hop profile interferes with some of the styles, but it works perfectly with the dry irish stout.  This is unique and a must try for anyone who likes this style.  Extreamly drinkable to boot.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Awesome looking pour pitch black with frothy root beer head. Lots of bitterness and grass in the nose and carries into the flavor profile. Definitely interesting for a stout. Decent.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 Bomber at Jerrys. Black with good, creamy brown head / Toasty, grassy chocolate nose / Medium body, chewy, with good balance and decent finish / Flavors of roast barley, grass, straw, raisins, and roast coffee / A solid stout, with the grassiness as an interesting change from the chocolate-vanilla stout profile.

Bottle pours black with a medium tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, currant, and hops. Taste is not overly sweet, profile mostly consists of roasted malts, strong bitterness, and some hints of raisins and nuts. Fairly thick mouth feel with a dry finish.

Pours out pitch black with nice rootbeer head. Taste is sweet and malty but bitter for a stout. Nice dry finish. Some roasty flavors and maybe a little coffee & chocolate. However mostly hops. Great beer.

Bomber from Archer Liquors. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and citrus hops. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate and caramel. Nice hoppy dry stout that finishes dry but is smooth on the palate. Very good dry stout.

Bottle receive from my brother in law as a birthday gift (Thanks Neil!!)  Pour was a rich dark black with a little carbonation.  Aroma was a little malty and smoky.  Flavor was intially bitter chocolate, roasted malt and then finished with some coffee.  Once again, another nice FFF brew.
Pours a dark black with a chestnut head. The nose is fruity, hoppy, chocolate, coffee, roasty. Flaovr is grainy, some coffee, chocolate bitterness, waxy bitterness. Palate is dry and bitter.

Black pour with tan head and lace. Aroma of chocolate and hints of coffee. Flavor mirrors the aroma. Nice full bodied with good carbonation. I expected more hops on the nose and in the beer, but it had been in the frige for over a year. Still pretty damn nice.
bottle, walnut colored pour, nice crema  head, aroma has a vinous raisin quality to it, flavor is a bit on the light side, some coffee bitterness, burnt toast, good finish

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 This is amazing. Black pour,light tan head. Big three floyds hops aroma. Flavor is hoppy, lots of citrus chocoaltey, and amazing 3F hops. the hops in this stout are the standout. Nice mouthfeel. Overall,  Great, bitter, stout.

22 oz bottle.  After an initial whiff i find it hard to believe that this actually a stout since there is such a significant hop profile in the aroma, which definitely peaks my interest immediately, so i have to give some extra points for that alone.  Notes of highly floral hops, sweet fruits, and good amount of dry roasted coffee malts.  This is a very attractive stout as well, with a small layer of cappuccino cream head, and medium looking 
dark mahogany color.  A very appealing looking and smelling beer.  The taste fits nicely into how i  expected it based on the smell.  Lots of roasted malts, including coffee, nuts, and minor sweet caramel, come through from the start and stay strong through out.  Of course what makes this one a very unique and highly enjoyable beer is the 3fs floral hop bitterness that completely add to the experience of a traditionally malty alcoholic beverage. Smooth all the way, and a dry finish.  A great experience.

Black hole sun, wont you come, and wash away the rain.  Dark brown with a medium brown head.  Aroma of Three Floyds hops (Amarillo?) and roasted malt.  Taste of those FFF hops again, floral hops, roasted malt and chocolate.  Smooth body and more generously hopped than most stouts, but I like this one.

220z bottle. Pours black with a foamy, tan head. Aroma is of hops, caramel, chocolate, nuts, and coffee. Taste is of earthy hops, chocolate, nuts, coffee, vanilla, and sugar. Has an underyling backbone of light toasted malt. Lingering hop taste. Light, creamy mouthfeel. Needs more booze in the body. Drinkable, but the flavors are slightly muted.

Bottle sampled at the Hopsnobbery Collective stout tasting on 1.16.09.  Thanks Bill for this one.  Pours a very dark black pour with a tan, caramel head full of small bubbles.  Aggressively hopped, with a very strong chocolate malt backbone.  Finishes dry with those aggressively spicy hops kicking in.  Weird for a "dry stout", but all in all pretty good.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle sampled at the Hopsnobbery Collective stout tasting on 1.16.09.  Black color, as the name would suggest, with a medium tan head.  Sweet aroma with a bit of hop that seems a bit off.  Dry coffee flavor with some alcohol and a malty finish.  Not bad, but I expected it to be better.

Sampled at the Hopsnobbery Collective Stout tasting on 01/16/09. Pours black with a medium thin and foamy tan head that burns away to an outer ring. Spotty lacing on the glass. Earthy malt and astringent hops in the nose. Medium, dry body with flavors of dark malt and fruits, cocoa and bitter hops. The finish is earthy and malty with a lingering bitter hops aftertaste. Overall this beer shows promise but the ever-present astringency in the bottle I tried undermined it. I will have to try it again.

Pitch black coloured body with a super dense deep brown head that fades and leaves the perfect top on a beer. Aroma of - you guessed it - HOPS!! Very little else in the aroma-some malt and burnt sugars, but really the only thing very noticeable are the hops. Medium to Full-bodied; Nice hoppy taste up front - high a.a. but lingering behind are all the other tastes, the roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and light nuttiness. Aftertaste shows a lot of hops still and some sweet sugars. Overall, a nice beer - if you had your eyes closed while enjoying this one, youd be hard pressed to pick a style of beer. Obviously, this stratles the line and is definitely worth trying either for an IPA or a stout! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 15 July 2006 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Got the same old Three Floyds hops aroma... and its delicious.  Very thin bodied yet bursting with flavor.  Pretty sexy.  Got Honkeybra to thank for this, so I do.

Pours a dark brown color with thick off white head.  Aroma is of intensely herbaceous, with notes of floral hops and pine, as well as roasted malt.  Taste is piney, spicey, with bits of chocolate and roasted malt.  Finish is mildly carbonated with a full body and slightly creamy.  This would have scored higher if not for the funky nose and taste.

Pours black with a medium creamy mocha head that fades thinly, leaving  very little lacing.  Aroma is dark roasts, coffee, piney hops, and some notes  of alcohol it seems.  Taste is creamy with the dry finish - dark roasts and the piney hops are equally balanced an encompass the majority of the flavor.  Even though it is rather hoppy, it is not very bitter and still keeps the brew creamy.  Enjoyable.

nice!!!!!Pours black with a small brown head. Roasted malt aroma with some caramel and chocolate. Some candy sugar too. Sweet caramel sweetness shifting to a very dry roasted malt, coffee nut bitterness with a great coffee finish. Light dry body.I love this!!1
Black pour, rich herbal aroma.  Flavor of coffee, grains, and malt.  A malty and enjoyable stout.
Wow.  Another wait over. Does not pour as thick as I would expected. But very tasty. Nice overall chocolate to it. Wonderful.

Had a bomber and on tap at the brewery.  Chocolate and coffee, but not overwhelming.  Some alcohol taste and maybe some vanilla.  Neither sweet or overly bitter.  Pours dark brown with a light brown head that lingers a little.  Very drinkable.  Recommended.

Bottle courtesy of StFun poured into a snifter.

This one was crazy carbonated out of the bottle with a huge light brown head that overflowed the glass. It pours black with no light penetrating. There is at least one inch of head throughout and great lacing.

The aroma is very interesting for a dry stout and has a pronounced citrus hop kick up front before the roasted malts take over. There is a little bit of coffee bitterness in the nose as well.

The taste has the same citrus hops up front but has a more roasted coffee flavor than the aroma would suggest. There is the dark malt backbone before the hops come back in the finish which is nice and dry, about the only thing that is strictly within style.

The mouthfeel is very creamy with tons and tons of carbonation. There is a slightly dry and hoppy finish.

This is one unique take on a dry stout and very, very good. It’s also extremely drinkable for a stout - a great session brew.
Dark dark brown with dark brown head.  Coffee and bitter cocoa flavor.  Spicy finish.  Highly carbonated.

22 oz. Bomber. I picked this bottle up in 2006 and have been sitting on it for a couple years.  Pours out a slick oily black with a minimal tan head.  Aroma is complex and earthy with hints of chocolate, dried fruits, dry roasted malt and wet wood.  Flavor is slightly sweet, but not excessive and is well balanced by a strong hop backbone. Mouthfeel is solid without being syrupy and has a subtle persistent carbonation.  Finish is dry and slightly ashy.  Overall an outstanding low alcohol stout that I wish I could find more often.

Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pour a rich thick black with a small tan head. Caramel and malt on the nose. Good malt flavors at first, give way to caramel and good coffee flavors. A nice bitter finish. Real good beer.

Bomber courtesy of StFun.  Pours a dark brown with a 2 finger beige head.  Spotty, delicate lacing.  Nose is dark fruit, light chocolate and coffee and yeasty bread.  Taste is more dark fruits upfront, with some smoked malts, cocoa and roasty coffee in the finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Interesting stout.  Thanks Josh!

From a 22oz Bottle.  Dark brown, cocoa hued pour with a thick layer of fine bubbled tan foam.    Aromas of coffee, cocoa, and piney hops.  This particular bottle has a little age on it, which actually seems to have made the roast and hop characters come into balance much better; additionally, there doesnt seem to be any major oxidation effects.  Hints of prune and molasses.  Medium light bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel with a dry, roasty finish.  Light bodied and easy drinking for a stout, but plenty of flavor.  Roasty coffee and cocoa flavors with a touch of piney hops and hints of licorice.  Clean and toasty, without any excessive malt sugars to cloud up the palate.
Wonderful stout!  Aroma is that of roasted coffee with a hint of fruit and hops.  Great balance of flavor! Overall has to be my favorite brew from 3Floyds.

Murky dark brown hue with a nice thick layer of tan foamy head that mostly sustains. Aroma is a balance of grassy, pine resin hops and chocolate/coffee malts and roast, light booze and sweetness. Taste is smooth cocoa and light coffee malts, quick transition to pine resin and floral tones, the finish is dry and brief in flavor but a mild alcohol warming lingers. Moderate carbonation and watery-creamy texture. A nice refreshing and easy-drinking stout with low abv and modest hop presence.

bomber by way of StFun... pours really dark brown at the edges but the body is opaque black. its topped by a soapy reddish brown head with lots of pillowy carbonated lacing. the aroma is really hoppy... grassy, piny, some citrus  and floral hops mix in with chocolate, slightly scalded cream, charred wood, mild sourness and coffee. intense roasty flavor pairs with cream, wood, citrus pith, fruit and fruity sourness, grass, pine, chocolate and a dry finish leading to an aspirin burn in the back of the throat. ashy aftertaste comes with a bunch of coffee. medium to full body. soft airy carbonation, acidity and astringency trick you to believe its  a whole lot lighter... insanely drinkable...
Perfect head, thick with tiny bubbles forming slowly. Smooth, espresso-scented, hella hoppy for a stout, with a bit of sweetness in the finish. Thick mouthfeel. Yes, this is great.

22 oz. bottle - thanks to SQNfan for the trade; jet black and oily texture; frothy chocolate-colored head settles quickly; lots of coffee on the nose and some sweetness too; roasty and mild fruit flavors present; flavors are slightly on the mild side with touch of bitterness; dry finish and very nice overall with a good combo of sweetness and bitterness from the chocolate and coffee

Poured deep black color with a brown head that left excellant lacing. Smell is incredible, piney hops come right through, paired with some roastiness and cocoa. I wouldn’t normally expect so much hoppyness in a dry stout, but it paired wonderfully. Taste of coffee and cocoa paired with a wonderful piney hoppyness. Mouthfeel had medium carbonation and medium body, very dry finish. I love this, and even with the steep price tag, I will and did pick up more. Definitely worth trying.

This review is from multiple bottles from 2005.  This past years version did not seem to be as good.

Poured to a jet-black with medium thick tan head hat lingered well thru mid-glass and left okay lacing. Nose was a pleasant chocolate-caramel malt with hints of earth scents as well. The mouthfeel of this medium-bodied beer was full and somewhat sweet, and the taste accentuated the chocolate-caramel of the nose. Alcohol never did make itself known, which at 5.25 is not surprising. Finish was sustained and pleasant. A pretty good stout.

I love this beer.  One of the most complex lighter stouts i have had...More hop aroma and flavor than any other light stout i have had, also hints of fruit, especially cherries...my only real knock is that is a little thin and has lower ABV, but that is really nitpicking
pours black with thin tan head.  aroma is roasted barley, coffee.  flavor is mild coffee, lots of good dark chocolate.  a little thin and slightly overcarbonated in my opinion.

My Mom flew this beer back for me from Indiana, great pick Mom!
It is a very dark brown, not quite black. There was little to no head, with a little lacing. It has great clarity, but looks a little thin. Note- I dont really care that much about appearance.
Aroma- friggin awesome. I know this sounds really corny, but it reminded me of a forest in the rain. It was a fresh aroma, woody with vanilla in front; roast malt in the back. I smelled this beer for awhile.
Taste- Really nice balance between aroma hops and malt, with a hop bite at the end. Not too hoppy at all. Vanilla was still there, with lots of roasted barley.
Mouthfeel, the beer was lighter in body, which made it easy to drink.
If I ever make it to Munster I will go to the brewery strictly for Black Sun.

Bottle. Pours black with brown translucent edges when put up to a light. The tan head quickly diminishes but creates some decent lacing. The aroma is very, very interesting. Lots of hops, chocolate, and some burnt cardboard notes. The initial flavours are rather interestin as well, because some werent noticeable in the aroma. All kinds of citrus is apparent, from darker citrus, to a little pineapple, apple, and kiwi. Hops make a big appearance with the citrus. Some roasted notes start to creep through along with a slight bitterness. Towards the finish, chocolate becomes more apparent. The roasted notes bursts, complementing the chocolate quite well. Citrus becomes overwhelmed by the other flavours, but is still noticeable towards the end. Apple seems to be the flavour that becomes more apparent than the rest. Light bitterness mixes well with a subtle chocolate sweetness. The finish is quite smooth. This is very, very tasteful.
Very nice.  Hoppy stout.  Black pour with little head.  Coffe, roasted malt, chocolate and hops.  What a combination.

Dark brown with an eggshell head that seems unmatched to the body.  Very unique for the style, with attributes of both an IPA and stout.  Rich chocolate, dry-roasted Columbian coffee, and caramel contrast a slight citrus and pine underbelly.  Interesting.  Rather thin but enjoyable.  Definitely a tasty beer but not on par with the big boys.

Shared with HogTownHarry, Harrys bottle (as always!!) Appearance: Deep black with a small frothy tan head. Aroma: WTF??? Harry warned me but my God... Its an IPA! No wait, there is some burned malt in there, but wow, that is unique. Flavour: Creamy, silky hoppy and malty, some peppermint? So smooth, a lovely coffee bitter finish, simply superb!

Another brew shared by bruce. Bottle about three years old. A little disappointed but for a dry stout it is not that bad... Light black in color with a small head. It was a light stout. Malty and sugar thrown in. Just to light for my liking... Thanks again Bruce for sharing.

Bottled sample from the brewery.  Shared it with Piscator.  We were a bit stressed at the lack of bublles at the start of puring, but the carbonation was perfect.  Surprisingly hopped for a stout. Great beer.

Tasted at the April Northern California Beer Tasting. This stout poured a dark black color from a 22oz bottle. Small to medium sized tan foamy head. The aroma is coffee, chocolate and a touch of diacetyl. Medium bodied stout. The malts are burnt malt, chocolate and coffee. The hops are piney and resinous. Kind of weird in an imperial stout. Decent balance. Good carbonation. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 Graduation weekend in Bloomington. Three Floyds Black Sun Stout is a deep black beer with a nicely formed brown head. The aroma is present, but with lighter characters than expected. This is a very viscus stout in nature, but not watery in taste. While this is a winter brew for Three Floyds, the flavor and finish are light enough to enjoy year round.

Pours a very dark mahogany brown color with a dissipating, foamy tan head.  Soapy, sudsy sheeting slowly droops down the glass, leaving minimal spotting behind.  The nose is as hoppy as a stout can possibly be, with crushing pine and spruce notes dominating what seems to be a roasty, chocolate and coffee background.  The flavor is just as hoppy, with pine resin overpowering the malty elements.  Bakers chocolate and espresso come through in the background, but serve more as afterthoughts to the intense bitterness.  The mouthfeel is substantial, but very dry and overly carbonated.  Kind of chalky feeling.  Overall, it seems as though the intense hopping is an attempt at covering up numerous flaws within the brew.  Its just too damn hoppy for the style.  Im not a big fan.
bottle from archerliqours.  Black with a creamy tan head.  Dark chocolate and citrus hops aroma.  Dark bitter chocolate, mild coffee notes, and an aggressive hoppiness.

Pours a near-black brown with a thin fine tan head.  Typical Three Floyds hop aroma  accompanied by large dry roasted coffee malt.  Very light bodied...a little bit crunchy =) with sophisticated carbonation.  Its always good to see a dry stout that is actually dry...ha!  Coffee malt, fresh hops, and some caramel malt maybe.  Easy drinking stout...and I mean it this time.. understated flavors.  This is my prelude to DLD 08! cya in a few hours =)

Bouteille 650ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, de chocolat noir, de houblon résineux et herbeux (menthe et herbe fraîche), moyen de café et avec des notes fruitées (raisins et prunes) et de sucre brun. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse et aux faibles notes résineuses. Léger goût fruité (léger de raisins, notes de cerises, traces de cassis et de prunes) accompagné de faibles notes de crème, de chocolat au lait (petites sensation lactique) ainsi que des traces de réglisse noire lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se  rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti, moyen de chocolat noir et avec de faibles notes de sucre brun. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un goût moyennement amer de houblon herbeux (herbes fraîches) et moyennement résineux (notes asséchantes) tout au long de la gorgée ainsi quun goût de café qui progresse pour devenir plus domiant en finale, avec des notes épicées (menthe et poivre). Post-goût long et un peu sec, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux et résineux, de rôti, de café, moyen de chocolat et avec des petites notes fruitées (pelures de prunes).

22 oz bottle given to me by tjthresh.  I believe this is a bottle from 2007.  Pour is deep black, with a one inch dark tan head in my snifter.  Head settled slowly, with a nice rocky appearance.  Aroma of bitter pine hops and roasted coffee.  There is also some dry fruit sweetness.  Taste has a really interesting combination of the pine hops, the roasted malt and the fruit sweetness which is more like plum in the taste.  Nothing is terribly dominant, great balance.  The palate is very wet and mouth coating.  The bitterness lasts a decently long time, as does the soft sweetness and roast.  Really well done Stout, and crazy drinkable.  Thanks for lugging this one back from Indiana Tom!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2008 This isnt a dry stout at all. More like a sweet or standard. Pours more like an Impy with its oily consistency and deep tan colored head. Nose is coffee, sugars and subtle roasted malt. The flavor is quite complex with a substantial hop presence, all influences found in the nose, but what stands out most is buttered popcorn, both in the flavor and the mouthfeel. Always an experiance with 3F.

On nitro tap at the brewpub. Overall this is my favorite Stout hands down to date. Complex yet smooth. Subtle notes of Coffee, Chocolate, slight raisin & malt sweetness, with more hop finish than the average stout. Very well balanced, with no single trait too overpowering. I need to find this in the bottle to see if it stands up to the draft offering at FFF.

08 Bottle:  Pours a translucent black color with a small tan head.  Dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and brown sugar are all noticeable in the nose.  Some very mild soft hop notes show up as it warms.  Medium-bodied mouth feel, flavors of chocolate malt, coffee and piney hops throughout.  Solid brew.

From bottle:  This pours black in color with a brown head that dissipates just leaving some light lacing.  The nose shows scents of chocolate, cream, coffee and a dry, mineral edge.  These flavors follow through to a medium-bodied beer with good depth.  The midpalate shows bitter chocolate and expresso roast which transfers toward a dry mineral finish.

Pours a deep, pitch black with a minimal, but stubborn mocha head. Very interesting aroma for a stout - some of the familiar notes are there in the form of chocolate and subtle dark fruits, but these are covered up by a peppery hop aroma. The flavor is starts bitter-sweet with some nice coffee and dark chocolate notes, and finishes nicely bitter and dry with the spicy hops taking over (although I must say that there is a lingering milk chocolate sweetness on the tongue once the hops have faded). The mouthfeel is a little pit prickly for a stout, but works given the dry spicy flavors of the brew. A solid stout, and pretty unique given the intense hop flavor/aroma present, but not the best Ive tasted.

Pours dark black with a nice tan head.  When I smelled this beer, I really didnt know what to think.  Theres so much hops!  Then, less abundantly are the roasted malt notes you expect in a stout.  The flavor is sweet with some caramel and a hoppy dry finish.  The mouthfeel is light-bodied but rather smooth going down.  Quite a different stout, but definitely something enjoyable.

No head. Aroma: Piny hops and a bit of cat pee. Quite hoppy. The rest of aroma is fairly dark, not sweet, somewhat bitter, malts. Taste: Some chocolate, still quite a bit of hops for a stout. Finishes, dry and chocolaty from both the hops and bitter malt. Mouthfeel is decently smooth but a bit too thin.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 filthy dark allowing no light to penetrate. much less aroma then i predicted, what is there is similiar ironic: sweet, if anything. typical stout silky mouthfeel, doesnt coat for long before a quicker finish then one might expect.  more chocolate then coffee, more malt then hops, this doesnt linger for long. warming even at low ABV and relaxing, a solid stout but not as satisfying as id expect from 3F. love to try the bouban barreled version, it would probably make up for the shortcomings here.

rerate for nearly 2 years aged bottle from lush: first of all it seems i was espically harsh in my initial review i upped ’overall’ to 16), and i neglected to mention the wonderful dried cherries, which are even more evident in this aged version.  booze seems prevelant despite the low ABV, this is a nice balance between comforting and challenging

bottle: pours black with a small soap bubble tan head. aroma  of floral hops hit me first.  good dark fruits,some sweet malts, fresh fruits, touches of chocolate and small roast. this all plays behind the fresh hop aroma. the flavour is much more roasty than the aroma with plenty of chcolate and some coffee, stilll a good amount of sweet malts linger with in. the hops from the nose are not as strong as i thought they would be, but do show up in the finish with some bitterness. very good stout

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2008 Thanks Jerel and/or Jean!  Pours a dark brown to black with a decent enough tan head, thinning over time.  The nose is sweeter than most dry stouts, with strong enough roast, and stronger hops, ala FFF.  The mouthfeel is a bit thicker than a dry stout, welcome, for sure!  The flavors are in line with the nose.  This is a hopped up stout.  A bit less dry than most for the style, that Amarillo hop FFF bite, but at the end, a fine stout, perhaps not $8 fine, but I wouldnt hold that against the beer.
Black color with a creamy tan head. Aromas of dark fruit, chocolate, molasses and coffee with a hint of hops. Taste isof coffee and chocolate with some dark fruit and a medium hop flavor.

Bomber, thanks to TomDecapolis! Pours almost clear black with a lacy tan head. Medium-light body. Chocolate pine nose. Coffee, chocolate and brown sugar taste. Chocolate and grapefruit finish -which sounds weird after the fact, but was really nice.

22. Thanks, BitBucket! Black, thin tan head. Big chocolate nose. Nice creamy medium body. Chocolate and roast on themid-palate with just a little bit of hop on the back end to balance it out. Mild dry cocoa finish.

pours black with no head.  sweet, woody, slightly medicinal aroma.  sweet & piney flavor with a good medicinal bite.  finishes a touch too sweet for my taste.  but this light-bodied brew is definitely worth trying from one of the best brewers in the world.  maybe i got a bit too rah-rah there,.  sorry.  (love you floyd, floyd and floyd).

Thanks to JCapriotti for the bomber. Pours deep brown with a smallish head. Aroma of coffee, licorice, roasty malts and huge pine hops. Dry, without a lot of dark fruit.  Medium bodied and surprisingly drinkable. Im obviously getting a little more used to highly hopped stouts. (This doesnt totally suck)

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 Bomber courtesy of tjthresh. This is a very cool looking bottle, probably my favorite label for a 3F brew. It pours black with a dense, creamy, tan head. Picture perfect. The nose is an interesting and fairly enticing blend of: coffee, roast malt, piny hops, bing cherries and faint chocolate. Light to medium-bodied and fairly aqueous, it transitions to a lightly dry and mildly bitter finish. It is a bit thinner than Id expected, but it is supremely quaffable. Sweet, dark roast and coffee are followed quickly by floral and lightly piny hops and notes of caramel, cherries and light chocolate, very much like the nose. Quite nice and beautifully balanced. This is easily my favorite dry stout and one of the most flavorful and drinkable stouts that I have tried. It combines the thinner quaffability of Guinness with the flavor of a 3F brew. Three Floyds may be famous for Dark Lord and Dreadnaught (both excellent beers), but they continually impress me with the quality of their session brews. Thanks a million for bringing this one back from the brewery, Tom!

Bomber pours out dark brown and opaque. Nice khaki head that laces well. Pungent aroma of pine resin hops and chocolate. Citrusy grapefruit underneath. Creamy medium body is lighter than most stouts but improves drinkability. Taste has a spruce pine bitterness that is edged by grapefruit notes. A hint of roast bitterness is lost in the wave of hops. Dark chocolate notes try to assert throughout. Finishes dry. Certainly one of the hoppiest stouts out there and one of my favorites.

Black pour with a tight off white head.  Aroma of hops and some sweet malts.  Hoppy aroma not really expected from the pour.  Taste is roasted with sweet malts and a light, dry, hop finish.  Some coffee present.  Mouth is prettty thin for a stout.  But a good brew all around.

2-3-08 bottle shared at tasting 

Thick black in color.  Nice sweet hoppy malt smell.  Tastes decent - not the best from Three Floyds, but no doubt another good solid brew.  Palate is a bit tricky - highly carbonated and very thin and somewhat watery.  However, the flavor of hops and sweet malt makes up for it.

Pours black, with a light tan head and a smell of dry roastiness with nicely noticeable hop nose which you dont generally expect from the style, and which almost gives in a minty freshness.  Taste is roasty, mild, and dry with a subtle and simple hop flavor giving it a bit of added flavor.  Very drinkable, I found, and although not groundbreaking, I thought it was exceptional for the style, albeit overpriced...

Bottle. Nose shows lots of hops, oddly because none show up in the flavor profile, with a touch of coffee. Black with a thick beige head. Nice classic dry stout flavors, lightly sweet with a milky palate and lots of roasted malt character.  Really great example of the style.

Aroma:Roasted Hops, fallowed by hearty wheat bread, with a milk chocolate finish.
Appearance: Black with a thick fluffy head, nice lacing.
Light chocolate notes upfront followed by a smooth coffee flavor. 
Full smooth palate.
Its solid, but nothing spectacular.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 This beer is unlike any "stout" I have had.  It has a lower ABV, which is good in this case.  This is a very drinkable beer.  It is thin on the palate and is certainly the most "hoppy" stout I have had.  It has an aroma of coffee,  honey, and syrup.  It has a dry almost smokey finish.  I think a lot of people tend to rate this beer low (than other 3Fs anyway) because of the ABV and thinness, however that makes it great.  I could drink this all day long over other beers with higher ABV.  This is probably my favorite Three Floyds beer so far and the bottle is cool as hell.
Dark pour. Aroma and flavor of dark chocolate, walnuts, burned coffee, sour roasted malt. Surprising hop presence and a fairly bitter hop finish. Good, but not great.

Probably my least favorite Three Floyds beverage Ive had to date. Too much going on for a dry stout. Looks like they were trying to make a beer with a  little bit of something for everyone and ending up with an average beer.

April 2006 - I didnt find this nearly as offensive as some of my finer brethren did. Yes, it was a weird take on the dry stout style (I never would have known that it wanted to be a "dry" stout), but something about the sweet licoricy flavor, the strong roastiness and the coffee...it had a nice complexity to it and I didnt mind the overhopped nature. I was kinda liking it.

22oz Bomber

Recieved this in a trade from my RB Secret Santa, thanks Melvin. An aggressive pour brought about a fingers worth of tan creamy head that settled to a thick crown. Black body with no light coming throuhg at any point. Leaves patchy lacing here and there. 

Although the aroma is fairly simple its no less appetizing. Theres a light roastiness with a mild nuttiness and mild lactic creaminess. Theres also some dark fruit, as it warms, adding a sweetness that compliments the roastiness nicely. There a hint of the nuttiness throught but its faint. 

Black Sun is medium bodied with a slightly prickly carbonation which at certain times feels a little too prickly. 

This is a beer I could enjoy all night. Big flavor from a more standard abv stout. The abv really helps the drinkability. 

Another good beer from Three Floyds. Ive always passed this beer up because the pricetag is pretty hefty considering the abv. Im glad I got to give it a shot. Although the price tag is high I would pick a bottle of this up occasionally.

This is a solid stout from Three Floyds. The aroma translates pretty well into the flavor. Light roastiness is the canvas with a splash of lactic creaminess here and dark fruit there. The dark fruit shows up on the backend.

1/20/08
Bottle.  lots of hops.  Most ive ever had in a stout.  Quite low alcohol for a stout as well.  overall a pretty good stout.  three floyds never lets me down

22oz bomber poured into a glass.  dark black pour, little head until i poured more aggressively and then i ended up with one about 1 inch thick.  smells of chocolate and light coffee.  appearance is dark black with a slight ring of head remaining after the initial pour.  slight lacing.  smoke, coffee, sweet tastes.  medium bodied and leaves a slight coating in your mouth which hangs around

Draft.  Pours jet black.  Has the aroma of roastiness and chocolate if you concentrate to get past the most hop aroma Ive ever experinced with a stout.  Tastes roasty and malty sweet finishing with hops the way only 3 Floyds can
September 2006 - wonderful salty nose-  almost like sea air (I wrote this down - was I drunk?). Dark brown color, small head n top. Chocolate malt taste- a bit sweet. Interesting and good.

I was a little let down by this - very strange coming from my favorite brewery.  Not bad by any means, but there are alot of better options out there when it comes to basic dry stout.  Lots of hops, no surprise there.  Maybe not enough alcohol to be sipped, and too much body to be sucked down like your average everyday stout.

I was really surprised with this one.  Liked this one a lot better than most. 

Jet black pour of course, small head.  Awesome lacing. 

Absolutely the hoppiest stout that Ive ever smelled or tasted.  Mixture of hops and malt and chocolate on the smell. Big time hop presence on the taste here.  Starts hoppy, fades to malt and chocolate and then finishes with the hop presence again.  

Another awesome FFF brew.

Bottle.  Pours with a deep black body with an olive-green head, but the beer is too lively (at least too noticeably lively) for my taste.  Smells of mocha coffee, roasted nut, and chocolate-covered cherry.  Flavor is dry roasted nut with a cocoa powder finish.  Average mouthfeel.  Decent stout, but finish is a tad too dry for me.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Weird dry stout. Not actually crazy about this one. Nose is roasted malt and hops. Taste is roasted and chocolately but the mouthfeel is thin. Good with my rack of ribs but not awesome.

Bottle from West Lakeview Liquors, Chicago.  Dark brown color with medium brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt, farely sweet, chocolate, and a slight smoke.  Flavor is chocolate and roasted malt, pretty sweet, plum, not bad though.  Medium body and slightly creamy.  Okay.

Poured the expected near black with some lighter hints at brown and ruby.  Brown head produced more foam than I anticipated and after it receded it managed to provide tiny spots of lace.  The aroma was roasty malt, light campfire even with some chocolate and the definite presence of hops.  The flavor followed suit, with mild cedar, smoke, roasted malt and chocolate all coming together fairly well.  Lots of tight carbonation initally, so decanting this one for half an hour to an hour only helps it escape from what could have been a fizzy mess.

22 oz bottle.  A well put together stout.  Nice aroma.  This beer has nice touches of chocolate, licorice, and a little bit of coffee.  It has a nice little smoky flavor to it.  I thought I remember the beer having a little bit of a hop character the first time I tried it...maybe it doesnt have it as much now or I might have had a little bit of an older bottle.  I kind of like that a 22oz bomber is only a 5.25% beer instead of a 10%+ it seems like a lot of them are.
Did not know about the low percentage. Lots of nice flavors and complexity for a low abv brew. Some light chocolate, coffee and sweetness. Taste a bit creamy with a faint roastiness.

22oz bottle.  Really nice stout - light brown head, quickly dissipating.  No lacing on the glass to speak of.  Reminds me a bit of a milk stout, definitely tangy.  Chocolate, coffee, malty, smoke.  One of my favorite 3F offerings

Rich aroma of cocoa, fudge, walnut, and maple syrup. Black pour with a medium brown head.  Harmonious taste of chocolate and licorice. The licorice lingers on the palate with a subtle introduction of smoke. Medium body, yet sufficiently flavorful. Not very hoppy. This a special brew!
For having on 5% abv, this beer has plenty of taste. So many flavors swirling around in here. It was  very dark and complex, more like an imperial stout. Hopped fairly well too.

I really liked this beer, Im surprised its not ranked higher. Pours black with virtually no head.  Mouthfeel is great, hops up front with smooth finish.  Almost like a smoked  porter/stout.  My only complaint is I would like to have it a little more full bodied but the flavor is about right for 5.25%.

Pours pitch black with a thin fluffy mocha-colored head. Aroma of sweet roast, coffee, roasty chocolate, alefruits, brown sugar, smoke, pepper and bourbon. Taste is lightly sweet and smokey with notes of coffee and sweet maltiness. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush (over)carbonation and just a lingering amount of sweetness that I enjoy in a dry stout.

Black with a tan large head.  Hoppy smell at the first whiff but quicks goes to roasted coffee and dark chocalate aromas.  Coffee and roasted flavors are nice and it finishes with some strong hopiness at the back of the palate.

22 oz. bottle from (I think) slob!  Pours ebony and opaque with a small tan head.  Very torasty aroma, bitter chcolate, molasses, herbal and floral hops, orange zest, french roast coffee.  Unsurprisingly has a roasty flavor as well, dark unsweetened chocolate, slightly soured milk, herbal notes, prune, lots of floral and slightly citrus hops, bitter coffee.  Medium body, velvety mouthfeel and gentle carbonation.  Nice treat from 3Fs.
Pours black with a hint of coffee smell.  Not cloudy at all.  Thin body for this type of beer.  Roasted malt flavor.
pours a black with mild tan head.  hop presence on aroma.  licht mocha presence, mild finish.  has a fluid palate.  good.
Pours black as coal with a thin dissapating tan head.Aromas of hops and coffee. The hop presence was too much for me.The finish was hop bitterness.

Bottle from Discount Liquor. Pours a deep brown bordering on what could be black. Clear as in not hazy or cloudy.
Nose is rather dull with a bit of smoky, roasted malts. Ehhh, only okay. Thin on the tongue which I detest.

Aroma is roasty and bitter. Pours black and when I hold it up to light I cannot see through it. The beer also has a pretty dark brown head. Flavor is alot of coffee taste with some strong initial hop bitterness. As the hop flavors dissipate, more espresso like flavors coat the mouth. Very dry finish.

My third bomber of Black Sun, as far as I can recall, and Im still not feeling it as much as most raters. Im a fan of the brewery and the style, but I feel that this one - while very solid and generally above average - sort of falls short of the mark. First, theres a trace of oxidation. While I was looking for that lovely, gentle roast that you get in the best dry stouts, I found something too close to a thinly hopped bitterness. Not bad, but not what I want. Second, since the brew moves away from classic dry stout qualities, its also surprisingly thin in the body, with an insubstantial presence that undercuts the malt presence. Like I said, its a solid brew but I find it short of expectations.

Bottled. Black colour, small brown head. Aroma is slightly roasted, coffeeish and also some sourness. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee and some chocolate. Quite sour also. Pleasant thing, with quite dry palate.

Bottle @ Chris_o shindig 2007. Dark black color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark chocolate, strong coffee, roasted. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Witn a nice dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Courtesy bdigi66.  Pours black with a thin, quickly dissapearing light tan head.  Pretty big roasty aroma, alot of toasted malts, nuts, and mild chocolate.  Pretty nice smell.  The taste had real nice body to it, alot of roast, and the chocolate really shows up in the flavor.  Definitely was a little dry, so I think this is labeled correctly.  The finish was medium, mouthfeel was slightly sticky, and the aftertaste was of roast and dark malts.  Pretty damn good stout.

Bottle, Chris_o shindig. Black, fine tan head. Caramel, rum, and nice fresh esters. Makes me think of the aroma a Wyeast 1028 bubbling happily away, a very nice aroma indeed. Soft chocolate flavor. Solid, though apart from the aroma, a little unexceptional. Surprised to see this listed as a dry stout.

Bottle courtesy of Hogtownharry: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a small foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of medium bitter hops with some roasted malt. Texture is quite oily with some medium carbonation. Taste is a complex mix between some bitter roasted malt, some light chocolate notes as well as vanilla with some light bitter hops at the end. I very much enjoyed that one and I was glad that they didnt rely only on hops.

Bottle, Chris_o shindig. Nose is metallic with some malt, chocolate, espresso. Roasted. Brown with a thin tan head. Caramel toffee mouth with sweetness. Burnt malt and lasting. Finishes sweet malty caramel. Nothing special, but its good.
Bottle at Chris_o Shindig.  Black with beige head.  Lovely intense black malts.  Good intensity, good tar.  Good espresso stout.  Even managed to overcome my anti Three Floyds bias.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at Chris Os Shindig. Excellent o.t.t. American hoppy nose with lashings of malt and chocolate. Excellent in the looks department too. Black body, glorious tan head. Very good stuff. Surprisingly mellow and drinkable considering the aroma. Roasty and generally stoutlike but with a truckload of hops too. Nice wooden notes in the finish. Soft and very drinkable. Good beer.

Bottled - Chris O shindig 2007 - A black beer with little head.  The aroma is oily, hoppy and fishy.  Licquorice notes but suprisingly no roast.  The taste has fruit and light roast.  Chocolate and hops also.  Some hints of sweetness.  Tasty.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2009 Black with a brown head. Toffee and chocolate aromas, with a blackberry note and some alcohol, not all that complex. Sweet chocolate and roasted flavour with a long lasting roast aftertaste. I was not as impressed as others around the table.
Pours black with tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor was light woth chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.

22 oz bottle from Capones.  Pours opaque black with a beautiful dark beige head that displayed excellent retention.  The lacing provided ringlets of beige that stuck to the snifter.  The scent was of chocolate, roasted nuts, toffee, and coffee notes.  The taste was very complex, almost like an imperial stout with notes of coffee, malt, roastiness and chocolate swirling around together.  I was very impressed with how much there was going on in this dry stout.  Excellent!

Dark black with a bubbly head, and lace.  Very hoppy, with bittersweet chocolate.  Significant burnt and sour characteristics.
Bottle courtesy of Shintriad.  A bold Irish dry stout, and certainly good regular American stout.

Pours very opaque, which belies its surprising lightbodied-ness.  Aroma is not too strong, but has a sort of bitey zinging quality to it.  Flavor is clean and incomplex.  Dry, roasty, hints of coffee.  I think this is a great example of this style.  Certainly not heavy or thick like many of this beers stout-brothers, but roasty and thoroughly enjoyable.  (Wouldnt pay $12 for it again though!)

Aroma is interesting, touch of vanilla, some spice, but something almost sharp hiding in the background.  The beer itself is an opaque black, with a thin tan head that fades away quickly.  First, the body is really light, not what I was expecting at all.  The flavor seems to have something I cant place in it, something that causes it to have a bit of astringency in the beer.  Overall, glad I tried it, but theres a whole lot better out there for a far better price.
Just OK and way overpriced (thus the 10 overall rating - wouldve been 13 otherwise).

Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of biscuits and chocolate with some dark fruits. Flavor is much the same with hops added. Needs more thickness and strength, but a good, if expensive, session beer.

A very good stout, it just lacks depth.  I think that if this thing had a little bit more body to go along with the wet hop, chocolate biscuit.  Very surprisingly light bodied, i just wish it would linger.  Good, and very sessionable.

650mL bottle, courtesy of hopscotch.  Thanks, Eric!  Pours a dark brown color; medium tan head with patchy lacing.  Surprisingly fruity aroma; dark chocolate and biscuity malts.  Medium mouthfeel (slightly watery): bitter chocolate and citrus hops, with some red fruits.  Medium, bitter chocolate finish.

22 oz bomber. Poured a thick deep dark black that no light could possibly penetrate with a small light brown head. Aroma was freeze dried espresso and vanilla. Flavor was similiar with an overall freeze dried flavor but still very pleasant none the less. Good beer, not great like you would believe since its a FFF but good overall.

Appearance: Pours a black-brown body with a tan-colored head.

Smell: Rich chocolate malt aroma with notes of light, roasted coffee and smoke. The nose has an intense floral hoppiness to it, too. That much I assure you.

Taste: Flavors of dark chocolate and vanilla creme upfront that are quickly overcome bitterness. Hmm. Well, this beer certainly took an (unexpected?) detour into rather bitter territories. Herbaceous, piney bitterness continues to last through the dry, chalky finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied, but this beer has a remarkabe viscousness to it.

Drinkability: Pretty good beer, all things considered. I couldve used more chocolatiness, though.

Very dark brown with no head.  
Even though it looks like and at first taste is like a typical stout it is very different.  Undertones of coffee and malts. But very light and woody.  My favorite stout ever.
Nose-grassy, chocolately, malty. Body-opaque with a lasting foamy head. Taste-medium to high sharpness, grass, low chocolate, medium stale hops. Very good mix of hops and malt. Solid.

22 oz bottle. Served at cellar temperature. Relatively thick pour (but not as thick as Bells stouts). Color was opaque black. Head was foamy with stippled milk chocolate and oatmeal colors. It reduced rapidly to a lasting cap and left only scant lace behind. Attractive marriage of roasty/chocolatey malt and flowery hop aromas. Slightly sweet on the tongue with flowery hop flavor throughout. The hops are joined by malty chocolate, some blackened toast, and toffee. Finished with subdued roasty bitterness that lingered lovingly with flowery hops. Good stout.
I was stunned that this wasnt an imperial at first taste.  Very bitter.  Full of roasty coffee goodness.  Very delicious.

22oz. Bottle:  Lightly sweet and lightly bitter aroma.  Smells of roasted malts and some resiny hops.  Poured dark black with a big brown head.  Good lacing.  Opaque.  Flavor is a little sweet and a little bitter.  Starts quite malty, but then becomes hoppy and a little bitter, before ending with a nice balance of hops and roasted malts.  Light to medium body.  Watery texture.  Soft carbonation.  Long, roasted, malty, slightly bitter finish.  Very well balanced.
Chicago Trip. Saturday 23:59. Bottle at the motel. Black liquid. Coffee brown foam and lacing. Strong coffee aroma. Smooth dark fruit. Rubbery sourness. Lots of warm coffee. Intriguing sugary finish.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 Bottle from Capones. Thanks Stegosaurus. Nice ebony pour with modest tan head. Nose is of roast and pine. Roast taste with a hoppy finish. Very dry but smooth. I enjoyed this one alot.

22 oz  bomber via trade with EddieG.  Thanks.  Second Beer Lost Season 3 Finale, following DFH Red and White.  Pours black duh, with a half finger light brown head.  Very dry aroma lightly roasted.  Roasty malt with a bit of chocolate on the end.  Good dry stout, why did I wait so long to pop this.  On to the rest of Lost.

This is a solid dry stout...but I honesty expect a little better from Three Floyds.  This beer has tons of bitter hops and malt present, and if you close your eyes and smell the aromas, it smells like an IPA...HOWEVER, I believe that their signiature hop presence and taste was neglected a little....this dry stout needed a better hop backbone to fulfill my taste...but definitely a great stout nonetheless.  Dark, creamy, satisfying.

Some hops is an otherwise roasted malt nose typical of stouts. Opaque brown color, fluffy head. Licorice middle, bitter chocolate sweetness. Some hops in the end and a little salty. Drying bitter end. Big beer for sure. Good stuff.

Rating No. 1075.  Bottle.  This is just too hard to find in Indiana.  Sweet malty aroma with impy notes (chocolate and roast levels are that high) leaning toward milk chocolate, with surprising hoppiness.  Opaque motor oil pour with a foamy dark brown head.  Initial taste is strong sourness, soon overtaken by stronger bittersweet roast coffee.  Chocolate creeps in but stays behind that salty roast. Rather light-bodied, very drinkable.  Slight hop tingle begins on the tip of the tongue and lasts into the throat.  Dryish, bitterish, slightly sourish finish with milk chocolate and medium-strength grapefruit tones lingering in the aftertaste.  The hops make it a stylish brew, and the grapefruit notes really do harmonize.  The advertised flavor - including hues of cherry, vanilla, and dried fruit - is absent, but thats not a knock on what is present (a robust, delicious session).  Who bottles 5.25% in bombers?
pours black with small tan head.  aroma is coffee and hops.  taste is coffee and hops.  finish dry coffee hoppiness.  gives wonderful hoppy coffee burps.  not overally complex but damn tasty.

Black pour, medium density. A small beige head forms, with moderate retention and leaving thin lacing in its wake. Aroma is all pine, very hoppy. Biting roastiness follows. Notes of molasses, chocolate, coffee, fresh vanilla, caramel all very distinguishable. Flavor is extremely hoppy and very bitter, the hoppiest beer thats this dark that I can recall. Light sweetness and light astringency coupled with bold roastiness gently subdue much of the hops; balance at this velocity of flavor seems unlikely though. The chocolate character is chalky and spicy. Fnishes very dry and hoppy, chcolate lingering for some time. Mouthfeel is well-rounded, somewhat balanced and medium-full bodied. Very enjoyable, highly charismatic.

Bottle drunk 4/27. Black with good medium body. Nice roasted malt/maple syrup/hop aroma. Light coffeehoppy taste. I can get any time but got it in a trade so I had to drink it. Pretty good better then I thought it would be.

Shared courtesy of the ever generous piscator34. Thanks Kris!! This is one tasty brew. Beautiful looking stout with a great nose of roasty hoppy goodness. This is a complex brew that is really telling on how complex brew doesnt need to be a booze bomb. Roasty, medium body and medium carbonation with a cascade hop kick at the tail end. Finishes very nicely. Great session stout and holds its own against its bigger brothers. Well done FFF!

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2007 22 oz bomber.  Pours deep brown/black with a good sized dark tannish head that disappears quickly.  Very rich aroma with strong smells of coffee, hops and cherry.  Tastes just like it smells with a chocolate finish.  A great stout worthy of high praise.  I love it!

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2007 Bomber via mnurda, but sampled with oakbluff. Black in colour with medium carbonation. Big American C-hop aromas upfront with notes of citrus, black pepper, and herbs, followed up by some dark roasted malt notes. Some caramel sweetness upfront along with some strong chocolate and coffee character. The hops re-assert themselves near the end and integrate surprisingly well with the dry roasted finish. Im shocked at how well the high hop rate seems to work within the context of a session stout. Fantastic stuff.

bomber...pours jet black w/ a slight oily consistency, aroma is unlike any stout Ive ever smelled before...strong American hops, taste is sweet up front and fades into hoppy-roasted flavor.  Good, certainly unique and will buy again, one would think it would have a higher abv by the taste

On tap at Roccos on 45th in Highland, IN.  Taste definetely surprised me with its hopiness and the aroma is just full of hops, truly unique aroma .  Chocolately but definetely this beer is all about the hops.  A truly great stout

Super dark pour. Creamy brown head. Aroma is of HOPS! Woo! Nice chocolate, coffee and malt in there too. First sip is big hops and chocolate. Very different for a stout. Very warm and welcoming. The bitter coffee finish is a lovely balance. Nice distinct differences from beginning to end. This is what I want out of a stout. Again, I cant get over that awesome hop aroma and smooth chocolatey mouthfeel. Incredible stout.
On tap at 3F brewpub.  Not overly complex, but definitely a good dry stout.  I dont usually like stouts, but could drink a few of these with no problems.

Black Color with Dark Tan Ring.  Chocolate, English Hopped Aroma.  Big Initial Hop Hit on the Tongue...Chocolate, Light Malty Background...Dry Hopped Aftertaste.  Some Subtle Light Roasts...Not Very Balanced...Hops Definitly Win Out on Dominance...Big Tasting Beer for the Alcohol.
22 oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown with thick tan head.  Smells surprisingly hoppy for a stout.  Chocolate and coffee, too.  Great flavor... the hops are what make this unique.

pours black like any other stout with some tan head. Theres a fair bit of lacing around the glass. The aroma is full of coffee, chocolate, and piney hops (its not normal!).  The taste echoes the aroma, displaying bitter chocolate and coffee up front, and hop bitterness in the back. It finishes with a mix of coffee and hop bitterness.  Despite it being against convention, I really like the use of extra hops here, though you may have to be in a certain mood to actually want that sort of hoppiness in your stout. Mouthfeel is pretty good, between watery and thick. To be honest, the beer isnt as complex as the label makes it out to be, saying that cherries and dark fruits should be in the flavor as well. Despite the relative lack of complexity, this was a very tasty brew. Definitely something Id drink all night, if given the chance.

Tap, nitro @ Coles.  Completely opaque, dense tan head.  Nose is that distinctive 3F fruity hop hit.  Hidden behind that is cocoa, dark malt.  Very un-stout.  Flavor is chocolate covered fruity hops, caramel, dark malt hiding behind a tingly bitterness.  Cocoa milkshake finish.

draft off the nitrogen tap....appearance was nice.  black with a nice fluffy tan head....aroma was lightly floral along with a malty, chocolate essence....taste was lead by the roasty malts and then taken over by the floral hops. a different combination but it was nice nonetheless. mouthfeel was very nice, smooth and creamy.

Pours an opaque black with a fluffy brown head.  Aroma is roasted malts, some coffee, chocolate, caramel, and a hint of hops. to it.  Flavor is dry roasted malts, some caramel, chocolate, and a bitter dry finish.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY on Nitro. Pours a beautful black with that nitro guinness look. Malty, coffee & slight choclate notes. Light to medium bodied & quite good.

Bottle - pitch black pour with a very light tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolates/coco with some hop spice.  Flavor is similar with strong roasted notes, coffee and a firm resinous hoppy flavor.

22 oz from Ty5592...An amazing beer. Dont think it gets the credit it is due to the low abv...Eventhough it is not a "big" beer, it is excellent. Pours like black tar, nice dark brown head, tastes of melted chocalte, with a roasted coffee finish. Drank this with a couple friends who were strategizing about how we could locate more...In another state...Thanks Ty.
Black body, dark tan head, roasty nose. Serious cocoa with coffee notes, creamy mouthfeel, excellent.

22 oz. btl.  pours jet black with a tan head. nice lacing. Aroma of sweet malt dark roast coffee and roasted bread. Sweet beggining of caramel and toffe with subtle esspresso and bisquit.  finishes slight sweet and dry. I agree w/ the btl description of light body. Very drinkable and smooooooth...

22oz bomber.  Pours thick, dark black with a small brown head that goes away fast.  Looks like an imperial - very dark.  Aroma is the hoppiest stout Ive ever smelled.  Under the hops theres some malts and chocolate, but hops predominate.  Nice. Flavor is a nice balance between hops at first then sweet, chocolatey malts.  Very impressive.

This is a very dark beer out of the 22oz bottle with only hints of light around the edges when held up to the light.  The surface of the beer has a thin galaxy of a tan whisp and a lasting ring around the edge of the glass.  Nose of sweetened coffee and molassess.  I get lots of coffee in this beer, both in the initial sip and long into the finish.  Sweetened coffee, bitter chocolate, molasses, some ash and burnt grains.  The finish is a long coffee bean, dark roasted malt bitterness.  Very nice stout.
