Bomber, pours a thicker deep black, nice dark tan foamy head, great lacing.  Very roasty malt aroma, some light chocolate and espresso coming through.  Smooth and covering mouthfeel, friendly on the palate with an appropriate dry finish.  Starts a touch sweet and finishes dry.  Not a bad stout, recommended.

Sampled at the O-Town throwdown. Pours black with light brown head. The aroma has a mild burnt maltiness with some sweeter malts and maybe some oatmeal or rye. The flavor is just like the aroma with burnt malts, lightly caramelized malts, some vanilla and maybe oatmeal.

A black pour with a decent very dark head. Aroma is strong roasted malts and mild hops. As it warms it seems to get sort of a vegetable type aroma. Weird but good. Flavor starts out quite roasty but then switches to more of a hoppy light citrus taste.  Also is quite dry in the finisg. Very interesting and pretty darn good.

On tap @ the underbar, happy birthday Ethan. Thick chocolate black color with a creamy head (and no, unlike the hopleaf this one was without nitro).  Bakers chocolate chalky malty and pine hop aroma.  Medium light bodied chocolate, roast, slight hops, lightly sweet.  Tasty beer, not worth the price in the bomber, but pretty decent on tap.  I would probably consume a decent amount of this stuff if it was in sixers at alpha price, but for now, ill have my one pint at underbar a year.  See ya next year evil mario 3 sun.

Courtesy hopscotch, consumed at the Throwdown.  Aroma is a chocolate hoppiness, much akin to Alpha Klaus.  This brew really seemed like a variation on Alpha Klaus with some slight differences.  Black thin tan head.  Thinnish palate for a stout.  More roast in the finish where AK has a hop punch.  Seems like a toned-down, more traditional version of Alpha Klaus.

This may sound weird but when I poured this beer I instantly thought the smell was of black olives (a favorite of mine).  Poured black and had a head that increased after the pour and then quickly subsided to little lacing.  First taste was of a sweet hop and then a finish of a weak coffee taste.  I didnt get the caramel taste but would recommend this as a decent stout.

Powerful malt. sweet-caramel aroma.  Pours a deep black color with a slight cream head. Dry with malts and some hops up front and some chocolate/ caramel at the end.  Hints of coffee throughout.  Light-bodied for a stout.

22oz bomber- Aroma is of light chocolate and coffe. Pours black with minimal head which dissipates quickly. Very dry flavor profile and also very hoppy. The body is more on the thin side for a stout but never the less very tasty. This beer finishes with a dry roasty flavor. Overall a nice beer.

Bottle from Ty. Aroma is very interesting... dry woodiness -- not oak, more like farmed wood -- light pine, paint, vanilla, tar. Quite unique. Flavor starts with that dryness, but ends up a lot more sweet, round, saucy, with maple sugar, mahagony. Not as good, and could be a good bit more dry. Certainly not "surprisingly light-bodied." A nice beer, though misses the style mark by a good margin, I think. Seems more of a brown porter to me.

man, it is great to vacation in america... all i remember about this beer is that i had it just after "last call" and it was absolutely delicious. i mean, the most enjoyable stout i ever had... it was so smooth and easy to drink, but it wasnt really sweet, rather, quite hoppy instead and it handled like a champion session. so flavorful... so quaffable... three floyds always surprises me! now, i just need to drink it sober to gather some objective notes... for now, im probably overrating this brew, but you all can suck it!

22-oz. bottle courtesy of tjthresh.  Pours black with spare dark brown head, mostly diminishing, spare lacing.  Aroma is average malt (chocolate, caramel), heavy hops (pine), light yeast (dough) with notes of tar and wood.  Medium bodied, thin texture, flat carbonation and a chalky finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, acidity and bitterness; nice roasted malt and chocolate flavor.

Midnight black pour, thin wisp of a tan head.  Aroma is burnt coffee, chocolate and piney hoppiness.  Palate is a bit thin for a stout.  Flavor is coffee and dark chocolate mixed with a bunch of hops.  Probably one of the hopiest stouts Ive every drank.

Yum. From Bomber during Superbowl. Indiana wins. 
Pours dark and develops a dark brown, espresso like head. Its thin and it doesnt persist. Its so full of rich chocolate flavors, its so smooth. The alcohol is subdued, and the beer while thoroughly satisfying is an exercise in restraint and finess by the guys at 3F. 
Wonderful. I want more of this. Someone said delicious. I agree.

A big o Super bomber of Stout for Super Bowl Sunday!  Poured into a snifter, this sucks in the light like a black hole, but has no head whatsoever.  The aroma is sweet and fruity with a definite medicinal flourish.  I guess 5% is relatively high for a stout, but on the first swallow I might guess this to be a higher gravity brew.  This drinks with a strong java roastiness but theres also a ethylene viscosity, while not as robust as a Baltic Porter, at least reminded me of one.  This is delicious, if not a bit thin for the body in the flavor.  (#2684, 2/4/2007)
Love this stout....not too over the top, but lots of roasted malt and dark chocolate here. Some good hops of course...as is to be expected w/ 3F.
a lot of chocolate and roasted malt, lots of hops.  tastes a LOT like storm king, carmel and some limited peanut flavor.

Black pour with dark tan head.  Aroma is a fine mix of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and a decent amount of hops.  Taste is a pleasant, almost creamy mix of chocolates, coffee, and dark roasted grains.  Hop flavor is very prominent - almost at the level of a Victory Storm King.  As with other 3Fs beers, they really push the boundaries of a style by adding a little extra - namely hop flavor - to styles not known for hoppiness (Gumballhead as a Wheat and Robert the Bruce as a Scottish Ale come to mind).  This wont please everyone, but I remain a big fan of everything 3 Floyds.  Black Sun is a winner!

You really have to chew the hell out of this beer to get any sort of complex malt character and even then, there is hardly a hint of goodness.  Its outrageously hoppy in both the aroma and flavor.  Its unbalanced for me, way too hoppy and i like hoppy beers.  Not enjoyable, but finishable.

Bomber coutesey of cbkschubert. Coffee, dry coco and sweet roasty aroma. Black body with dark tan head.. Had the quaity basic ingriants of a stout with the chocolate flavor, sweet malt and roasty malts. Noticed some bitterness which wasnt all bad but took away from some richness. Good brew.

draft at hopleaf. pours black with small creamy head. looks delicious. aroma is roasty with chocolate and mild piney hop aroma. flavor is extremely roasty with rather sweet chocolate notes. the roasted malts seem a little row and  not have melded together well or yet.  light carbination, mouthfeel is creamy smooth but finishes watery. that finishes very dry. i dont care much for this style, but if the roasted malts didnt seem so raw this would be killer.
22 oz bottle. Tan head on the edge with tiny bubbles. Chocolate hoppy nose and taste that finishes bitter. Creamy and full on the palate.

Bottle.  Poured like motor oil with a thin beige head.  Aroma is really hoppy. Lots of dark fruitiness (dates/fig), not balanced in the aroma department at all, but this beer is distinctly 3 Floyds.  Weird citrus highlights in this beer and a kind of chemical component that I cant put my finger on.   Not a hugely complex flavor - immediately its too thin - decent hops and bitterness, coffee, roasted malts.  Good, but not impressive.

Bottle poured black with a nice brown head and lacing.
Aroma and flavor of rich, roasty malts, chocolate and coffee.
Body is thick with a creamy texture and deep roasty finish.
I wish I could get more of this!

Interesting charcoal and wine aroma with some plums.  Fairly black and thin with a light brown pour.  Delish.  Lots of ink in the flavor, plums, roasted malts, and pleasant hoppiness.  Tastes like a British stout.  Thanks Timmy Immy!

Had this on nitro-tap on a recent visit to the brewery. Served in a pint glass.
Appears a very inviting black color with a quarter inch head. This beer looks declicious.
Smell is roasted malt and hops. Im not a hop-head and prefer my stouts on the non-hoppy side, but the nitro tap takes care of most of this. This beer is so creamy and smooth, its very, very good. Very good dark choco taste with a perfect amount of hops coming through in the taste. This is a very solid offering from FFF.
This is a great beer that I could drink for a very long time. The moderately low ABV makes this highly sessionable.
Im slowly becoming a very big fan of Three Floyds. Cant wait to try more of their stuff.

Draft at Three Foyds pub.  Rich toasted malts, full of cracker and burnt bread flavors.  Sits right in the center of the dry stout style, properly "dry" and almost chewy at the same time.  Light malted milk balls and toast.  Light chocolate.  Having this along side Alpha Klaus on draft didnt help, but overall its a tasty stout.

Thin dense head of brown creamy bubbles.  Minimal carbonation.  Nice roasty aroma with milk chocoalte, light hazelnut coffee and toasted biscuits.  Quite nice.  Color is a very dark brown boardering on black.  Creamy and smooth.  Lots of roasted grains with a nice hops kick mid swallow.  Finishes with lots of roasted coffee and a little malty sweetness.  Relatively light bodied for a stout.  Very well balanced and not overpowering in any certain aspect.  A very good stout.
Im getting the slight taste of chocolate and some coffee flavor. Mild sweetness. I could drink a good amount of it. I like. Is good.

Solid black body, smallish creamy chocolate brown head. Aromas of roasted coffee, dark chocolate and a remarkably strong presence of hops.

This beer is full bodied and bitter from both hoppiness and coffeeish malts. Silky smooth on the palate - this is a pleasantly bitter and flavorful dry stout.

22 oz bomber from Holdenn via trade (Thanks!!!)  A dry malts emanate from the aroma first, then come in the chocolate and caramel that linger around in the scent.  Coffee and roasted nuts round out the aroma.  Pours a jet black with a small sized tan head that is gone within a minute or so.  Taste is a creamy chocolate maltiness with caramel and  nuts punching through.  A light coffee texture lingers on through the aftertaste.  Palate is a little light, somewhat dry and medium to light bodied.  Overall,  This is a definitely sessionable stout. Very very nice stout!  Cheers!!!!

22 oz. Bottle: Pours jet black with a small tan head that diminishes quickly. Aroma is roasty with hints of chocolate and coffee. Flavor starts a with dark chocolate sweetness and finishes with a coffee bitterness. Body is rather thin and non lively which makes it very easy drinking. Delicious and enjoyable!
65cl bottle, Winnipeg (via Indiana). Jet black, dark beige head, thick pour. Musty chocolate aroma, thick malt, dark chocolate and coffee flavour. Decent stout.
Bottle.  Hickory smoke and dark chocolate aroma.  Dark black color with small head.  Smokey malt and hops flavor - notes of chocolate, burnt coffee and chalk as well.  Body was a bit watery.

Bottle.   Pours a dark brown almost black color, witha dense, medium sized, tan head.   Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, hops.   Flavor is chocolate, cream, coffee, malt, floral.   Palate is medium bodied, medium to high carbonation, sweet finish.   I loved this!!

Chocolate and hops stand out in the aromas.Pours pitch black with a medium tan head.Get lots of chocolate and coffee in the flavors.A little thin for a stout but not to bad.Get some hop bitterness in the finish.

750 ml. bottle. Jet black pour offers up a medium frothy brown head. Chocolate, coffee, dark fruits on the nose. Medium body and a clean mouthfeel for a stout. Rich coffee - chocolate flavor complemented by some peppery spice. Cry, but not overly bitter finish. An easy drinking flavorful stout.
Bottle.  Dark-black, with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  A little bit thin and dry.  Not horrible, but about average for me.  Not my favorite style.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2009 From the 22oz bottle. Black with a tan head. This stout had a nice roastiness, coffee and burnt chocolate taste. Body was lacking, very thin feeling and kinda watery and astringent in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2006 22 oz bottle via JCAPRIOTTI (thanks!). Pours a midnight black with a large tan head. Nose is pretty typical Imp Stout with mostly roasted chocolate and floral hops. Taste is very balanced with roasted chocolate, licorice, and citrusy hops.  Body is a bit thniner than expected. Very easy to drink and much more flavorful than other dry stouts i have had. I will say though that i do not care for so much hoppiness in a stout...

Very enjoyable, high quality.  The nose was rather on the hoppy side of stouts, but the overwhelming character was the dry, roasted, chocolate, of the kind you might have with a proper bitter, high cocoa chocolate.  Pitch black, rich and forecasting the thickness and excellent mouthfeel.  Quality stout.

Bottle: Dark black with light red hue, light head and tan lacing. Nose of staunch cenntenials and submissive smelling syruppy sappy dark molasses. Flavor is full of coffee, light cocoa and a semi-sweet mouthfeel, lots of hoppiness. Finishes a bit sweet and nice light astringency. Beautiful dry stout, lots of hops, not very dry though. Nice dry stout! wonderful. Thanks Ken!

Bottle pours a deep black with a thin tan tan head and traces of thin lacing.  Lots of dark roasted bitter hoppy aroma.  Tastes sharp, bitter and smokey.  Dry, yess.  Thin and strong.  Surprosed to find the ABV to be only 5.5%.   Dry and quick on the palate with a long lasting bitter bite.  Nice for a sub-style that is not favorite. Thanks again to OhioDad

22 oz. Bottle:Black with brown head.  Aromas of rubber, alcohol, and brake fluid.  The taste is barley, and a slight bitterness as well as a papery taste.  I think the only other dry stout I have had is Guiness and this is definitely 18 steps up from that one!  Thanks <Indiana_Red!

22 oz Bottle Pours out a Black topped with a tan head. A Great aroma of HOPS. Great floral and some bitter. Very nice.
Thanks Indiana_Red

Bottle. Pours very dark opaque ruby with a nice tan head. Now, as Im looking at this brew in my large glass here is the curiosity on my mind: what do I expect? I mean, Three Floyds is so unpredictable. Most of their brews are quirky, yet some of them are faithful representations of a particular style. For some reason Im thinking this is going to be a solidly executed, textbook dry stout. Nope. A sniff brings that signature Floyd hop assault to my nose. I grin with satisfaction. Amid the defined, rounded, zesty pine are notes of soy sauce, chocolate, walnuts. The flavor has a very good Irish stout character. Its drying in the finish, plenty of coffee to be found. A hint of meaty notes is detected. This could stand on its own as a solid dry stout, but Three Floyds deemed it necessary to hop the shit out of it. Well, my hat off to them for chosing to do that. It comes across like a charred forest with embers glowing in the damp earth. . .with coffee. Theyve created a solid, tasty, and simultaneously unique beverage. The finish brings out coconuts and more floral aspects which battle with a wash of creamy, drying bittersweetness.  Its not normal.

First of all, this is a mighty impressive pour.  Almost black, in an imperial fashion, with a large dark tan head.  Nice soapy bubbles too, lacing sticks around forever.  Aroma?  Oh hell yes, what a smell too.  Who would have thought this blackness would smell so strongly of fresh pungent and funky hops?  Anyway, aroma is hoppy, with a planty vegetable quality rather than any pine or citrus quality; also with some caramel and mocha/coffee tones.  Do I smell something vaguely cheesy too?  I think so.  Aroma is still detectable right after tasting too.  Flavor is chocolaty, with some burnt coffee tastes, and a slight acidity.  Hop flavor compliments the coffee pretty well.  Finishes caramelly, followed by roast, and some of that hop flavor that I detected in the aroma.  Hints of cigar smoke in the finish too.  Pretty thick for a regular stout, low carbonation.  One of the best non-imperial stouts Ive ever had.

22oz bottle (thanks to black95tt) poured black in color with a small brown head. Great hop aroma backed by chocolate, caramel, roast and some coffee notes. The taste had the perfect amount of bitterness with a nice malt profile to balance. A dry finish helped bring out alot of the roasted malts and left you wanting more. Overall one of the best stouts I have had and I put it up there with all the Bells Stouts.

Pours pure black with a sweet roasted hops aroma.  Had with a good cigar was was well paired.  Not as thick as one would think as dark as it poured.  Would consider this more of a sweet stout.  First mouth full came the roasted hops and malty with coffee and choclate afterthoughts.  A fine beer that I wish I could get more easily.  If you like a stout, this is a must try.  Very smooth with little aftertaste.  Well worth a having.

Horrid piney roasted nose. The hop character does not go well with style of beer. Smells like a burnt pine cone. Astringent malt has a big chewy mouthfeel. Hops are overly prominent from beginning to end, YUCK with a capital Y.

Poured a watery black from the bomber with a thin white head.  Little aroma, no hops, slightly roasted.  Initial flavor was nice, malty and roasted with coffee notes but extremely weak.  The flavor was too simple and faded quickly.  Reminder me more of a porter than a stout.  Unimpressive as far as micro-stouts go.

Pours a dark black with a nice tan head.  A very fruity aroma of sweet malt, spice, chocolate, and coffee.  Damn this stuff tastes good.  Piney and peppery with strong flavors of chocolate and coffee.  Smokey, fruity, caramel, and piney hops.  Thin, but thats the way this style is.  Easy to drink and complex.  I prefer thicker brews, but this is still very good.

Black with a slimming yet dense, lush tanned foam. Thin sheeting lace covers nearly every inch the head touches.

Sweet oily aroma of orange oils, pine tar, blackened stuff, and slight peppery spice.

Taste is round, big, and bold with a big jump of flavor on the buds with charred roasted malt tone mixed, almost balanced, but not quite, with a orangey pine oil. Slimming bite and bitterness. Semi tangy, mostly charred-like, peppy, lip smacking, smokey dryness really sticks it right on the palate and doesnt move from there. Finish is a mix of complex notions with blackened, charred, smokey, ashy things with a sliver of coffee and oily wood and orange.

Feel is sooo nice...quite big and everlasting in body. Richly set in lasting and well rounded big roasty/charred malts and tone with a semi plush tang underneath it. The hops really make for a unique experience as they add both an extra dimension of flavor and finish within the tone of charred malts. Theres an oily side to it that stays just to the back and around the sides, letting the blackened stuff stay up front and heavy on the tongue. Complex as hell; I tell ya what...

An exceptional stout. A mind over matter...of drinking the hell out of the bomber type of brew that exhumes itself from the depths of obscured stout sessioning. What the hell Im I talking about? Just drink it. Youll be impressed; and if youre not, more for me ...ya simpleton.

Bottle.  Pours inky black, with a thin beige head.  Aroma is of piney hops and coffee, chocolate, toffee.  Taste is more of the same, lots of coffee and chocolate and the pine hops are there as well.  Finish is slightly bitter and a coffee/tobacco taste lingers for a while.  A little thinner than I wouldve thought.  I dig these hoppy stouts.
Bottle. Black with a thin brown head. Very nice roasted and perfume aroma. Lightly sweet chalky roasted flavor with big hop flavor for the style. Pretty good though a bit sweet for the style.
Beautiful inly black with dark tan head to top it off.  Nose was like  coffee and chocolate.  Nice sweet roasty flavor with very slight bitterness on the finish, almost perfect.

Motor oil black with a beautiful tan head.  Elegant lacing on the edge of the cups.  The aroma reminds me of sipping coffee in the woods!  With the aroma showing signs of coffee and pine.  The palate shows the same...coffee and chocolate with a dry finish that lingers.

bomber.  Aroma:  Coffee, roasted malt, slight cocoa, and a good measure of pine and grapefruit.  Appearance:  Black and slightly oily looking.  Dark tan head was full and frothy.  Great lacing.  Flavor:  Medium-sweet roasted malts, chocolate, slight coffee.  Grapefruit and pine come on right before the finish.  Palate:Full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Finish was dry and a little chalky.  Overall:  3 Floyds does it again.  A dry stout with a load of hops added, but it all balances and tasted great.  Really good.

22 oz. bottle. This is my first brew from Three Floyds and I was not disappointed. Pours opaque black with a thick brown head. Moderate aroma of coffe, chocolate and hops. The flavor followed the aroma with chocolate and coffee noted with some hops bitterness as well. A bit hoppier than a typical stout, but by no means overdone like some beers. Dry finish. Very good.

Bottle from cbkschubert! Thanks Craig! Nose of coffee, chocolate, and a small bit of hops; very opaque brown with cherry fringes and some tan bubbles against the glass sides; flavor shows first some hop bitterness, then coffee and chocolate, more hops than most stouts!

Pours absolutely black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is a pleasant mix of centennial hops (or something similar) anise, chocolate and coffee. The flavor is nicely balanced, but still big. The body is lighter than some, but this is an excellent stout.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Styles.  Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, and some piney hops.  Pours a dark brown, with no transparency and a small beige head.  Flavor is loaded with coffee and contains moderate chocolate.  Mild piney hop finish really blends well.  A very nice stout.

bottle. black pour with enormous tan creamy head.  nice coffee, roasted malts and hoppy aroma.  coffee, hops, sour malts, slightly smoky flavor.  coffee dominant in a dry aftertaste.  Small bitterness. Good but I was expecting more.

Who put a hop bomb in my stout?  3F did you bastards!!!!! This is the black Alpha King.   Something about 3F makes me giddy.  I bet those 3 Jicky Jacks have fun making this beer, because I have fun drinking it.  I love burping 3 Floyds hop bombs for hours later.

Pours an opaque black with a brown head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy with notes of pine and grapefruit but the chocolate malts and coffee notes do come through with a great deal of dried fruits. The body is rather thick even for the style and the CO2 is low. The flavors are decidedly burnt with a lot of coffee and chocolate. I am really getting very little caramel character. The finish is hugely bitter and drying. Pretty awesome example of an American Stout.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 (Bottle at OT, Stockholm)  Pours black with brown reflexes. Hardly no head. Smells (burned) rubber and hops. Bitter cocoa. Roasted coffee and salty liquorice. The taste is smokey and pleasently sour. Minty icecream feeling. Dark chocolate. Rounds of with a coffee bitterness. Minerals and rust. A bit of creamy fudge. Burned malt. Clean taste. Roasted and dry, Duh...

Pours as black as old morot oil, and about as thick.  1" tan head.  Sweet chocolate aroma with a good fruity bitter aroma.  The first sip yields a sweet medium bodied beer with not as much bitterness as anticipated.  Overall a quite drinkable beer, glad I got the big bottle!
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bomber. Pours a thin head that expands creating a great looking beer. Very sweet aroma with chocolate undertones, mild malt and hop presence. First taste right from refrigeration taste like an iced coffee from dunkin donuts. After settling down the top of my beer formed a cobweb of foam creating a black hole that sucked me down. Great taste that goes well with chicken. Good mouthfeel that stays long after each sip. Great beer but pricey ofcourse. Cheers!

(Bottled, Oliver Twist, Stockholm, 10 Aug) Colour is black with dark brown edges, foamy beige head leaving a ring around the glass. Nose is roasted with coffee, dark chocolate and floral notes of hops shining through the dark. Taste is roasted with dark, bitter chocolate, notes of juniper berries and dark cherries. Fresh citrussy hop taste in a long, rather dry, finish. Light to medium body makes this a very drinkable stout despite loads of taste. Lovely!

The 22 ounce bottle poured a deep impenetrable black beverage with a small off-white creamy head that lasted throughout and left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was dominated by citrus in the form of grapefruit peelings, roasted coffee, and sherry.  This beer has a medium body, soft carbonation and a distinctly dry texture. The flavor starts off slightly sweet and tart with grapefruit and coffee playing well together. The finish is quite long and the sweetness fades into a nice dry bitterness.

[Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm] Black with beige, creamy head. Strong aroma of cofee and grapefruit. Dry, very aromatic and really roasty. Medium bodied with soft mouthfeel and tons of coffee flavour. Long salty grapefruity bitter finish. Packed with flavour, yet so drinkable. A superb stout!

Bottle.  Pours indeed black in color with a pleasant, compact, light brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves great lacing behind.  Aroma is roasty, just the slightest hints of smoke along with a hint of hop.  Medium bodied, carbonation level seems lower as the beer warms.  Definite 3F hopping levels are noticed towards the finish.  Roasty grains are present more towards the front end of things.  Pleasant, certainly worth trying.  Interesting twist on a "normal" dry stout.

Black bodied, medium sized mocha head, ok lacing.  Hoppy aroma, with maybe a little roasty malt too.  As dark as it was, I was expecting a more intense flavor.  Ended up just being a normal dry stout with some extra hops as is typical of 3F.

The BIF 30 package from BA orbitalr0x included this 22 oz. bomber, and I am finally getting around to it.  When poured into the pint glass, this looked as black as any beer Ive ever seen, with a mocha colored foamy head.  When holding up against strong back light, the body did not let a single photon pass through, so the color remained jet black.  The aroma was a bit too timid for a beer that had such good looks.  All I could detect was a distant coffee and burnt grain notes riding atop light alcohol fumes.  The taste was very smoky with the coffee, toffee, and chocolate flavors being most prominent, followed by dense and citric hop bitterness.  The finish was roasty and burnt, and aftertaste swung back into hoppy flavor again.  The body was not overly thick to begin with, and the creaminess imparted by the carbonation made it feel even less so.  It was a pretty easy task to get this bomber down.

A pretty dissapointing stout to be sure. The Black Sun Stout pours, um, black of course, and has a thin tan head. The aroma reminds me of green tea with some citrus notes. The taste is very hoppy for a stout. The mouthfeel is thin as well. This stout just doesnt offer much to talk about. Definitely not worth the price."

22oz Bomber from the Foodery in Philly.  Pours like liquid obsidian with a medium sized tan head.  Sweet aroma of toffee, vanilla, roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate and alcohol.  Well balanced flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, aging fruit, coffee and alcohol.  This stout has a nice (and surprising) hoppy finish given the lack of hops in the aroma.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin but still silky and the finish is sweet, moderately long and very satisfying.  Another well crafted brew from these guys.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2006 Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Black with a low, light brown head. Smooth floral and peachy hop aroma with a light roasted undertone. Flavour starts smooth of flowers, gently roasted malts, caramel and mocca before strong notes of bitter coffee and orange-peels sets in and devolopes in the long aftertaste. Really nice stout.

Bomber.  Pours thin dark black.  More like cola that oil.  The aroma was coffee and chocolate and massively floral.  Smelled like I had just walked into a florist.  Dont drink this one too cold.  Let it warm up.  If its too cold its tinny and a little bitter.  After it warms all of the choco-coffee stoutness will be there.  Nice one.

Aroma is tons of American hops, but just a bit of roasted malt... or anything else really. Appearance is something of a let down- thin thin head atop a watery looking black body. Flavor is hard to pin down- it starts off like Alpha King mixed with a normal stout... not so tasty. As it warms, the stout character comes out a bit more, but the hops still stay there in the finish. This creates a sort of skanky taste. Finally, this is possibly the lightest bodied stout Ive ever had from a Microbrewery. Not 3Fs best beer... but that didnt stop them from charging $11 for a bomber.

Bomber. Slight coffee notes with  alittle roasted malt. Pours dark however with a small creamish head. Thin mouthfeel but was still pleasing to the palate. I had started sampling this when it was a little cold, once it began to warm it got much better!

Points for appearance. A nice, carbonated pour that is near black with a thick brown head.  Aroma is a cross between roasted chocolate malts and citrus hops.  First impression upon tasting is... wow! Very lively mouthfeel with some nice chocolate notes.  Again, the citrus hops lead into the middle and finish.  Roasted malts.  Too thin for me, however... Pretty good for a surpsingly low rated style???  I need to get out more.

This one was almost disappointing after Alpha Klaus.  But it is still a fine beer.  0 head, black in color.  Chocolate and coffee aroma + hops.  Oily, thick chewy palate.  Has backbone along with roasted background.

22 oz via trade with OhioDad and Slob (both sent a bottle, too cool) - Pours black with a nice tan head.  Light spotty lacing.  Has a light roasted, chocolate malt aroma.  Roasted chocolate and light coffee dominates the flavor.  Has a smooth dry finish.   Medium body.  A very good beer.  Thanks Scott and Bert.

Bottle: Pitch black in color, large frothy light brown head, minor lacing.   Huge hop and piney aroma, roasted malts take a back seat it seems.   Clean roasted malt flavor, semi-sweet, slight lactose, with lingering hop and pine notes.   Body and mouthfeel are surprisingly moderate.   Lingering coffee and pine aspects.   Solid for the most part, and very quaffable.   Thanks to Captaincougar and pineypower for each sending a bottle!
Big bottle.  Weak mouthfeel.  Some malty flavors in there.  Overall, it cant walk the walk because it smells like nothing.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a fat brown tan head. Hops jump out in the nose first, then a little chocolate sneaks past the pine. Im thinking thin chocolate IPA with a peanut butter flavor. A bit of roast coffee in the finish with some more pine. Drinkable, with a few enjoyable points, but not something I will buy again. The hops hide what I like in a stout here, the roast sweet malt profile is just obliterated by the bitterness.
Ap-5 ar-5 tas-3 pal-2 ov-8

22oz bomber.Pours a light-crushing dark black with khaki-colored head that leaves spots of lace here and there. Aroma of pine, chocolate, coffee, roasted grain and a hint of vanilla. Prominent piney hop and bitter roast grain sets the tone for the flavor, and the two elements clash a bit. A bit of chocolate shows up later as does a lightly spicy hop bitterness. (More chocolate would have made this an absolutely killer beer...)  Big thick slightly viscous palate. This is exactly what Id expect a stout made by Three Floyds to taste like, for better or worse.

Bottle. from trade with JCW (I think) Ok nose, bittersweet, baking chocolate, malt balls, little egg (Not sulphur), cardboard, seltzer. Tad of evergreeen when cold that faded as warmed. Black color, brownish arond the edges. Small head with ok lacing. Bitter roasty flavor, like aroma with  tinniness and/or grapefruit added. Medium body, lite creamy smooth mouthfeel, dry chaulky finish. tasty! definately hits the mark in dryness. Maybe too bitter for some, but not for me.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Smells like paint.  Like a freshly painted apartment.  I can almost see the paintroller and the cheap paint tray on the floor of an empty room.  Black color.  I dont much car for the angry lookin sun on the label.  Faint fizzy at first but it slips away quickly.  It has an oily hoppyness towards the end.

Bottled @ Sk8vikings blind porter/stout tasting. Beer no. 18: Pitch black. Dense brown head. Pine, herbs, roast and a light balancing sweetness in the aroma. Flavour is light fruity, has pine notes, is sweet and has cocoa and  some light roast notes. Is quite smooth and balanced. Has a dry bitterness in the end. Nice hoppy dry stout, that is very drinkable.

(bottle) Deep black, not as oily as an imperial stout, small dark tan heads that fades quickly. Nice lace. Aroma is roast coffee and hops. Flavor is bitter, burnt coffee and unsweetened chocolate. Hops more prominent than an Irish dry stout.

Geez, another whiff by 3F tonite (Boru the other). Poured a pitch black (some mahoganey edges) with a nice chocolate colored generous head that laced quite well. The aroma was messed up for a dry stout: hops all over the place (grapefruits and piney notes) and some smoke. The flavor was dry roasted malts with hops over the top (again, grapefruits and pine). Boy, do I want a Guinness right about now, as 3Floyds just killed the style with this one. Ok, the mouthfeel wasnt bad, they hit the style there and kep the gravity fairly low (but this smoke.... too much roastedness for a dry stout).

Overpowering hop aroma, which follows into a hoppy flavor.  Sticky sweet, juicy hop flavor.  Too bold to be just citrus.  Comes off more like tropical fruit.  Then, in the back, it is a roasty, dry stout.  A bit thin, and with notes of molasses and roasted nuts.  Almost no bitterness, despite the huge hop presence.  The combination of hops and dry malt just doesnt work for me.  Its like two different beers mixed together, clashing.

Bottle.  Very dark pour with a small tan head.  Taste is roasted and malty with a nice hoppy kick.  Very light and easy to drink for a stout.  Cant hold up to an imperial stout by any means, but it does very nice for the style.  I would drink this all the time if I didnt have to drive to Virginia to buy it.

Tasted blind at Sk8vikings amazing Porter/Stout tasting - Black body, light brown head, some laces; IPA like nose (if I was blind I would guess this to be an IIPA). Pine, sweet flowers, far behind it soft coffee, soft chocolate and soft licorice; Very soft velvet like body with balance and a little bitterness; Into medium long bitter, dry, flowery, hoppy finish with complexity, depth and everything, the only thing it lacks is a bit of balance within each elements and between nose, body and finish.
Bottle. Pitch black colour with a nice head. Hoppy aroma with notes of roastedness and citrus. Very tasty flavour of hops, roastedness and coffee. Ends up very nice and easy to drink.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours black with a large cola colored head. Aroma of roast, hops, and citrus. Flavor is citsy, roast, and hops. Very enjoyable brew.

Deep dark blackness like an overused metaphor involving a troubled soul. Opaqueness breaks only at the very bottom of the glass, only when held against a lamp. Sorry--I got tough standards when it comes to stout pours. No five for you!

The scent, however, is stout dry stout perfection. HOPS. Roasted malt. Dear god this is bittersweet tastiness all perfectly cooked and melted down. 

Taste transfers over. Yummy yum yum. Big warm hops welcome you in, very dry, backed up by almost-as-strong dry, roasted bitter stout malts. These give way to a very smoky middle, but its a unique smoke. Not meaty or chessy. It tastes like stout grains being smoked. Wonderful. All this ends on an inexplicably sweet malt finish.

This is one of my very favorite beers. Grab this if you can find it. It makes life worth living.
Bottle. Black colour with a brown head. Dry dusty chocolate, coffee aroma and a light dry roasted, coffee taste. Medium body with a very dry finish.
Saw this the other day at the store and decided I needed to have it.  Beautiful pour and auroma.  robust flavor with a hint of coffee to it.  Nat a bad beer at all.

Thanks to px2grafx. Black pour with a small tan head, decent to blah lacing. Aroma is all the dark stuff.. roast, coffee and chocolate with caramel too. Also a hop presence here too... grapefruity maybe? Loads of fruit with chocolate and caramel in the finish. The roast is bitter just like the Alpha Klaus. This beer really grew on me as I finished the bottle. At first it was good, but it kept getting better. The flavor started off at about a 6 and ended at an 8, so I chose 7. I really liked the mouthfeel and lingering finish.

(Blind rating at sk8vikings.) Pours black. Smells of amarillo (I think?) - nice. Mild sourness. Very hoppy, otherwise rather mellow aromas of caramel and coffee. Nice with the amarillo (?) but it´s not quite mixable with the burnt malt aromas in this stout. Low carbonation. Would have enjoyed this hops profile more in an IPA.

Bottle.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Roasted aroma of hops and pine needles.
Roasted flavour of hops, grape fruits and pine needles.
A pitch black beer with a brown head. The aroma is very hoppy combined with light notes of malt. The flavor is sweet and dominated by roasted malt, but also with light notes of wood.

(Bottle 65 cl) Pours completely black and opaque with a small, beige head. Quite a refined aroma of fruity aroma hops. Fairly good body with lightly sweet, hard roasted malt. Pleasant and complex malt composition with notes of chocolate. Some lovely, lightly citrusy hops create a balance close to perfection. 030606

Thick and dark with inviting tan head. Strong aroma of citrusy hops  grapefruit, orange and lemon  and sweet chocolate with notes of coffee bean. The flavor is dominated by the hops   the orange, grapefruit and bitterness. Your taste buds have to work a little harder to get at the undercurrent of sweet malts, but its there. Caramel, chocolate and vanilla. The thin to medium body is well carbonated and the mouthfeel is juicier than other dry stouts I have had. Clean throughout with a lingering taste of citrus. Heck, if dAchouffe can throw citrusy hops at a tripel, why cant 3F hop up a dry stout? The combination of IPA and tripel works better for me. Still, Black Sun is unique and enjoyable though there is something disjointed about the bittering hops dominating the sweet chocolate.

Deep black with a small tan head.  The aroma is loads of pine and floral hops (about time the Floyds started throwing some hops in their beers :-).  Flavor is big with roasted coffee malts, smoke and molasses.  Rounded out by a dry, piney, fruity hops finish.  Nice medium body with carbonation thats nice but not too intrusive.  Very good if you enjoy the Floyds heavily hopped style.

Bought in Blacksburg, VA. Bomber. Beer was a nearly opaque, dark brown-black color with an average-sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing head. This brew was terribly lovely, something to really sink your choppers into. Malty with moderate notes of cookie, caramel, chocolate and coffee, heavy notes of roasted grain; hoppy with moderate-to-heavy notes of herb, apricot, resin/pine; light yeast notes of cobwebs and dough; Light miscellaneous notes of vanilla and moderate notes of alcohol. The flavor was moderately sweet, lightly acidic and heavily bitter with a long, lightly sweet, lightly acidic/tangy, moderately bitter finish. The body was light-to-medium, the texture was watery and the carbonation was fizzy. I want to get my mits on more of this brew.

Very dark, near black.  Medium crema-colored rocky head, recedes with nice lacing.  Aromas of floral hops, malt, citrus, metal, and alcohol.  Big roasted malt flavor, with earth, peat, smoke, charcoal, molasses, coffee and dark chocolate with a solid bitter citrus hop finish.  Slightly thicker than average but the used motor oil consistency of some stouts.

Bottle (bomber).

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate), moderately to heavily hoppy (apricot, resin), with notes of vanilla and alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

A black IPA, you might say.  Ehhh.  Very hoppy, with an abrasive, sour flavor balance.  Seemed hotter than it is.  Not enjoyable.

Pours quite dark for a light stout. Nice frothy head with a cola like look to the beer. Aroma is very hoppy, with a little dark malt coming through. Taste is dry and chocolaty with some floral hoppy flavors/bitterness showing up at the end. Viscosity wasnt as high as I would like for stout. I wasnt extremely impressed, but this isnt my preferred style.
Pours black with nice head.  Aroma of HOPS and sweet malts.  Flavor is of bitter chocolate and smoke with a bittrer hop finish.  Nice mouthfeel.  Thicker than expected.  Great Stout!

From Bottle.  Cola-like pour, dark, dark and more dark.  Brown, frothy head.  Cola like look, I could see the carbonation bubbles.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and fruit.  Flavor of roasted coffee, chocolate in the middle, and nice fruity, and hop flavors in the finish.  Fruity flavors and hop flavors more present as it warms. No bitterness.  Full bodied.

(22 oz bottle via trade with <!-- A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank -->kramer17801<!-- /A -->, thanks Jason!) Pours a very, very dark garnet-tinged brown with about 1 1/2" of tan head. Aroma is very strong raw hops with more bitter coffee and some chocolate fighting through as head recedes. Weepy rings of lace. Mouthfeel fairly smooth, a bit oily, a tad thinnish. Flavor is rich strong bitter coffee with some chocolate as well. Has quite a grassy finish along with the hops that were strong in the nose. A little messy, was kind of expecting better.

Thanks to Ohio dad for this.  Pours ebony with 1-finger brown head.  The aroma is huge piney hops, roasty dark patent malt, chocoff, and some spices.  The aroma reminds me a lot of the Alpha Klaus aroma.  The taste is roasty malty up front, with big piney hops, jalapeno oils, and chocoff at mid-palate.  The dryness takes hold as it warms, giving an increase to the java and piney spice elements.  The palate is on the dense side, very complex, and very smooth.  It was all I could do not to chug a pint of this with y cold cuts and swiss cheese.  Another world class beer from Floydx3.  If I see a case of this, I will buy a case of this.  Its as simple as that.

I was thinking about this as I logged in.  I was going to say something along the lines of "Dry and surprisingly light-bodied." but the  commercial desciption beat me to it.  Lots and lots of floral/herbal hops on the nose.  Good beer, but I would have prefered a wee bit more malt and viscosity.
(22oz. bottle)  Pours a oily opaque black body with an average creamy light brown head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, grapefruit, and vanilla.  Nice balance of roasted malt and hops in the flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark with a thick tan head. Beautiful aroma of floral hops,  roasted malts, citrus, and sweetness. Flavor is smooth, slight hop bitterness, citrus, roast. A little weak for a stout, but it has a nice dry finish.
Pours black, with a light brown head. Aromas are hops, roasted malt, and coffee. flavors are hops, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Body is rather thin. thanks to footbalm for this bottle.

Very enjoyable 22oz bottle. Pours very dark, one of the darkest ive seen with tan/light brown head. It has a smooth mocha aroma with a little bit of a sweet scent. Coffe flavor with some bitter chocolate and a little taste of hops at the end of the drink. My favorite stout so far. Very good!

Pours black with a medium tan head that fades. Aroma is of rounded roast, sweet chocolate, mild coffee, toasty biscuity malt with light fruity, citrusy, mildly herbal hops standing up admirably to the rich malt fumes. Flavor is of a nice blend of roast, bitter coffee, sweet chocolate, fruity slighly herbal hops. It has some fleeting sweet moments but is solidly bitter overall.  Body is medium, palate is a slight slight bit oily, and finishes a slight bit watery. Great beer overall, only small nitpicks would be the a bit to much bitter roast/coffee and a slight watering down of the palate and flavor in the finish. I love burping up hops and roast in the same belch its excellently confusing.

Pitch dark black, like tar beneath an average off white head.  Coffee, licorice, and some dark fruits is what I get when I put my schnozzle towards the rim.  A little light in flavor, but then again its hard to expect more from a dry stout.  One of the best Ive tasted in this style.  This kicks the crap out of Guinness and Murphys.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 ultra black body with a nice dark brown head.chocolate,molasses,and rasoted malts in the aroma.powdered cocoa,chocolate,mocha coffee,and roasted malts in the flavor.nice medium mouthfeel and an excellent long lasting palate.(ONE YEAR OLD BOTTLE CONSUMED ON 1/9/08)still has a nice dark brown head.some oxidation has set in for sure.flavor seems a bit less complex than i remember.mouthfeel has thnned out a little as well.

Bottle. Fruity, sweet, rich, hoppy aroma; somewhat like fruit loops with hops. Almost opaque body; some red hues on the edges. Tan head; excellent lace. Tastes pretty much like it smells. A little chalky. Milky, somewhat creamy, lactose. Somewhat dry. Good hop profile. Needs more alcohol. Maybe a shot of everclear.

Thanks to CaptainCougar for getting this one for me.

A creamy black head tops this black bodied brew.
Coffee and chocolate dominate the aroma.
Hops remain in the background with a strong presence, but the roast malts play the loud notes here. Smooth and creamy with a long bitter finish.

Strong orange-citrus, resiny pine hops in the nose are joined by plenty of chocolate and roasty character.  Opaque black body is topped by a shy tan head that recedes rapidly to ring.  Thick malty caramel and chocolate up front are joined quickly by the juicy citrus hops, leading through to a crescendo of roasty bitterness.  Rich medium body with lively effervescence.  A symphony of flavours with the signature full hopping one would expect from Three Floyds.  Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, cathschlag, MartinT, Rastacouere, Olivier_MTL, Siroy and Yowie.

Pour was a dark brown (almost black) with a small brown head. Aroma was hoppy, with some roasted malt and coffee making their way through. Flavor was sweet malts, coffee, and licorice.  The finish was a bitter dry hoppiness.

22oz. bottle.  Opaque brown-black with a small dark tan head.  Cocoa powder, muted roastiness, and tinges of herbal hops in the aroma.  Caramel and mild chocolate flavors with a slight hoppy undertone.  Finish is coffeebean astringency and roasty bitterness.  Mouthfeel is a full medium, rather dry.

Bottle. Poured a black color with a frothy tan head that mostly lasted. Roasty aroma with chocolate and some light hops. The flavor found coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. I found a slight bitterness to it. Excellent! Thanks to Springslicker for sharing this at the Tennessee Tasting!
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. It has a smooth mocha aroma with some lactose notes. The flavor is cold coffee with some bitter chocolate and just a bit of hops in the finish. Yum.
Black, as one might expect. Really nice coffee aroma, with some hints of dark chocolate. Huge coffee flavor, too. Nice hoppy finish, extremely quaffable. Thanks to Springslicker for sharing!

Bomber. Jet black with a thick, creamy brown head. Nose has the typical 3F hops, plus a deep, roasty malt and coffee aroma. Some chocolatey notes as it warms. Body is really interesting - light, but full. I dont even know if that makes sense, but it fits. Flavors of sweet malt, caramel/toffee and coffee prevade, with some cocoa and burnt flavors underneath. Finish is dry and bitter. Really complex, really pleasant!

Another fine stout from Three Floyds.  While not up to the standards of Dark Lord, this is nonetheless impressive.  Jet black body capped off by a small, frothy brown head.  Bitter-sweet chocolate and coffee first hit the nose joined by (oh, what a surprise!) hops.  The aroma and flavor hold notes of brown sugar and malt.  Full bodied, gentle carbonation but more than I like in a stout, good mouthfeel.  A very enjoyable drink.  Especially with the brewpubs chocolate dessert.
a solid dry stout.  rich and creamy, not the typical overhopped three floyd brew.

This stout is delicous from the first sip. That being said, I am generally not into Impy Stouts, so this fits my palate a little better. Smooth rounded roasted malts with coffee, dark chocolate, and cocoa powder at the forefront. Caramel sugars and dry hops are noticable after the palate is saturated.  This beer is surprisingly light bodied and the sweetness is kept well in check. I have yet to meet a Three Floyds beer that I didnt enjoy.

Thanks to OhioDad for another brew.  Aroma is coffee, hops, chocolate, and pine.  Northwest hops type aroma.  Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, hops, espresso, with a hint of smoke.  Pretty damn awesome, another great 3F brew.

Bottle.  Exceptionally dark brown with minimal head that rides the edge of the glass, but provides almost no lacing.  The smell is a beautiful mix of very dry smokey malt and floral hoppiness.  Sweet is the first thing I think as I take a sip, dried fruits, citrus, and hops before a charcoal finish that mingles with the sweetness to provide a unique and pleasant aftertaste.  A nice smoothness accompanies the pleasant flavors and makes this quite enjoyable.
Black as night stout. very good malt hop balance.  Good chocolate undertones.  very enjoyable.  The few ThreeFloyds Ive tried have all been very good.

For my 500th rating I celebrated by journeying to Dayton to visit Belmont Party supply.  I
had to go there to secure a special brew to commemorate the landmark rating:  Three
Floyds Black Sun Stout.  To be perfectly honest, I originally wanted to rate the Dark Lord
for my 500th, but since they didnt have it, the Black Sun would have to be substituted.  I
guess Ill have to reserve the Dark Lord for rating 666.  Im proud to say that not only did
I leave the store with the Black Sun, but I liberated an additional 85 bottles, and a growler
to be sampled at a later time.  OK back to the Black Sun.  As usual from this master
brewer, the spicy nose is heavy on grapefruit; just the way I like it.  In addition, notes of
flowers and brown sugar abound.  Usually when rating, we speak of a brews complexity
as it relates to taste.  This brew might have the most complex nose Ive encountered to
date.  The brew pours black.  The sweet casual cascade meanders slowly into a fluffy
rocky brown head that leaves hunks of lace on my glass.  The retention is fair.  Espresso,
lots and lots of espresso.  The brew has a roasted, acidic and mighty mighty bitter taste
with tons of character - then again, what else would you expect from the Floyds Three? 
The finish is perfect bittersweet, perfect.  Espresso and beer, the best of both worlds.  The
thick, chewy and soft palate is like music to my mouth.  What a rewarding experience.

Bottle.  Now this is what a stout should be - dark as night, Thick, creamy and yummy.  True malty goodness.A little sweet...a little coffee...a little chocolate...a little hops and lots of malt.  Very, very tasty.

Not quite your standard dry stout though the pour wouldnt make you believe that.  Dark black pour with nice brown foamy head. Nose is where the surprise comes in with a lot bigger hop than you would expect (if you didnt know it was a Floyds brew anyways)  Flavor is potent chocolate, with the hops still doing thier thing, bits of coffee come into effect too.  Pretty sweet, and pretty tasty overall.

Pours a jet black color with a thin light brown head. Strong aroma of hops with roasted malt and chocolate. The flavor is bitter and sweet with an effective roasted and chocolatey malt and hops. The body has a medium thickness with a dry mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Very interesting.

Bottle.  Dark black pour, decent head.  Roasty chcocolate aroma laced with citrus hops.  Sweet roasty malt flavors, with defninite chocolate and notes of coffee, again with more citrus hops.  Decent body for a stout.  The hops blend well with the malt profile - this could be one of the best session stouts Ive had.  Very nice.

Pours a dark black color with a thin brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate, caramel, coffee, roasted malts, and a strong hop smell.  A little surprised about the hop aroma but it blends together nicely.  Flavor starts off sweet with roasted malts, chocolate and a hint of coffee.  Finishes with hops that blend well with the sweet, malty flavor.  Taste lingers for a while but the sweet, roasted malts compliment  the hops better then I expected.  Very delicious.

Got  a few of these in trades, thanks guys. Black pour with brown head, small and creamy. Big hop nose, surprise? from 3 FFFs.  Well, a very distinctive taste here. Roasted malts, yes, some coffee and  a touch of chocolate, bit a complimentary hops not over the top. Very smooth drink and nice dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2006 650ml. Pours oil black with nice diminishing brown head. Aroma of wet coffee grounds and dark roasted malt. Very heavy roasted and burnt flavors with a pleasant spicy hop profile. Full bodied and lightly fizzy mouthfeel. Finish is a blend of coffee and caramel, with a slight hint of pine. I am very particular about dry stouts and I tend not to like many, but this was good. Maybe too hoppy for some, bu tnot for me. Another good offering from one of my favorite american breweries.

Huge thumbs up to atpayne for hooking me up.  Bottle.  Aroma mainly hops piney and citric with a espresso mixed in.  Poured nice black with a huge creamy chocolate head.  Flavor was definitely interesting heavily hopped with a nice bit espresso and tinge of caramel.  Palate was nice also not too thick so it matched the flavors nicely the hops definitely dance on your buds before the coffee tones knock them out.  Overall I found this to be damn tasty!!

22 oz bottle.  Black pour with the slightest tinges of chestnut at the edges.  Creamy one inch dark brown head that left nice lacing.  Nose is heavy roasted malt and espresso with a nice hoppiness unusual for a dry stout.  Flavor is very dry and roasty with a high hopping level.  Aspects of coffee, burnt fruits, and caramel with an astringent burnt finish.  Mouthfeel is pretty full-bodied for a Dry Stout, with an oily texture.  Carbonation is a little fizzy but not to excess.  A nice take on a usually boring and unimpressive style.

Poured a very dark brown color with a small tan  head and brown oily film on the glass.  Roasted malt aroma had a good amount of coffee and a large amount of piney hops.  The flavor consisted of chocolate and coffee with more piney hop.  Finishes a little thin.  Medium bodied.
Oh my I love me some three floyds. First came across this brewery about a year ago and have yet to be disappointed. This one has a smokey and somewhat piney scent, and a powerful finish.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2007 Rerate22oz bottle, though I cant remember if this is my Dec. 05 or 07 bottle that I picked up at the brewery.  Cracking the bottle I still get a lot of piney hops, so lets go with the 07.  Black with just a smidge of ruby on the edges and a small tan head.  Aroma of piney hops, roasted malts, a hint of ash, anise, and light toffee.  Flavor is piney and roasty up front with moderate piney sweetness and caramel sweetness (the hops and malts meld thatwell).  Roasty ashy bitter finish.    Carbonation is almost nil, though the body is still smooth.  I could drink quite a bit of this stuff, though its too damn expensive--my problem with most 3F brews--though this isnt strong enough to warrant the high price tag like their other brews.  Old rating follows.22oz. bomber, no date.  Pours a dark brown with a mod-sized tan head.  Aroma of 3Fs hops, consisting of pine and grapefruit and grass--not that thats a bad thing.  Can also pick up some coffee and bitter chocolate.  Seems to be almost too hoppy for a stout--not true to style, but still good.  The hops pretty take over the whole taste until the finish, which is dry, as expected.  Pretty good, reminds me of Alpha Klaus, though not as in-your-face.  8-4-8-3-13--3.6
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Not my style of stout.  Hops out of balance, body is thin.  Flavor is dry and roasted -just not round or lively.  Adding some caramel woud really help here.

Bomber bottle, enjoyed on <font color=green>St. Pats Day.</font> Ah, Floyds usual big grassy fresh hops smell is the first thing I get when I pop er open. Deep black body in my shaker glass, with a half inch of brown foam the dwindles to a ring of lace. Now theres a roasty coffee aroma, with a bit of cocoa. Taste is very stoutish: dry, and roasty-astringent. Goes a little overboard for me, without a balancing smoothneess. Very nice, but $8 a bottle? Im not sure.

Ok, so can 3F make a beer that isnt loaded with beautiful citrusy hops?  I mean come on, this stout pours deep brown with a mocha head and screams stout from the get go.  I give the glass a slight swirl and the hops just punch you in the nose.  Orange, grapefuit, mango are combined with lesser notes of grass and lemon.  The strong hop presence actually makes that nice malt profile hard to notice in the aroma.  The hops continue in the body, almost acting out of balance with the nice, roasty profile.   More citrus, more perfume and more floral notes cover the nice mocha body.  Maybe some time would help mellow this, but as is it seems out of whack for me.  Of course, I love 3F hops, so I cant rate this too low.  Give me Alpha Klaus everyday and thrice on Sunday over this.

Bottle shared with tupalev, jerc, blankboy & HogTownHarry - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Deep brown colour with a quick tan head. Aroma - holy crap, those are some HUGE hops off the top, didnt expect that! Good notes of roast and coffee lurking behind. The body is thinner than I expected, a bit disappointing, but the flavour makes up for it - a great combination of coffee, hops, roast malt and smoke. Mmmmm.

Light beige head covers the very deep brown colored body. Strong malt-strangling hops come across very piney, green, foresty and playing around the chocolate powdered malts. Hop focused Three Floyds without the greatness of Alpha Klaus, but packing as much dry-hopping as legitimacy allows in a really drinkable, low-gravity stout. Miraculously avoids astringency. Supporting malt is supple, not really flavour contributing at all besides the roastiness, but at least keeping things in order and perspective. Obviously not designed for me, but doing what Three Floyds are renowned for and as clean as it gets. Do you like American hops or not?

Any first impressions?
-A faint ring haloes the opaque blackness.
-Intricate roastiness and silky vanilla zigzag around the portentous citrusy hoppiness.
-Multifarious citrusy hops blend admirably with the chocolatey sweetness and roasty firmness.
-A luscious mouthfeel for the style remains drinkable while exposing its malty wealth.

What if you dig deeper?
-Finishes with a calculated dose of malt roastiness and hop bitterness.
-The dark chocolate continues into the finish to make sure youre not taken advantage of.
-Very intense, but somehow near equilibrium in that intensity; there is enough malt to back up all the hops.
-Stunningly cohesive and very flavorful, while never going overboard. Another 3Floyds success in my book.

Bottle; no date.

Thanks to JPDIPSO for trading. Pitch black. Modest, creamy, khaki carbonation. Smells like poison. Burnt licorice and grapefruit, roasty malt, and a touch of smoke. Flavors are big, resinous, citrus hops up front followed by bittersweet chocolate and licorice and burnt malt. Everything crams together for one hell of an aftertaste. Medium body, just to the smoother side of balanced. Oily afterpalate. One of the hoppiest dark brews Ive had, well done.

Totally opaque balck color with small light tan head. Aroma has lots of coffee, cream, tar, slightly tart. Flavor has lots of coffee, touch of malt, bit of roastyness and ash. Very smooth finish, a touch of sweetness. Nice overall, though not as roasty as some stouts.

Is this a rich, dark, malt-laden IPA... or is this a stout for hopheads? Call it what you will, the hop/malt ratio is definitely off-kilter for a "dry stout". So, refrain from "rating to style" and enjoy this for what it is... whatever it is.
Pours black with blood-red highlights. A creamy, tan head settles slowly and laces nicely before resting in an oily film. Aroma finds an immediate onslaught of pine, which is eventually found to cover deep, roasted coffee, an undertow of chocolate syrup and a chemical-dash of "new car smell". A buttery/savory palate makes my mouth water while it discovers the flavors of Hersheys Special Dark Chocolate complemented with twangy citrus notes. Sweetness and piney hops intensify independently as the beer warms and make me wish I would have shared the bomber as the last ounces are hard to swallow.What this is, I decide, is simply another tasty, hopped-up offering from the notorious Brothers Floyd. With the intense hop signature they apply to virtually every beer, some have called them a "one trick pony". That may be, but if you like the pony, youll keep riding it. Or... insert a better analogy about ponies.
