650 ml bottle from Sams Wines & Spirits, Chicago (December 2005).  Cellar temperature service in a Sam Smiths pint glass.  Pretty near impenetrable blackness in the glass, topped by a slow-fading moderate dark tan head leaving faint lacing....dark chocolate and coffee not surprisingly dominate the nose, but a pungent hoppiness is present in spades as well....overall, its not terribly overt, surprising from this brewer....lightly sweet front, lots of dry roasted malts throughout, burnt brown sugar barely softens the strong bitterness equally contributed by the roast espresso and woody hoppiness....some sharp, pine-needle character towards the finish and a touch of acrid smoke and shy dry herbs (tarragon, thyme)....quite full body, carbonation level a bit high.  If the nose were more expressive this might be great, as it is somewhat disappointing from this brewer though still excellent compared to most.  Aftertaste just keeps on going....

22oz bottle, 2nd beer of brew day at Book_M_Danos house.  Very dark and opaque but not particles.  Light off whit-brown head.  Light lacing.  Light spicy (grassy) hop aroma.  Thats about it.  Not a bad aroma, just solid hoppy spice.  FlavorNice and dry. Spicy hops. Roasted and burnt malts in the taste and relatively balanced for 3Fs.  Very-very-very light sweetness but you have to look for it.  Dryish mouth feel.  Not a bad stout, and dry is definitely the word for this one.
Black Color with small brown head. Aroma is chocolate/hopps. Taste is the same chocolate and hopps. With a nice after taste of coffee and chocolate.
Black color with a small brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, hints of caramel, and some light hops. Chocolate and hops flavor.

Pours black with a small brown head. Roasted malt aroma with some caramel and chocolate. Some candy sugar too. Sweet caramel sweetness shifting to a very dry roasted malt, coffee nut bitterness with a great coffee finish. Light dry body.

Bomber.  Different label than that in the picture.  A pitch-black pour with a smallish mocha head.  The resiny aroma of a Balsam fir with just the slightest hint of vanilla beans and sour berries.  Thin to medium-bodied, though smooth and creamy.  A soft, malty base with lots of resiny hops at the end.  One of the hoppiest stouts Ive ever had.  Some dry and bitter coffee/dark chocolate in the finish.  Just a touch of sour berries throughout along with a bit of roastiness.  Good stuff.

pitch black body topped by a medium frothy tan head. the aroma is packed with hops. your fathers dry stout this is not. reminds me a good bit of the alpha klaus in the aroma. the flavor is more roasty then the aroma but still quite hoppy with an interesting chocolate grapefruit thing going on. the body is surprisingly light. quite quaffable. i liked this much more than i had expected that i would.

Pours a beautiful deep dark coal/black with a nice thcik dark beige/light brown head which lasts, and leaves great lacing.  Initially when it is cold you can smell a bit of yeast along with some sweet malt, roasted barley, coffee, and a good amount of amarillo hops, then gives way to straight roasted barley with an even bigger hop presence.  Possibly one of the hoppiest smelling dry stout.  Flavor has lots of roast up front with a bit of sweet caramel malts, but finishes moderately bitter with a nice roasty dry finish.  Smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle, shared with Jerc, Harry, Greg, and Blankboy, Harrys bottle.  Lovely fresh hop aroma - smelled blind, you would never guess this is a stout, the aroma was that hoppy and that immense.  Some chocolate and roast once you get past the hops too.  Pitch black, small chocolaty brown head.  Taste features the hops again and some chocolate.  The body though is disappointingly thin.  While the flavour remains bitter throughout, you do get some roast and smoke.  Very long bitter linger.  The stout flavours do put up a fight trying to break through the hops.  Put some body in this please, it would be world class.

This bottled brew from the Fort Wayne Locals tasting event on 2/4/06 poured a small sized head of mostly lasting foamy fine to medium sized dark brown colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing and an opaque black body with no hope of viewing the carbonation level.  The aroma was nice with hoppy roasty toasty dark malty notes.  The mouth feel was tingly at the start then merged into a strong hoppy finish with a lingering mild malty aftertaste.  The flavor contained roasted malt and hop notes.
Pour is black with a thin tan head...smell is toasty coffee and hops...taste was a tad sweet up front, turning hoppy hoppy toward the finish...a tad watery...

Another disappointment from Three Floyds. Aroma was nice with strong malt bill with chocolate and hops. Appearnce was dark with a tan head, nothing really special. Mouthfeel was on the thinnish side and the flavor was off somehow. Hops and smoke really dont make good bedfellows. So far 0-2 for the boys from Indiana.

650ml bottle. Black pour with nearly zero head. Forms a wisp of a khaki ring of tight weak bubbles. Aroma is a sucker punch of hops, dark chocolate and smoky malts, and blackberries. The beer is surprisingly smooth and well-balanced. Reasonably thick stout with ideal carbonation. Not unlike the Alpha Klaus though drier on the finish and not quite as resinous. I particularly appreciate the reasonable ABV.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours black with an average size creamy light-brown head. I took a whiff of this bad boy and exclaimed "WHOA!" -- I was not expecting that. "That" being the huge hoppy aroma that first hits your senses followed by coffee, some chocolate and roasted malt -- it doesnt  smell like your average Stout but boy do I love it! The flavour, which I also love, is also HOPS, coffee and chocolate -- it has a huge lasting bitterness. Its somewhat light bodied but its not detrimental to the beer. This is quite an interesting take on a Dry Stout and I must say Im quite impressed with it, it smells and tastes wonderful. I have to get me more of these!

From bottle.  Pours black with a thick brown head.  Aroma is very grassy hops with some roasted malts underneath.  The most hops Ive ever smelled in a stout.  Flavor is roasted nuts, black liquorish and a good bitter.  Nice.

Black body with think tan head, a great consistency to the appearance.  3Fs really ought to be commended for the hop presence in the aroma rather than criticized because I think it is interesting how all their brews have the same sweet citrus aroma regardless of the taste, its uncanny.  Tastes like a Christmas Porter with more roast malts and chocolate.  Rich dry finish.

Bottle. Black body with a moderate khaki head. Powerful aroma is a strange blend of chocolate and very green hops. Reminds me a bit of Alpha Klaus, not in character but in the strangeness of the dichotomy. Initial sip is unpleasant coffee ground like bitterness, but smooths out as the glass goes on. Lots of ashen-roast bitterness throughout, accented by dark bitter chocolate. Thinnish palate. Unique.

Bottle (650ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jer and tupalev - my bottle.  Looked basically opaque, oily, thick black with an average creamy brown head.  Aroma - holy *&$%, hops!  Lush, almost overwhelming resiny hops, roastiness and chocolate begin to compete as it warms, but its mostly about the hops; maybe this isnt balanced but its awesome.  Taste of deep roast coffee, chocolate, and waves of funky resiny hops, almost sweet they were so pungen - like fresh-crushed mint leaves.  This had a long, bitter, slightly grassy finish, with a bitter, flat mouthfeel and a slightly thin body - The consensus was we all really liked it, but the body left it a little short of an outstanding dry stout - and unique in our experience.  (we all let out with a "wow!" on first sniff)

My second bottle of this was different from the first.  The first I instantly dubbed "Storm King Lite", as the hop profile was strikingly similar, but the whole experience was just a bit more restrained.  My second bottle highlighted more of the beers malt character.  It is a complex and rich array of dark malt flavors, essentially those which I would expect in a top quality American stout.  Regardless of where the focus lay, the beer was truly enjoyable.  I do not share my comrades view that the beer was wierdly unbalanced.  Seemed fine to me.  Oh, and it is ridiculously overpriced.

I would say that this is the best dry stout Ive ever had.  Normally, I like my stouts full and slightly sweet, but this really did it for me.  it pours jet black with a paltry hear.  The aroma is the hoppiest Ive found in a stout, with notes of very bitter chocolate.  The flavor is dry and smoky, with hints of the hops, chocolate and slight sweetness.  It was a good foil for the stream of huge imperial stouts I had been drinking.

Bottle. Deep dark black in color with a nice tan head. Malty roasty and hoppy aroma. Like a chocolate hoppy Ipa. Lots of hops. Nice hop bite. Malty and hoppy flavor. Light bodied. Sweet tasting. Caramel notes. Finish is dry. Very nice beer. Drinkable.

"2nd 3floyds tonight and another not so good of one. Pour pitch black nice chocolate head. Aroma was hops which i didnt think was supposed to be in this style. no where close to a guiness and they are much cheaper. "

Beautiful appearing beer, pouring black with a gorgeous, totally retained tan colored head.  Big hoppy aroma akin to a Christmas tree.  This is the aroma I remember from the 04 bottling of Alpha Klaus, and I love it.  Wonderful flavor of chocolate malt, coffee, and the ubiquitous Floyds hops.  Delicious.

Bottle.  Pours a very deep shiney black with a nice fading brown head. The head  leaves a nice film over the beer and produces decent  glass lacing.  Aroma is very vineous, hoppy-like.  There are also slight notes of coffee and possibly charred wood.  Flavor is nice and clean.  Notes of coffee, cooking chocolate, burnt coffee beans, and oddly hops and a nice dry milk chocolate finish.  Really quite complex when I think about it.  Nice beer.

Nice, pours a nice deep black color with a medium-dark tan head that turns to film. Almost a kind of hoppy aroma when I opened the bottle...a bit of coffee and a bit of pine...interesting. The flavor is nice and crisp...bitter coffee bean, bitter chocolate, pine, smoke...not really what I was expecting but its still a nice combonation of flavors for this dry stout.  Initially bitter over the tounge the turns to a nutty, dry finnish with a slighty bitter aftertaste. This beer had a lot of little suprises that I really enjoyed...it was as if this was the bastard child of a sweet sout and an ipa.

The aroma is highly hopped, which is a pleasant surprise from most dry stouts.  It is also malty and roasty and indeed, dry.  The flavor is somewhat too hoppy, though, and it is slightly metallic.  Vanilla and dry minerals, and woody/earthy too.  A decent dry stout.

Thanks to OhioDad for the bomber - nice black pour with lasting off-white head - very woody, hoppy nose, making me wary that this will be overhopped for a stout - however, the hops dont overpower the mild caramel sweetness and dry roastiness of the flavor - instead, they add a very woody flavor that compliments the dryness very well - a hint of dried fruits in the finish - very nice stuff.

Really cool lookin bomber.  Poured damn near black with garnet highlights and a moderate cap of toffee head.  Nose begins with roasty, almost burnt chocolate and coffee malts followed by 3F signature hop blast (pine forest engulfed the nose)... Flavor had great balance between the bittering pine hoppiness, burnt coffee, dark chocolates, and had an added dark fruity dimension.  Finish was lenghtly and dry with copious amounts of pine and coffee bitterness, roasted chocolate, caramel sweetness, and licorice.  This was an excellent treat all around!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2007 Pitch black color pour. No light goes thru even on the edges. Quickly diminishing tan head. Coffee, chocolate liquorish aroma.  Dark fruit and almost some dish soap. Flavor is mostly biter coffee, but also some of the liquorish.  Body is oily and silky smooth.  Weird but nice.  8/4/7/4/16 

RERATE: 22oz bottle approx 6 months old. Pour is black with a head of tan cream. The head quickly reduces to little more than a ring around the glass. Aroma is a pleasant roast with a bitter dark chocolate backbone. Flavor is much the same as the aroma but flip flopped. The dark chocolate is prominent but there is also some light bitterness from the remaining hops. The body is perfect. Smooth. Nicely carbonated. Great stuff. 7/3/8/5/18

Bomber - I normally like the hopped qualities much more in the three floyds beers.  This beer had the look and aroma of a great beer.  However, I couldnt get over the fact that it seemed I was drinking a very bitter chocolate coffee.  The bitterness seemed to overpower the beer.  At $8.25 a bottle, 1 is enough for me.
Dark black with only a slight brown head. Aroma of piney hops, roast and coffee. Flavor of piney hops, dark chocolate, roast and coffee. Long bitter chocolate finish.

Deep black, some brown at very edge, nice tan head fades into a ring.  Purdy.  Massive hop aroma, loads of pine, and a roast coffee undertone with a hint of cherry.  Initial blast of spruce in the mouth, melds into cherry and raspberry dark fruits, a bit of chocolate, and bitter roasted coffee finish.  Medium bodied, and wonderfully complex.  This is a fantastic beer.
Bottled.  Pours black with a light tan head.  Malty aroma with notes of chocolate and hops.  Thin, bitter flavor with a strange mustiness.
Sampled at Dickinsonbeers NJ January gathering.  opaque dark brown color, tan foamy head.  hoppy roasted malt aroma.  flavor is dry hoppy and dry roasted malt.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 had the special version at the 3 floyds brewpub.  started off amazing.  at first was easily the best stout of its style ive had in a long time.  but my taste buds were shot after like 8 ounces.  the rest was still good, of course, and i dont know the solution, but it was disappointing the rest of it wasnt as enjoyable as the first sips... rerate.  from the bottle, this is no good.  all smoked malts, but the aroma is poor.  all weird hops.  taking it down a few pegs.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2006 Huge aromas, huge flavors, huge bitterness. This isnt your traditional Irish or dry stout. This beer is just jam packed with character. Black Sun pours to an ink black color, with a nice tan head, that fades, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is very zesty and aromatic, with a big punch of piney/citrus hops, paired with aromas of chocolate, cocca powder, and roast. The palate is firm with lots of big chocolate malt flavors, paired with flavors of pine tar, and hints of coffee. Black Sun finishes with big dark chocolate, and coffee flavors, then ends with a big smack of piney/citrus hop bitterness that lingers. Wow. Fantastic stout, with huge aromas, flavors and character. A great American twist on an Irish classic.

Wow, big hoppy aroma and flavour, not something I would have expected out of a stout.  It is big and bold, but really lacks some stout body.  it does have some faint smoky charing, but not enough to make me want to return.  If I want a dark IPA, Ill go for a double IPA...  not a stout.

Bottle. Pours a black color with an average creamy light brown head that lasted and produced good lacing. Heavy roasted coffee chocolate and pine aroma. Medium body with a creamy texture. Very good complex roasted malt, chocolate and sweet fruit flavor with a moderate pine bitter finish of long duration. Very good brew at a fair price.

Nice dark pour, quote of the night from some uninitated chick, "Is that beer? Thats the darkest beer Ive ever seen." Followed by me holding it up to the light and saying, "Nope, not even close." This one had a nice dry hoppy aroma which matched the flavor. Not what I expect from a stout, but I felt it worked well with this one. I have to admit, the 3F label probably swayed me a bit, but I really enjoyed this one.
Bomber.  Grapefruit molasses first; hoppy up front, coffe alternating with chocolate behind the american mint snap hops.  Beer is a fin grizzly bear.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 Pours pitch black with a medium tan head. Great mix of dark roasted grains and fresh Pacific NW piney hops in the nose. Whoah, very very hoppy for a stout. Fresh grapefruit/pine hops accompanied by dark roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, sweet caramel and raisin. Pleasantly sweet, ample bitterness provided by the combination of the hops and from the roasted malts. Somewhat of a burnt aftertaste. Medium bodied, very smooth and creamy with moderate carbonation. I love these guys.

Bottle at 2/4/06 Fort Wayne Tasting. Poured a tan small head that quickly dissipated, sparse lacing, no visible carbonation, opaque, and a black hue. Malty, chocolate, coffee, roasty, hoppy nose. Flavor mimicks the nose with a slight burnt taste. Tingly palate. Medium-full body. This beer would have earned a higher overall score from me had they laid off the hoppiness a little bit.

bottle - woah, this is one intense dry stout.  Theres a very distinct malt aroma and it pours up a moderate, long lasting head and a very deep black color.  Roasted malt, and surprisingly for the style, signficant hops dominate the flavor.  Theres also a hint of coffee.  This beer is very full bodied and has a long, malty finish.  Its too heavy for me to drink as a session brew, but still an altogether pleasant drinking experience.  Thanks to Thedm and Hotstuff for sharing the bottle.

Plenty of nice hops on the nose of this coal-black bad boy.  Pine, grapefruit, herbs and rosemary.  Great flavors of coffee, chocolate, candied orange and some ripe red fruits are 180 degrees off from the aromas.  A dry, hoppy finish closes the beer, but the fruit continues to linger on the palate.  Definitely something new and unique.
Bottle courtesy of dough77.  Wow, not what I was expecting.  Great hop flavor and aroma.  Pushes the limits of the style.  Very different.  Clean, fresh hop flavor w/ mild malt background.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2006 Looks like the perfect stout, pitch black, with mocha colored head.  Aroma is just like every other 3 Floyds brew, very piney and citrusy with a slight amounts of coffee burnt flavor.  Very reminiscent of Alpha Klaus.  Why Hop it this way?  I opened the bottle and instantly knew it was 3 Floyds.  Its a black IPA.  Frankly I like it, not as a Dry Stout which it isnt, and definitely not at $9 a bottle.  I like the hop combination, but enough is enough.  Lets do something different.

Pours with a black head topped by a thin head with little lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy for a stout, in fact the hops overpower everything else.  The flavor is sweet yet bitter with a roasty malt note and an obvious hoppiness.  Full bodied, smooth and slightly dry.
a very tasty stout. Mucho hops are present, definite 3F house flavor. Big dry malt taste, plenty of flavors floating around in there.  A tasty tipple. Nice dark brown head.

There is an aroma of dark chocolate and roasted malt.  Also in the background is a hint of dark fruit.  The color is a rich deep black with a short lasting tan head.  The flavor is at first of dark chocolate, followed by a coffee like roastedness and a dark fruit finish on the palate.

Thanks cquiroga!  Pours a clear black color with a very small off-white head and not really any lacing.  Aroma is roasty with slight alcohol hints.  Flavor is weaker than I had hoped for, but still roasty and slightly rich in flavor.  Very smooth, almost bubbly on the palate.  Not great as Ive come to expect from 3F but still good!

Thanks to Dickinsonbeer for sharing this at the January gathering.  Poured black with a creamy brown head.  Strong pine and grapefruit hop aroma, which would have been awesome on an IPA, but seemed misplaced here.  Taste has some good roastiness to it with a hint of chocolate, but the hops are really getting in the way.  Much too hoppy.

On tap at the brewery.  Dark opaque with a nice clinging tan head.  Sweet malt nose with hints of coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Sweet yet floral aroma.  Dry and well hopped.  Bitter with chocolate notes.  Slightly fruity and caramel.  Still good amount of tan head towards the end of the glass.  Great lacing around the top of the glass.  Top quality dry stout!
heavily hoppy and roasty but medium bodied.  just rich enough, but still very drinkable.  would be an excellent session stout.

Bottle. Crazy good. Pours absolute black with thick soapy head. Swirls oily and coats the glass. Smelled like insane coffee and molasses. Tasted smokey, coffee, and sweet. Carmel at the balanced finish. Hints of hops balance it out. Creamy moutfeel. Finish was shorter than I expected.

22 oz bomber.  I wanted my 100th rated beer to be something special, and this was it.  Pours a deep dark brown with a thin tan head.  The aroma is a bit floral, which is very different for a stout.  The taste is malty, with chocolate, coffee, and a nice hopped finish.  A very pleasant beer to drink.

22 oz. bomber at Dickinsonbeers gathering. Dark brown, almost black color with a small tan head. Nice hoppy, roasted malt aroma with just a hint of coffee. Very mild roasted malt flavor with lots of hop bitterness. Nice, easy drinking stout.

Bottle. Pours opaque blackness with a small tan head. Nose is big roastiness with lots of coffee and a nice hop profile. Taste is very nice! Fresh hops, caramel, dark chocolate, roasted malts, sweetened coffee and light fruits (melon, citrus, raisins). Very nice! Body is medium with a mild carbonation feel. This is very slick and smooth and seemingly oily at times. Finishes with lots of bitterness. Coffee, hops, light pine, roasted malts, milk chocolate, hints of caramel and fruit. Nice beer!

This was my second sampling, and it was much better than the first. A powerful and somewhat unique, roasted malt and hop aroma greets your nose,classic stout darkness, a monsterous smokey roast coffee bean and malt taste,with bitter chocolate aftertones. Was looking for coffee grounds on the bottom. A little to one dimensional to be rated among the best,a little pricey also, but still a very good brew. Makes me wish I could try a Dark Lord even more

Pours out a nice dark thick black color with a small tan head. Nice hop aroma. The taste is very nice, rich roasted malts with notes of some chocolate and maybe a bit of coffee here and there. Smooth silky mouthfeel made this a very drinkable beer. I liked this one a lot, maybe just because Im such a hop head, but I thought the blend was very nice.

Pours black with a dark, two-finger head. The first whiff is mostly light hops, but others reveal decent dark malt aromas. Chocolate, coffee, and chocolate in the flavor, with a finish thats just a tad too hoppy--it doesnt blend well. Still a good beer.

22oz bottle via trade with sprinkle - Thanks Mike! - Pours black with a beautiful creamy tan head that stays well and laces beautifully on the sides of the glass.  Aroma is surprising pine and citrus, well not really so surprising considering it is 3 Floyds..  Flavor is much more of the traditional dry stout.  Roasted malt, coffee, a touch of chocolate, balanced with those citrus hops. Much like the Alpha Klaus porter but less chocolate and a little less body.  Palate is rather light but interestingly creamy with a dry finish.    Another very unique and interesting beer from a fun brewer!  I liked it..

22 oz bomber.  First off i must mention that Rayboys review below does not mention that I was the one who obtained this fine brew for him.  Not only did I share a bomber with him in my own home , but I gave him a bomber for the road, yet there is no mention of this in his rating.  That really burns me up.  I should mention that he helped me fix a couple of radiators at my house "free" of charge so perhaps one should disregard my gripe  ;)  The brew pours dark with thin brown head.  Pine and grapefruit aromas caught me offguard followed by roasted malts.  This was an interesting brew and quite good.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2006 Thank you, Oh El Borracho, for not only this sample bomber, but also for all your help when I repaired your heating system, free of charge, on a Sunday, my one day "off"...because without you and your vast knowledge of construction/ maintainance,  I would not have known what to do next!....Interesting stout with an unexpected citrusy hop profile that surprised me.   Big dry stout sweet/roasted malt base note, but nicely counterbalanced with   very robust grapefruit/orange hop notes.   Quite drinkable and refreshing.

On tap at the brewpub 12/16/2005: Opaque black nitro pour has a thick, well-lacing tan head.  Amazingly fresh, hoppy, trademark Three Floyds aroma has a good semi-sweet roasty balance. Body starts with a sweet roasted malt, well-balanced with a lot of hops and a dry, smooth dark chocolate finish.  Reminds me of Alpha Klaus with a little less malt.  Very nice.  If this werent so expensive, Id drink it every day.

Pours a full dark brown and sits black beneath a dark tan head.  The aroma is wonderful.  Great big robust roasted and smoky malts and a wonderfully balanced sweet citric hop.  Coffee malts and sweet orange hop aromas are noticed later.  The flavor is a strong coffee flavor.  Roasted but also nicely balanced from what appears to be a fairly sizable hop bill for a stout.  Clean crisp citrus hop bitterness goes great with the bitterness that emerges from the coffee flavors.  The finish is shared by a nice dryness and a citric hop bitterness.  Unique stout.  Im glad that its not overpowering in alcohol or malt.  The aroma immediately identified it as a Three Floyds beer and its balance didnt disappoint me.

WOW.  When I first opened the bottle, the Hop aroma erupted from the bottle before I even poured it.  Pours black with frothy light brown head.  Nose is incredibly hoppy and even a hint of citrus.   Oily with chocolate and coffee-like tones.  Well balanced.  Roasted malt character with piney/dry finish. Unique but nice beer.

Super black in the glass allowing no light thru.  Nice head that st\ettled pretty quickly.  Lots of chocolate in the nose.  Initially, when served probably too cold, I truly enjoyed it.  Very malty with a touch of citrus.  The hops werent very noticible until the beer warmed.  As it warmed, the bitterness of the hops came thru and my enjoyment level went way down.  Id get it again, but would have to share it or drink faster!

22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark black color with a medium sized beige head.  Aroma is of sweet dark chocolate,roasted dry hops,(that vintage 3 Floyds piney hop scent) and killer malts.  Flavor is of rich sweet dark chocolate, the kind used for baking, roasted hops galore and more chocolate malts.  Excellent !!  Another gem from those Three Floyds.

Deep dark body and a tan head with an oily fade. Nice aroma of unsweetened chocolate with nectarine and mango hop notes. Signature Three Floyds hop profile. Flavor is moderately roasty with smooth dark malts and some citrus and tropical fruit hop flavor. Some rich sweetness initially but finishes dry with substantial bitter aspirin. A medium-bodied and good American-style stout.
A hoppy/minty session stout that is nice and dry. The dryness was very quenching. Urbnhautebourg suggested that this beer is like a Storm King light, which I agree with wholeheartedly.

22 oz capped bottle, fairly fresh: slightly opaque, brunt red-charcoal.  Fluffy, light chocolate coloured, very modest sized head.  Dusty Bakers chocolate and mild piney hop aroma with hints of oatmeal, roasted bark and nuts, and grapefruit.  Quite strong bitterness mixed with hop flowers, roasted dark chocolate and a lactic sourness provide a decent, but fairly non-descript flavour.  Long blackberry fruitiness and lingering hop bite make this a tasty beer, but it doesnt strike me like some of the other 3Fs beers.
deep black color with a foamy brown head.  heavy chocolate malts.  lightt sweetness and a strong coffee flavor.  caramel is appaerent but not overpowering.

(22oz bottle) Black body with small tan head.  Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some chocolate, light peach.  Taste is medium sweet, bittersweet chocolate, roasty, with a grapefruit finish.  Light-medium body.  Much more hops than what I think of in a dry stout -- this is a good thiing.

Small cocoa powder colored head thats short lived, thin, tight beaded lace. Dense blackness, opaque. Lightly oily, medium bodied. Nose is chocolatey and hoppy, resinous with a chocolate coated pineyness. Chocolate, roast, piney and citrusy hop flavors, a touch of black patent chalkiness, coffee and hints of blueberry also. Dry finish is hoppy and roasty. A nice Dry Stout! Kool label too!
Ths beer is black. I had it on tap in the brewpub. The smell is of sweet roasted malt. There is a mild hop backbone. It is a light stout for three floyds.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of TomDecapolis. Poured a dark black with red edges and an averaged sized light brown head. Aromas of heavy pine (hmmm, a hoppy FFF beer), with some roasted malts and chocolates trying to come through. Tastes of pine (not as strong as the aroma, but still strong), roasted malts, chocolate and a bitter coffee finish. Thinner body for a dark stout. Nice piney burps.

Pours a dark black with an average size tan head that left great lacing.  Aroma of pine hops, roasty malts, coffee, minty, roasty and chocolate.  Flavor is dry with cocoa, some coffee, and some of the hops in the tail.  A little thin but still a great stout.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2006 (12.31.05) On tap at Firkins, Libertyville, IL. Blacked hued stout with small off-white head and spare lacing.  No discernable carbonation. Roasted malt and coffee aromas.  Medium bodied stout that starts dry with burnt roasted malt, expresso and hop flavors. Finishes dry with lingering bitterness.  A good drinkable dry stout. Enjoyed  at a special New Years Eve dinner with visiting family members at Firkins. UPDATE (05.18.06) One pint, 6 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. Poured opaque black with small tan head. Soft carbonation.  Hoppy and roast malt aroma. Medium bodied stout that start with light malt sweetness and fruity (raisin), roasted malt, and hoppy flavors. Finished dry with lingering bitterness.  Starts smooth with complex flavor character but raggedy finish. Delicious stout but could be further improved with some aging to smooth out the rough finish. The bottled version was superior in flavor compared to the tap version, thus the rating reflects the average.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 Original rating 1/11/06 - 6/5/6/4/15=3.6 - 22oz - Aroma is pretty much all fresh floral hops.  I do get a touch of chocolate malt in there as well.  Pours black with a thick medium brown head and great lacing.  Flavor is a lot more malty than the aroma leads on.  Roasted chocolate malt with hops bringing in the rear.  Palate is sticky and snappy.  A very different stout that needs to be tasted to be appreciated.  It was confusing to have such a hoppy nose with a roasty flavor. RERATE same batch as original rating - Aroma is very roasty chocolate malt with a lingering earthy smell like potting soil.  Flavor is creamy  chocolate, caramel, a touch of nuttiness.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  I like it a lot better now that the hops have mellowed.  They took too much away from the roasty choclate that I love in a dry stout.
This is a pretty good stout.  I like that it has a strong hop character.  I had this right before a founders breakfast stout, and this was a bit better.

This looks and feels like a great stout. Dark, opaque, full-bodied, beige head and lacing. Then theres the aroma and flavor. Very hoppy. I guess that is characteristic of every Three Floyds beer Ive had. Im not a big hop fan (I tend to shy away from IPAs as a result), so this was kind of a disappointment for me. I got used to the hops as I kept drinking, but I wish they werent so pronounced. Stouts are one of my favorite styles, but this was not one of my favorite stouts.

From a bomber which opened with much of a carbonation hiss. Pours pretty flat with a black body. Aroma has a piney hop smell similar to Alpha Klaus. Flavor has a burnt roasted flavor without much hop flavor until the aftertaste. The flavors seem to conflict more than compliment each other. Easy to drink since theres not much carbonation. A little disappointing for 3Fs.

Thanks for sharing Chuck!
Dark brown with red hints around the edge. Full creamy head, leaves a nice ring. Dry roasty metallic malt covered by piney "Batch 7000" and "Dark Lord" citrusy//piney hops. Not much else in there though. There is a conflict in there between roasted malts and fresh bright hops. Same with the flavor. Dry roasty malts, bunch of bright hops. I wonder what this would be like without the hops. Personally, I think they add a nice flavor, but (and not to rate by style), but are a little much for a dry stout. But, it is a good beer.

Dark black pour huge frothy tan small bubbled well laced head.  First smell is the huge dry hopping coming off this beer monster fresh grass and pine hops.  Hints of a smoked and roasted malt follow that smells like it would be a big beer.  Palate is fairly avg, decent coating and body not very big.  Flavor is great.  The dry hoping gives a style (dry stout) i normally find to boring a great kick.  The flavor explodes with roast malts and pine hops hints of a light fruitness in the background w/ a touch of chocolate.  A very good stout.
Pours black with big dark brown head.  Aroma is hoppy and smoky.  Flavor is pretty solid.  A good stout with some smoky flavors but no hops.  A solid Three Floyds product.

Black as night decent tan head that is pretty quickly fading, lace sticks pretty well.  Roasty malts and hops are previlent on the nose and a slight bubblegum.  Rich and expansive, sweet roasted malts, slight hops and a slight almost watermelon then a nice dryness on the finish.

Thanks go out to Tom and Eric for each bring a 22oz bottle to the KC holiday tasting. Nearly black color with a hazy head. Roasty malt and buttermilk aroma with some background hops. Taste is roasty with chocolate and moderately bitter hops. Enjoyable.

Black with a wispy mocha head.  Smells of roasty chocolate and pine needles.  Flavor is pretty similar, lots of piney hops at the forefront with some bitter coffee and dark chocolate in the background.  Balanced somewhat by a deep molasses sweetness.

2005 bomber from Rooftoprogue, drunk on 12/31/05.  Pours a dark brownish-black, transluscent-to-transparent, with tan edges and an initially large tan head.  Begins like a typical dry stout, appearance-wise, but the head, while it never diminishes completely, does recede rather quickly to cover with no lacing.  Would like to have seen better head retention, especially on a dry stout, but hey, thats the price you pay for fake carbonation and filtration.  The aroma is bursting with fuzzy hops.  Green, mossy, quite floral and just really interesting.  Almost like an herbal-spiciness with touches of conifer in the background.  I didnt get any smoke out of the nose, but there is a light espresso, salty roast and hint of vanilla creaminess.  The hops are really aromatic, rather dominating the nose, but hey, at least its a dry stout you can smell!  The flavor begins with an equal burst of fuzzy, green, leafy hops, quite flavorful and dry, with some minty-pine notes, hickory nuts and notes of orange zest.  Behind the hops is a distinct coffee note, that is nowhere near overdone and adds bits of vanilla and creamy malt.  The hops recede and leave in place a brace of caramel malt sweetness, ending on a roasted bitterness, well-controlled and lacking any acrid/acidic notes.  With continued drinking and warming, the hops remain strong in the flavor, never too bitter, with more chocolate and a light playfulness of cherries and dates, though overshadowed greatly by the vanilla and coffee notes.  Everything seems well-placed, with the ingredients being easily identified and staggered for effect.  The texture is lightly creamy, the malts soft on the palate, and the carbonation, while a bit prickly at times, does not seem to disrupt the body significantly.  The sweetness is certainly there, not in force, but I dont find the body thin or lacking.  A unique interpretation of the style (would not expect anything less from 3Fs), carefully constructed with no alcohol apparency.  Thanks so much Rob!
excellant stout sweet and smooth as silk with a little hop to it just right good job guys again

22oz. bottle.  Very interesting aroma, some nicely hoppy accents (Chinook?), piney and spicy along with plenty of highly roasty, silky maltiness, some faint smoke and earthiness, even some slight hints of black olive and perfume.  Opaque ebony color with a fine, slight head and sparse lacing.  Flavor profile features an influx of spicy hop flavor up front, more fresh pine and earth overlaying the dark, roasty malt foundation which does indeed provide a dry, rather short finish and featuring a lingering blend of cocoa bean and hop flavor.  Bitterness is light-medium, as is the body.  Mouthfeel is is effervescent and perhaps just a tad thin.  Still, particularly for the style, this is pretty impressive and unique.

Bomber bottle and served in one of my Expedition snifters, stoutie rating #499: Poured opaque with a moderate initial tan frothy head that settles of a small coating and left very good lace. The nose on this is super hoppy, if I was blind I would think it to be an IPA! Lot of pine resin and grapefruit (similar to that of Alpha Klaus but more pronounced), light roasted coffee and chocolate esters, and a hit of black patent malt. The taste is not has hoppy as the aroma thank goodness but you can still get some piney and citric qualities towards the finish. The forefront is more towards burnt and sweet malts with a espresso like bitter undertone and even a hint of walnut. The feel is lively and quite smooth with the exception of a metallic astrengent and dry finish. Quite drinkable really, it will be much like Alpha Klaus and Gumballhead for me, when I seek something in a style that is more towards a hoppy than malty or wheaty character. It will be interesting to see how much the hop nature mellows over time.
Bottle.  Very hoppy aroma.  Dark black pour.  A very sweet taste.  Not as hoppy as it smells but a nice finish with a hint of the hops.

Pours black with a thick tan head.  Aroma was very hoppy consisting of smoked coffee and chocolate plus citrus.  Similar to the Alpha Klaus.  Taste was the hoppiest Ive encountered in the style.  That being said.  I liked this anyway.

Cascade? Chinook? Probably chinook, and lots of them in the nose!  This massive citric hop aroma, with a touch of piney resin, is the hoppiest nose on a stout Ive ever encountered.  Curiously the hops are much less pronounced in the mouth; smooth and clean with roasted and smoky notes. Just a touch of grassy and piney hops in the flavor.  Medium bitter finish.  Dark brown color, and khaki head.  A curious, unusual and interesting beer.

This beer offers an aroma consisting of hops, fruit, and citric acid.  It is black with a creamy coffee colored head.  This beer enters the mouth as a thick solution with a bitter-sweet coffee taste.  A smoky flavor rolls in then dissipates leaving a mild sour bitter taste lingering on the tongue.

Deep black body with a thin, almost non-existant brown head.  Aroma is hoppy with some burnt notes.  Taste is similar - mostly hops with burnt chocolate and maybe a bit of citrus.  Not much in the way of malty sweetness.  Palate is smooth but not very full.  A good but not great stout.

Courtesy of Slob.

Aroma smells like a cross between plastic, burning rubber and vinyl. Normally Id be worried, but the last beer I had that had that aroma was Gonzo Imperial Porter and I loved that. Deep black with a huge two finger thick mocha head. Fore is dominated by intense hops. I dont know what kind of hops they used, but it has an almost plastic-like flavor. Very roasty in the middle with some chocolate notes, but the hops carry allt he way through to the finish. A Year ago I would have thought this was way too hoppy, but it works well in this beer....though I will say i wish i could taste a little bit more of the malt base...its hard when the hops linger so long through all the flavor ranges.
Draft - odd aroma for a stout.  Next to nothing but grassy hops.  Nearly black body with a medium brown head.  The hops fight with the chocolate/coffee malt.  Far from my favorite.

Black Suns brownish black color and dark tan head could stand up to most imperial stouts in terms of darkness. Its nose is mostly citric American hops w/ a chocolate roast character not far in the background. As per their description this is somewhat light bodied yet still quite full flavored and not all watery. Mild carbonation w/ a crisp astringent bite from the roasted grains backed up by a lingering hoppy bitterness in the finish.

heemer brought this bomber to the 2005 Christmas gatering at hey_kevins.  a black motor oil pour with strong hoppy aroma.  flavor was rather harsh with dark roasted malt, slightly burnt coffee and piney hops.  not what I was expecting, some age might help this one but I doubt it.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2006 Rerate from a bottle.  Even better.  The aromas and flavors are much better balanced.  3F should get rid of the nitro in the brewpub.

Nitro pour in Dec 2005.  Black as black can be with a brown nitro head.  Huge hop aroma.  Grass and citrus.  Would be better if some or the roast came through.  You can get a light dry roasted character, but the hops are the showcase.  Piney, grassy.  A touch sweet up front with a nice dry finish.  Light body, very smooth due to the nitro.  Id say this is basicly a typical Irish stout with amped up hops.

from a 22 oz. bottle thanks to heemer77.  sampled at hey_kevins christmas gathering.  Dark opaque pour with a dark tan head that stuck around the edge.  Piney aroma, as well as coffee, and some dark, earthy smells.  Taste was mainly coffee, with some caramel and nuts too.  The hoppy finish was harsh though.  This needs some more balance and it would be better.  Thanks Eric

Bomber. Blackish with some tan head, somewhat transparent. Why oh why must they filter and force carbonate? Nose is pure American Cascades and alcohol along with some scant mocha. Flavor is strange. The cascades are defintely a different touch, but dont really mesh well with the minimal malts in this one. Very dry. And why is the alcohol so dominant in this one? Is it really only 5.25% ABV, if so, that is not good. Needs balance.

22oz bomber from JoshuaB. Pours a thin black with a ligh tan head. Nose is light chocolate and alcohol, some mild toffee notes. Taste is thin, watery, light chocolate, more alcohol, a dry bitter off sensation. This just didnt sit well with me, but I cant put my finger on this feature that just made the beer not good. It had kind of a bland, watered down and just not fitting taste.

From the bottling in late 2005. This poured with a black body topped by a peach and orange colored head. The aroma was grassy with pine and coffee. It is obviously another hopped up 3Fs brew. The mouthfeel was smooth and slick. The taste had coffee and bitter dark chocolate. There was also some tobacco. Nicely done and interesting, but certainly not close to style.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of dry roasted malts, vanilla, some smoke, pine, grass, and citrus fruits.  Smoke, hazelnuts, chocolate, and roasted malt in the taste, bitter hoppy finish.  Dry finish, but thin mouthfeel.

On tap at the brewery. Black with big long lasting brown tan frothy head. Nose is full and sweet with alcohol, fructose and maybe just a dab of ketones which is probably the hops that is pretty present. Roasted malts alcohol cheries and cofee grounds in the taste. THere is a bit of cream here and there. Overall I liked this one a lot.

Deep, intense black with a moderately fluffy tan head.  A hoppy nose reminiscent of Alpha Klaus.  Piney, resinous aroma walft out of the glass with underlying notes of caramel, cocoa, nuts, roasted coffee and some burnt toast elements.  The body is pretty thick and full, with mild carbonation proffering little prickling sensations on the tongue.  The flavor shows the fairly unique profile shown by Three Floyds.  The combination of fairly roasted malt with ultra bitter hops.  While I do enjoy the combination of flavors here, Im getting confused on the variation from other beers.  This could honestly be labled Alpha Klaus and I would believe it.  Almost, if not exactly, the same.  Good flavor, but boring in its lack of originality...

Lots of roasted coffee with some apricot hops.  Very much like alpha klaus.  Dark, dark black with a thin, brown head.  Flavors of roasted malt with lots of apricot hop...tons of hops.  Medium body and failry dry in the finish.  Reminded me a lot of alpha klaus.  I didnt like the combination of dryness and hops.

Milwaukee YEHa!05, brought by DavidP and 1FastSTi.  Dark brown body, light brown/tan head.  Huge Three Floyds "house" hops aroma- big pines and medicinal notes, with chocolate (overpowered by hops) in the background.  Really, a dead-ringer for Alpha Klaus.  But the flavor was quite different than the former beer, with licorice, toast, and chocolate leaving a sweet candy-like feel on the palate before, BAM!  The huge piney, medicinal hops slam the door on the palate and close out the beer on a bitter note.  The fruity aspect, almost reminiscent of cherry cordials or chocolate wafers, is unique.  Strange.  I cant really figure it out, but I liked this.

Bottle @ Milwaukee YeHa. Silky black body with a taller tan head. Aromas jump from the glass with fresh hops and a hint of roasted malt. Think Alpha Klaus, with a drier, chalkier character. A hoppy stout for sure.

On Tap(Nitro) @ the brewpub- Pours a pitch black color, nice sized light brown head. Aroma is crazy for a stout, citursy almost like a pale ale! Dry and sweet, the flavor is restrained, yet emphasized by the Guiness like stout charachteristics. A very interesting take on a dry stout.

Bottle... Pitch black ale with a small, creamy, light brown head. Very good retention. The nose delivers strong notes of chocolate and pine needles with lesser notes of caramel and vanilla.  The flavor is medium bitter and burnt. No residual sweetness... cocoa powder, coffee grounds and a pinch of salt. Light to medium-bodied with an astringent mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Finishes burnt, bitter then bone dry. Thanks go out to growler for sharing his bomber.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2008 I say WAY back that Id rerate this from the bottle, since my original rating was based on the muted nitro version that they always serve at the 3F brewpub.  The bottle version is very nice, allowing an aroma of resinous pine and some citric notes to shine through.  The flavor is also much more alive with a fresh hoppy bitterness.  Way better bottles... or probably draft, too, if they every drop the nitro crap.Original Rating 12/17/2005 - 7/3/6/3/15 - 3.4-------- />
Nitro at the FFF Pub:  I suspect my ratings will go up with the bottle that Ill pop later, cause nitroed beers are muted in aroma and taste.  Quite creamy to drink.  Heavily roasted malts and a solid floral/herbal hopping make for a good combination, but it tames the character of the brew when it nitros out of the spout.  Somewhat smokey, highly malted - its good, for sure.  But tamed.  Ill rerate on my bottle.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Floyds Brew Pub, Munster, IN<font size=-1>

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2006 Nitro at FFF.  Im so glad to see this come out of retirement!!!  It pours to a dark black body with a tan nitro head.  Thick and creamy head.  Dry and creamy.  The aroma is very hoppy with tons of PNW hops.  Also, dry and malty roastedness.  The flavor makes me think they took a Guinness and dry hopped the shit out of it.  The palate is pretty thick and dry.  Im loving it!!!
>>>>
Bottle: as good as the tap.

Purchased at Ronnies in Forest Hill,MD.22 oz bottle.Aroma is first heady floral hops(in standard 3F fashion)but then heavily roasted malts(coffee,chocolate,caramel,smoke)take over.Nice hoppy character.Oily on the verge of medium mouth feel.Good stuff but a bit pricy(8.99) but a rare one as far as I can tell.Mabey they put out more this year? The hop burps are very nice.

Nitro at the brew pub (with a forthcoming review of the bottled version - sit tight.)  Opaque and black in the imperial pint with a booming, dense and creamy khaki looking head that recedes to blanketing vellum lacing.  Black licorice and burnt espresso grinds paint the aromatic picture of a big roasty stout, with ample contributions from black currant, pepper, burnt rubber and oil streaks.  Some accentuations from Good & Plenty candy pieces as well.  "Roasted" is one way to say it; "singed" and "burnt" would be a more accurate descriptor, and, here, that gets you points in my book.  Iced coffee bitterness sinks into the taste buds, taking on a parallel flavor persona to one of those bottled frappuccinos sold in the supermarket.  Bitter, dark chocolate shavings melded to melted cappuccino ice cream.  Creamy and smooth character transitions to a prickly and lively (bitter) outtake with black jellybeans encapsulating the palates domain.  Nitro might rob some of the boisterous sentiments that I expect to find in the bottle version, and we all know theres one sure fire way to find that out.  Dense, chocolate brownies sprinkled with French roast coffee grinds takes us from flavor to finish.  Another admirable, style leading rendition by one of the worlds best.

This is as advertised!!!!  Thank you John for the bottle.  The beer pours black-as-night, with a nice head, that lasts a good few minutes.  The aroma is really overpowering, like opening a can of skunk-bud in a room.  You get the coffee, with plenty of roasted malt.  I taste chocolate, and coffee, very balanced.  Its very soft mouthfeel, is contrasted by a strong aftertaste ( maybe alcohol ).  I ts good now, in a few months, after it mellows, it will be that much beter.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2004 A stout, Three Floyds style, which can only mean hopped up. Grapefruit aroma in a stout? First taste citrus? Roasted malts and bitter sweet chocolates are next. Nice head and lacing from a growler. Are these guys awesome? Medium bodied and so drinkable its dangerous.

Draft at Monks Cafe in Philly. After all the Belgian stuff I had before this I thought my taste buds would be dead. Man was I wrong. This said HELLO your now drinking a beer from the USA. This had a wonderful hop smell that you could pick up across the room and  surpisingly it wasn't overpowering when you drank it. Finished with a nice smooth dry malt taste.
A travesty that this flavor packed dry stout, full of hops and sweetness should be rated lower than Guinness.  Tons of flavor, here, and a very nice appearance.  One of the better drys I've tried.
Wowza.  Hard to drink in the summer, but what choice have we?  I was impressed, but want to go back for a second try.
wow, slightly minty, excellent light roast, medium hops and some chocolate that goes great with Three Floyds House charecter.   Thank you Russo for buying this barrel

On Tap at the Blind Tiger Ale House, NYC: This stout pours a rich, deep, black color with a small, mostly diminishing tan head. The aroma is coffeeish and hoppy, with some malty sweetness and roasted malt hints. It has a medium body and moderate carbonation. The flavor is malty with roasted notes, a bit of chocolate, a fair amount of hops, and a slight hint of caramel. The finish is roast and slightly bitter from the hops. A very smooth, flavorfull, drinkable dry stout with that typical Three Floyds hoppy flavor.

Nice dark stout with a tan head.  Aroma is nice an hoppy - good florals, some pininess.  Flavor though is kind of mild - slightly thin and watery on the palate.  Mild roasted flavor, medium malt body.  Some mild hop bitterness.  Finishes clean - alsmot a bit too clean.  Unfortunatley, when I spotted it on tap I immediated was under the impression it was the Dark Lord Imperial Stout and was quite disapointed when I tasted it.  Now that I know that this is their dry stout, I can review it better in that category.
Beautiful dark stout. It has a smooth, silky palate and light astringent aftertaste. I can't get enough of it when it's on tap.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2006 Smooth stout with a great chocolate aroma of piney hops, slight dusty ester, some char and lots of coffee.  Sampled at the brewery it was pleasing to the palate. Nice hop finish, looking forward to trying the Imperial Stout.  Lots of hops in this one with alot of roast dominating the flavors.  Body is a little lite and this beer is somewhat one-dimensional, but still a tasty treat.

A little thinner in the body than it should be probably. All other components are there, though: Great deep black color, tan head, good dryness. Flavor: Moderately roasty with an unusual licorice-like component that I, personally, really like. Kind of tough to find, but worth it.
Dark and lifeless.  Too thin for a stout.  The only distinguishing marks are some bitter hops.  Its soapy and weak.  Disappointing from such a good brewer.
UPDATED: DEC 6, 2004 Nicely hopped black gold, thick and rich with hints of chocoilate and pine. Caramel aftertaste mixed with the hoppy pine and roasty dryness makes it hard to put the pint down,

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2005 Well, Three Floyds had to lay an egg sometime, and this is it. Really boring, watery stout, distinguished only by a ton of bittering hops. Normally Id like this level of hoppiness, but here theres nothing to back it up.
A little too dry for my tastes. A bit watery on the palate as well. Not my favorite 3Fs offering, but Im not a great Stout fan either.
A great stout, although I like Robert The Bruce Better.
